The President-elect told Tom Friedman of The New York Times that as a good Baptist he believed in conversion, and that perhaps the dictator could be dealt with if he acceded to U.N. arms-destruction and human-rights requirements.

title: Publishers Banking on Foreign Sales
description: At last year's Frankfurt Book Fair, Random House introduced its hottest new author, Gen. Colin L. Powell, who was paid a $6.5 million advance for his autobiography, by displaying his oversized photograph all over its booth. The goal was to find a publisher who would buy the overseas rights.

title: Framingham Journal; Backroom Where Talk Of Politics Is Relished
description: Barry Sokolov and his buddies were sitting on broken-down chairs in the cluttered back room of Mr. Sokolov's variety store, eating donuts out of the box and kicking back, as they do every Sunday morning.

title: Body Found in Swiss Chalet Identified as No. 2 Cult Leader
description: The mystery surrounding the macabre deaths of 48 cult members in Switzerland deepened today with the assertion that a presumed ringleader of the Order of the Solar Temple, for whom a murder warrant had been issued, had been identified among the dead.

title: Commerce Bancorp Inc.(COBA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Shortage Of Oil Seen If Gulf Erupts
description: Should the suddenly tense Persian Gulf erupt into fighting, energy analysts say they do not expect any shortages of oil but do think prices will rise, perhaps sharply.

title: Unbeaten and Undeniably on Top of Their Game
description: The San Diego Chargers are not only the National Football League's lone unbeaten team, but if they continue to play this way, the string may last. It may linger.

title: British Lens Distorts the Irish Political Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys Romp and Roar at Expense of Ryan and Cards
description: Certainly it is too early to call Buddy Ryan a failure in his latest fling with head coaching, this time with the Arizona Cardinals.

title: Speaker of the House Has a New Ring to It; Town Meeting Puts Call-Ins on Cable
description: Cindy Mooney just wanted to have a private word with her elected officials when she called Town Hall here the other night. Instead, people all over town wound up hearing what she had to say.

title: Montserrat Caballe Recital
description: Montserrat Caballe is to celebrate the 30th anniversary of her American debut with a recital at Carnegie Hall on Nov. 22 at 8 P.M. She is to sing works by Haydn, Scarlatti, Paisiello, Turina, Rodrigo, Obradors and others, accompanied by Manuel Burgueras. Tickets, at $10 to $50, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, (212) 247-7800.

title: Patents; Fees Rise at the Patent Office, Stirring Complaints That Inventors are Subsidizing the Federal Budget
description: BUDGET deficits plague the Patent and Trademark Office no less than most Government agencies. So the office has raised its patent application fees. As of Oct. 1, the basic filing fee for a large company increased to $730 from $710. A small company or individual will now pay $365 instead of $355.

title: The Hazy Gubernatorial Race
description: With less than a month to go before the election, the fierce race between Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York and his Republican rival, State Senator George Pataki, is caught up in a battle over dueling tax-cut plans, and the prevalent anti-incumbent mood, which registers in the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll as a strong A.B.C. factor: anyone but Cuomo.

title: Apple and I.B.M. Are Seen Close to PC Accord
description: Executives of Apple Computer and I.B.M. are close to agreeing on a common standard that would make the computers each company produces compatible with one another, industry executives familiar with the discussions said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID ZUCKER, executive producer of the "Naked Gun" and "Airplane" movies, and MARSHALL HERSKOVITZ, executive producer of "thirtysomething" and "My So Called Life," have teamed up to write, produce and direct a film for TreePeople, a Los Angeles-based environmental education and training organization, to celebrate its 21st anniversary.

title: Pataki on the Record: Excerpts From a Talk On Campaign Issues
description: State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor of New York, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times for two hours on Friday to discuss issues in the gubernatorial race and his goals if elected. Here are excerpts from the session. FISCAL MATTERS Taxing and Spending [ Senator Pataki was asked how he will be able to reconcile his campaign promises to cut taxes and control spending while also increasing aid to education and improving other state services. ]

title: POP
description: Of Hope Rising, Falling Or Just Surviving Bottom Line

title: AT LEAST 36,000 U.S. TROOPS GOING TO GULF IN RESPONSE TO CONTINUED IRAQI BUILDUP
description: The Clinton Administration announced tonight that it is sending at least 36,000 troops and some of its most potent warplanes to the Persian Gulf to counter a large and continuing buildup of Iraqi troops near the Kuwaiti border.

title: As Going Gets Tough, Kuwaitis Go Out to Eat
description: With thousands of Iraqi troops just north of the border, Kuwaiti reservists being mobilized and American soldiers on the way, many Kuwaitis are responding to the pressure by turning to one of the most beloved activities in the emirate -- eating.

title: A Lone Doctor Adapts Drugs For Abortions
description: The so-called abortion pill from France, RU-486, is still illegal in this country, but an alternative drug treatment has become available for $500 in New York. Richard Haus knecht, a gynecologist and longtime abortion-rights crusader, says he has used two drugs already on the market -- but approved for other purposes -- to perform more than 100 abortions without surgery.

title: TRANSACTIONS: WEEKEND
description: East Coast Hockey League ERIE PANTHERS -- Acquired Brad Harrison, forward, from Huntington for future considerations.

title: DANCE
description: A Swiss Troupe Emulates Medieval Fear of an Eclipse St. Mark's Church

title: Sungai Penchala Journal; A Malay Plot? Or Just a Well-Meaning Commune?
description: This, the Malaysian Government insists, is the lair of the devil.

title: POP
description: A Voice From Folk, An Outlook From Today Mercury Lounge

title: Treasury Will Auction Bills
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to bills, beginning with the regular weekly auction tomorrow of three- and six-month bills. On Thursday, the Treasury will auction a 52-week treasury bill.

title: Kuwaiti Troops Vow To Fight This Time
description: Kuwaiti troops deployed along the border with Iraq insisted today that they would not flee southward to Saudi Arabia, as many did in 1990, if Iraqi forces invaded again.

title: Iraq's Attempt to Have Sanctions Lifted Quickly May Have Backfired
description: By his show of force near the border with Kuwait, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq may have harmed his chances of having economic sanctions lifted early.

title: CBS Shares Rise Sharply
description: Shares of CBS Inc. rose $9 yesterday, to $336.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after it was reported that the company's chairman and chief executive, Laurence A. Tisch, was courting Barry Diller, the head of QVC Inc., to join CBS as chief executive. The report appeared yesterday in USA Today.

title: For the U.S., Not to Worry
description: None of the tainted paprika reported in Hungary has been exported to the United States, according to Hungarian officials and United States spice importers.

title: Fed's Sense of Timing; Officials See Another Rate Rise Coming, But Will It Be Now or Later in the Year?
description: Top Federal Reserve officials say the American economy is growing briskly, making further increases in short-term interest rates almost inevitable in the coming months to try to prevent the economy from overheating and feeding inflation.

title: Two Posing as Police Officers Rob a Park Avenue Penthouse
description: When two men wearing jackets emblazoned with the word "Police" presented themselves and their gold shields at 6 A.M. yesterday at the entrance of a Park Avenue luxury apartment house, the doorman whisked them up to the penthouse, the police said.

title: Dorsey Trailers Inc.(DSYT,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: All net income and share earnings are on a pro-forma basis that includes a provision for income taxes only during the period when the company was an S corporation.For comparative purposes with a normal tax provision recorded in all periods, net income in the latest quarter would have been 28 cents a share, compared with 14 cents in year-ago period; net income in the latest 9 months would have been 88 cents a share, against 32 cents a share in the period a year earlier.Prior to July 28, 1994, Dorsey was an S Corporation and therefore not subject to income tax. After July 27, 1994, the income tax provided on Dorsey's C Corporation earnings was offset by a required adjustment to its deferred tax valuation reserve. This adjustment increased net income by $ 566,000 in the third quarter of 1994.Sales are net sales.

title: Foreign Capitalists Brush Risks Aside To Invest in Russia
description: The ruble is crashing amid mounting fears of renewed inflation, and the fledgling stock market is still smarting from its first big downturn. Bankers and entrepreneurs are being gunned down in the streets. There is little financial regulation and considerable fraud.

title: Dollar Slips a Bit as Threat Of Persian Gulf War Fades
description: The dollar slipped against the Japanese yen and other leading currencies yesterday after Iraq said it had ordered its troops to withdraw from the Kuwaiti border.

title: Lufthansa in Thai Air Pact
description: The German airline Lufthansa signed an agreement today with Thai Airways International to expand Lufthansa's Asian passenger and cargo operations.

title: For Haytaian, the Pace Of Running Is Frenetic
description: Watching Chuck Haytaian's race to become the first Republican to serve as a United States Senator from New Jersey in a generation, it is easy to recall that the word "campaign" originated with armies on the march.

title: A New Weapon Is Added To Battle Gum and Graffiti
description: But for a single consonant, this might be big news: a gum-control plan will go into effect in midtown Manhattan today.

title: Vikings Stifle Hampton
description: The Giants needed an effective Rodney Hampton tonight to revitalize their ground game and to take some pressure off young quarterback Dave Brown.

title: Broad Pulse of de Kooning in Top Form
description: Along with Jackson Pollock, Willem de Kooning is the American abstract gestural painter of the postwar years to be reckoned with. A full-dress overview of his work is more than just a good idea; it is inevitable. For all its strengths, "Willem de Kooning: Paintings," which opens today at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through Jan. 8), is not that show, but it comes close.

title: Gators' Spurrier Grumbles, But Dean Is Still Winning
description: When a pass by Terry Dean was intercepted late in the second quarter Saturday against Louisiana State, Florida Coach Steve Spurrier ripped off his sun visor and threw it.

title: Catching Heck Over a No-Curse Rule
description: WHAT started Raritan officials thinking about cursing was Main Street. Pretty little Main Street. Nine blocks, two lights. Many whiskey-barrel planters.

title: Russia Seeks Solution For Nazi Art Loot
description: To the Editor:

title: North Draws Fire for Comments on Clinton Military Policy
description: Oliver L. North's relatively smooth-running Senate campaign has tripped over his suggestion that the United States could not stop an attack on Kuwait by Saddam Hussein and that President Clinton was to blame for a lack of military preparedness.

title: U.S. Investigating No-Haggle Car Pricing
description: As part of a wider antitrust investigation of auto pricing, the Justice Department is looking into the increasingly popular practice of no-haggle selling by car dealers, according to dealers and others who have been questioned in the inquiry.

title: COLLEGE SOCCER REPORT
description: Alabama-Birmingham

title: When a Repertorial Show Stays True to the Repertory
description: The performance that the Smithsonian Jazz Masterworks Orchestra gave on Friday night at Miller Theater would have seemed ideal 10 years ago: precise, intelligent and straightforward. Led by Gunther Schuller, the band made its way through the works of Duke Ellington, Count Basie, Glenn Miller, Artie Shaw, Benny Goodman, Fletcher Henderson and more, in an overview of orchestral works dating roughly through the late 1940's. Mr. Schuller is thoughtful, and his presentations manage an instructional blend of obvious material and pieces that are less known.

title: MAGMA POWER BOARD REJECTS CALIFORNIA ENERGY'S OFFER
description: The board of the Magma Power Company said yesterday that it had rejected the California Energy Company's $840 million tender offer to buy 51 percent of its geothermal power competitor's common stock, saying it is an "opportunistic attempt" to acquire Magma at an inadequate price. California Energy, based in Omaha, made an offer on Sept. 19 to acquire the company. The tender offer began Oct. 6 after the two companies were unable to come to terms. Stockholders have been offered $35 a share, composed of a combination of $25 in cash and $10 of California Energy stock, with the deal open through Nov. 3. A California Energy spokesman said yesterday that the company had no comment.

title: Apple Stock Continues Sharp Rise
description: Shares in Apple Computer Inc. continued their sharp rise today, in reaction to reports that Apple and I.B.M. were making progress toward agreeing on a common standard that would make each company's computers compatible with the other's.

title: Race for Governor: Cuomo Goes After Pataki's Tax Plan
description: CANDIDATE Mario M. Cuomo PRODUCER The Garth Group, New York City VISUAL This 30-second ad opens with letters on a black background reading, "George Pataki says he'll raise taxes. Don't believe it." The rest of the ad is devoted to three newspaper headlines about Mr. Pataki's personal finances.

title: Ernst & Young Makes Deep Cut in Legal Staff
description: Ernst & Young, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, said yesterday that it had dismissed about 240 people involved with its legal work, including 37 of its 65 lawyers. The firm also disclosed that it had replaced its general counsel, Carl D. Liggio, on Oct. 1.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Pennsylvania campaign for governor referred incorrectly in some copies to the charges against a convict whose pardon was recommended by the Democratic candidate, Lieut. Gov. Mark S. Singel. The convict, Reginald McFadden, is charged in New York with rape, robbery and kidnapping in one case and is a suspect, not a defendant, in a homicide case. In some editions the article also referred incorrectly to Willie Horton, the criminal who was the focus of television commercials in the 1988 Presidential campaign. When released on furlough, he was a convicted killer, not a convicted rapist.

title: A Rara Avis Record Label Of Americana
description: Forty years ago Composers Recordings Inc. became a company that said yes when commercial record companies said no. Financed by gifts, endowments and grants, not to mention a few record sales, C.R.I. has released 500 full-length recordings incorporating more than 1,000 pieces, most by 20th-century Americans.

title: DELL CUTS PRICES OF SOME PENTIUM-POWERED COMPUTERS
description: Seeking to entice consumers to leapfrog to the most powerful Intel Corporation microprocessors, the Dell Computer Corporation cut prices on two of its Pentium-powered computers by $200. Dell, a personal computer maker based in Austin, Tex., also introduced low-price Pentium models to its Optiplex line aimed at corporate users, which previously had PC's powered only by Intel's 80486 chip. With the price cuts, Dell's least expensive Pentium model, the Dell Dimension XPS60, will start at $1,899, with 528-megabyte hard drive and 15-inch monitor. Dell also added a Pentium-powered Optiplex unit with a list price of $1,970, which it said was the first corporate Pentium model for less than $2,000.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY EIGHT YOUTHS WOUNDED AT RAP CLUB

title: Aristide Is Now Facing Daunting Job of Restoration
description: As the military rulers in Haiti stepped down, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide spent today trying to decide precisely how he will run the country, whom to name as prime minister and who among a jostling crowd of American politicians will be on the airplane that takes him home.

title: A Modest Eastern Europe Attracts Beauty Stores
description: The sparkling brass-rimmed counters, the glistening bottles and the efficient sales clerks in crisp navy suits at the new Estee Lauder store here are a shock to many shoppers in Eastern Europe. Add a play corner with toys for children while mother spends and a brightly lighted seminar room for beauty consultations and customers could be forgiven for thinking they were in an affluent Western city.

title: Segregating Student Troublemakers
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon Cortines proposes to segregate New York City students who bring guns and other weapons to school in special disciplinary academies. The history of such separate schools has been mixed, but Mr. Cortines also suggests reasonable safeguards to prevent them from becoming mere dumping grounds. The main question is whether City Hall and the Board of Education can find the money.

title: 800-SOFTWARE TO BE PURCHASED BY CORPORATE SOFTWARE
description: Corporate Software Inc., a $384 million reseller of personal computer software and services to large corporate customers, has agreed to acquire 800-Software Inc. of Richmond, Calif., a subsidiary of the Digital Equipment Corporation. 800-Software had revenues of $141 million for the fiscal year that ended on March 31, 1994. The company, which specializes in PC software and peripheral sales to government agencies, was acquired by Digital in 1992. A Digital spokesman said yesterday that the sale was part of Digital's downsizing program. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. A spokesman for Corporate Software, which was taken private in March, said that after the acquisition Corporate Software would be the largest reseller of PC software to corporate clients.

title: A Woman's Ordeal of Rape, and Treatment
description: The woman who was raped early Sunday on an abandoned pier in Brooklyn described a night of horror that began when she and a male friend stopped to view the Manhattan skyline and continued with what she described yesterday as a humiliating ordeal at Woodhull Medical Center.

title: Prospects for Kohl Uncertain as Vote In Germany Nears
description: With less than a week to go before the German national elections on Sunday, Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who engineered German reunification in 1990 and did much to shape Europe's response, may well be returned to office for another term. The question for the 60 million German voters is whether he will serve as a changed or greatly chastened ruler.

title: Cutting Through Hype on Monitors
description: "MONITORS are not perfect," said Ray Soneira, who knows whereof he speaks. His company, Sonera Technologies of Rumson, N.J., sells a useful program called Displaymate for Windows ($79; 800-932-6323) that can help uncover and correct imperfections in computer displays. The program includes enough concentric circles, blinking lines and unusual color patterns to suggest that cable TV might want to consider a Test Pattern Channel.

title: No Headline
description: "I will not be with you." -- LIEUT. GEN. RAOUL CEDRAS, Haiti's military leader. [ A1:3. ]

title: Reviews/Fashion; In London, Designers Are All Grown-Ups
description: The way to look like a seasoned fashion professional in London is usually to mutter, "Forget what's on the runways," and head to Camden Market to see what vintage looks and handmade clothing people are pulling together.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMERICAN MEDICAL ELECTRONICS INC., Dallas, a manufacturer and distributor of advanced products for bone healing, appointed John F. Clifford president and chief executive.

title: First Federal Savings Bank of Puerto Rico (FBP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 429,000, or 4 cents a share.c-After a nonrecurring and nonoperational positive adjustment of $ 6,840,000, or 62 cents a share, on the implementation of a new accounting pronouncement related to deferred tax assets, FASB 109.

title: Accounts
description: * Dodger Productions and Kardana Productions, both of New York, to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, New York, to handle advertising for the coming Broadway production of "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." Billings were not disclosed. * Discover magazine, New York, to Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica, Calif., to handle its trade advertising account, previously at Ziff Marketing, New York, now defunct. Billings were not disclosed.

title: 2 Americans Share Nobel For Cell Signal Finding
description: TWO Americans, Dr. Alfred G. Gilman and Dr. Martin Rodbell, won the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine yesterday for discovering natural substances known as G-proteins and how they help cells convert signals from the environment and within the body into cellular chain reactions that control fundamental life processes.

title: James Monks, 81, Actor and Model
description: James Monks, an actor who began his career on Broadway in the 1930's and later worked in films and modeling, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81.

title: Burning Trash for Energy: Is It an Endangered Industry?
description: With its towering smokestacks, hungry furnaces and transmission lines vibrating with thousands of kilowatts of electricity, this city's immense garbage incinerator was once considered a safe and economical means for disposing of thousands of tons of trash.

title: Legal Aid Lawyers Weren't Striking Against New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNINGS PREDICTION HURTS CENTRAL GARDEN AND PET
description: The shares of the Central Garden and Pet Company closed down 26 percent after it said it expected a greater loss for the third quarter than it recorded for the corresponding period last year. Shares fell $1.50, to $4.25, in Nasdaq trading. The company, a national distributor of lawn, garden, pet and pool supplies, said it expected a loss of between 35 cents a share and 45 cents a share, compared with a loss of 8 cents a share in the third quarter last year. Central Garden also said it had retained the investment banking firm of Wasserstein Perella & Company to help it maximize value.

title: At Last, Life Care Comes to New York
description: In 1989, Jim and Ceil Spero, both retired and in their early 60's, were invited to a meeting about a new idea for New York State: a retirement community that comes with a guarantee of health care at a predictable cost.

title: Peak Performance: Why Records Fall
description: THE old joke -- How do you get to Carnegie Hall? Practice, practice, practice -- is getting a scientific spin. Researchers are finding an unexpected potency from deliberate practice in world-class competitions of all kinds, including chess matches, musical recitals and sporting events.

title: Even Shorn of Horns, Rhinos of Zimbabwe Face Poacher Calamity
description: THE black rhinoceros wore a radio collar and her horns had been shorn with a chain saw to make her less valuable.

title: MILITARY LEADER IN HAITI RESIGNS, VOWING TO LEAVE
description: With a protective cordon of American soldiers around him and a crowd of jubilant Haitians drowning out his words with jeers and insults, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras resigned as commander in chief of the Haitian armed forces today, pledging to leave the country in the next few days.

title: By Design; Drape It, Tie It or Let It Float
description: On the runways of Milan and Paris, models wear light-colored spring clothes with bare legs or pale fishnet hosiery and stiletto heels. In the audience the fashion professionals are dressed as usual in somber black down to their hosiery and shoes. It's sensible low-heeled shoes or knee-high boots for all but the most prestigious magazine editors, who teeter to their chauffeur-driven cars in high-heeled Gucci loafers or spindly Manolo Blahniks.

title: To the Brink in the Gulf, Again
description: Until this weekend, Saddam Hussein seemed on the verge of persuading key countries like Egypt, France and Russia that the United Nations' economic sanctions against Iraq should be relaxed. He was in increasing compliance with the Security Council resolutions passed during the Persian Gulf war. Why, then, would he provoke worldwide condemnation by massing troops near the Kuwaiti border -- only to promise to withdraw them?

title: Iraq's Reckless Ploy
description: Five days of Iraqi deployments and U.S. counterdeployments around Kuwait's northern border have left Bill Clinton looking like a born-again military strategist and Saddam Hussein like a dangerous and clumsy bully. Iraq's announcement yesterday that it was withdrawing troops from the border region vindicates Mr. Clinton's strategy of quick and massive military deterrence of any Iraqi plans for renewed aggression.

title: Garden State Warriors? Nets' Offense Looks Like It
description: Butch Beard trumpeted his offense in his first few months as the Nets coach, promising to push the ball, rather than walk it up the floor. He failed to mention anything about the 6-foot-10-inch Derrick Coleman playing point guard, though.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Masculine, but Oh So Softly
description: There is always a certain defiance to a woman wearing a man's suit. But Rei Kawakubo in her Comme des Garcons collection, the last show of the opening day of the Paris spring-summer season, sweetened that defiance by mingling elements of feminine dress with the manliest tailoring. "Spiritually, there are no more differences between men and women," she said after the show. "What is important is being human."

title: Q&A
description: Buried Nuts

title: CHRONICLE
description: All those thousands of teacups, and not a drop to drink. Since 1759, when the Wedgwood producers of fine china went into business in England, tea drinkers have had to steep other folks' leaves in their Wedgwood.

title: Arab States Withholding Their Support For Baghdad
description: Under pressure from the Clinton Administration, Jordan and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which were among the strongest backers of Iraq in the Persian Gulf war, are withholding support for Iraq in its movement of troops toward Kuwait.

title: Coram to Settle T   Lawsuit
description: The Coram Health Care Corporation has agreed to pay $25 million and issue 2.5 million warrants to settle a shareholder class-action securities fraud suit filed against its subsidiary T Medical Inc.

title: A Mattel Account Is in Review
description: Mattel Inc. said yesterday that it was searching for an agency to handle advertising for the Cabbage Patch Kids line of dolls. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $20 million.

title: THREATS IN THE GULF: KUWAIT -- Keeping the Iraqis Back; Pentagon's Long-Term Problem Is to Avoid Recurring Need to Send Troops to the Gulf
description: Even if Iraq pulls its forces back from the Kuwait border, as its diplomats promised today, Baghdad's troop movements have created a new and vexing problem for the Pentagon: how to insure that Iraqi troops not only withdraw from the border but also keep a respectful distance.

title: Oregon, Foiling Forecasters, Thrives as It Protects Owls
description: By now, the timber communities of Oregon were supposed to be ghost towns. There was going to an epidemic of foreclosures, a recession so crippling it would mean "we'll be up to our neck in owls, and every millworker will be out of a job," as President George Bush predicted two years ago while campaigning in the Northwest.

title: Out of the Closet and Onto the Stage
description: OUT THERE II Comedy Central, tonight at 9

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League TEXAS RANGERS -- Named Doug Melvin general manager. National League CHICAGO CUBS -- Named Ed Lynch general manager. Sent Todd Haney, infielder, Mike Maksudian, catcher-infielder, and Rafael Novoa, pitcher, outright to Iowa of the American Association. Activated Mike Morgan, pitcher, and Kevin Roberson, outfielder, from the 15-day disabled list and Jose Guzman and Anthony Young, pitchers, from the 60-day disabled list.

title: Motorola Net Climbs 49.6%
description: Motorola Inc. reported today a 49.6 percent jump in its third-quarter earnings, a better-than-expected gain paced by an increase in sales of its semiconductor and wireless communications equipment.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Congressional passage of a $60 billion education bill referred imprecisely to the position of Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico. He supported the bill.

title: A General Departs, to the Rich and Bitter Sarcasm of the People He Ruled
description: The honor guard snapped to attention, more or less -- swords brandished, red-and-blue banners flapping, rifles carefully checked by American troops to be sure they were empty -- as the Commander in Chief of the Haitian Army, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, stepped forward to make his farewell address.

title: Upjohn China Venture
description: The Upjohn Company said today that it had begun construction on a $30 million joint venture pharmaceutical factory in Suzhou, China. The company announced the project in July. Upjohn, which sells but does not yet make drugs in China, will own 75 percent of the venture. Suzhou Pharmaceutical Factory No. 4, which has more than 1,000 employees, holds the remaining stake. The plant is to begin making Upjohn products in 1996 with 150 employees, the company said.

title: Lynch 'Flattered' to Become Cubs' G.M.
description: When Ed Lynch left New York for Chicago in 1986, he was admittedly heartbroken. The Mets were a team on the rise, a team just a few months away from winning the World Series, and Lynch, a pitcher, was headed to the struggling Chicago Cubs.

title: Big Play by Mitchell May Remake His Image
description: It was only a 1-yard pass, but maybe, just maybe, it meant a turning point in the fortunes of the Jets and their flighty tight end, Johnny Mitchell.

title: Marcus Singer, 80, Professor Accused By 50's House Panel
description: Dr. Marcus Singer, a longtime professor of anatomy and zoology who was Henry Willson Payne Professor of Anatomy at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland, died on Saturday at his home in Cleveland Heights, Ohio. He was 80.

title: Bill on Holocaust Lawsuits Dies in Congress
description: A bill that would have allowed a New Jersey man who survived the Holocaust to sue the German Government for reparations failed to pass the United States Senate before Congress adjourned last weekend.

title: Stainless Steel Widens Appeal
description: The rusted tailpipe may be going the way of the side-vent window. In recent years, auto makers have increasingly been equipping cars and light trucks with rust-resistant exhaust systems made of stainless steel. By the 1996 model year, virtually every car produced in North America is expected to have a stainless steel exhaust system.

title: Rivers Is Moving Well On Road to the Lineup
description: Through four days of practice, Doc Rivers' left knee has not betrayed him.

title: The Video Poker Truck Stop: Ante Up and Fill 'er, Too
description: There are crickets in a hutch, fish guts in the trash, some dusty diesel pumps out front and in a back room, blinking giddily in the dark, rows of what everybody knows is the trucker's best friend: the video poker machine.

title: Premier Bancorp Inc.(PRBC,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an accounting gain of $ 44,322,000, or $ 1.38 a share, from the adoption of SFAS 109.Premier Bancorp said that 1994's third quarter included securities losses of $ 188,000, compared with securities gains of $ 777,000, in year-ago period.Net interest income in the latest third quarter was $ 55,890,000, up from $ 50,659,000 in year-ago period, and net interest income in the latest 9 months was $ 160,506,000, compared with $ 148,414,000 in 1993 period.Results for the periods prior to June 1994 have been restated to include the acquisition of Heritage Financial Corp. in June 1994, which was accounted for as a pooling of interests.The company said the increase in net interest income coupled with a decrease in noninterest expense were the primary factors contributing to the increase in earnings for 1994 third quarter.Premier attributed the improvement in noninterest expense for the latest third quarter primarily to gains on sales of repossessed real estate of $ 2.7 million in the latest third quarter, compared with a charge of $ 5.8 million in year-ago period, related to the business process reengineering.

title: On My Mind; Drowning In Oil
description: The heart of the matter is not what Saddam Hussein will do or can do to harass his enemies in the West and Mideast. It is what they can do and will do to destroy him at last.

title: Cable Group Seeks Deal With Sprint
description: A group of the nation's biggest cable television companies is talking with the Sprint Corporation, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier, about collaborating on a nationwide wireless telephone network.

title: RESULTSPLUS
description: TENNIS Martinez Takes Measure of Maleeva

title: Among Haitians in Exile, A Mood of Unbridled Joy
description: In his art gallery in Cambria Heights, Queens, Guy Fleury was recalling the celebration in the Haitian-American community that greeted the news yesterday morning that Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras was resigning after three years as Haiti's military ruler and leaving the country.

title: Tears and Protest at Mock Slave Sale
description: As white actors in tricorn hats and ruffled waistcoats recreated the colonial custom of auctioning black humans here today, two modern-day blacks sat in silent protest on the steps of a restored tavern.

title: Private Lives of Franklin and Eleanor
description: Opening a new season of "The American Experience," "F. D. R." turns out to be a personal sort of history. The focus is less on President Roosevelt's public accomplishments, though they are duly noted, than on his triumph over polio and, especially, his complicated relationship with his wife, Eleanor.

title: CLINTON SENDS MORE PLANES TO MIDEAST, SAYING HE SEES NO SIGN OF IRAQI PULLBACK
description: Iraq announced today that it was withdrawing its troops from provocative positions along the Kuwaiti border, but President Clinton told Americans tonight that the United States had seen no evidence so far of a withdrawal and was adding new firepower to its forces in the Persian Gulf region.

title: Unsentimental Education: Brown Fails, Giants Fall
description: The nation watched as Lawrence Taylor stood at midfield, looked up at a packed Giants Stadium, and said goodbye. His No. 56 jersey was retired in a classy and emotional ceremony. Then, after that, quarterback Dave Brown showed the nation that as good as he is, as good as he can be, his education is not complete. Not by a long shot.

title: Element Is Stripped of Its Namesake
description: FOR the last seven months, Element 106, an artificial element first created in 1974 by the Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., has been provisionally named seaborgium in honor of Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg, the laboratory's director at large, a Nobel laureate and the codiscoverer of plutonium. But just as seaborgium is finding its way into textbooks and scientific papers, an international committee has created an uproar by dropping Dr. Seaborg's name from the official roster of chemical elements.

title: Patterns
description: Packaging Street Fashion

title: Prodigy's Dream Has a Price
description: Jack and Pat Lipinski never intended to become the parents of a figure-skating phenom. When their only child, Tara, was born 12 years ago, Jack seemed relieved to have a daughter. "We don't have to worry if she's the best athlete in school," he told his wife. Which was fine with Pat, who knew or cared little about sports, especially skating, where she couldn't distinguish a double axel from a double play.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; To build Minolta's visibility and market share, a new campaign lets slip a watchdog of copiers.
description: GEORGE LOIS was barking.

title: Southern National Corp.(SNB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After payment of preferred dividends of $ 1,299,000, the company's net applicable to common shareholders was $ 26,714,000 in the quarter, and after payment of preferred dividends of $ 3,897,000, net applicable to common shareholders was $ 77,047,000, in the 9 months.c-After payment of preferred dividends of $ 1,299,000, the company's net applicable to common shareholders was $ 20,430,000, in the quarter, and after payment of preferred dividends of $ 3,897,000, net applicable to common shareholders was $ 38,483,000, in the 9 months.The year-ago 9 months was also after a charge of $ 27,217,000, or 65 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago periods were restated to reflect 1994 acquisitions.

title: Gore Stands In At Fund-Raiser
description: Vice President Al Gore was a last-minute stand-in tonight for President Clinton at a Democratic Party fund-raiser here.

title: Eight Youths Are Wounded In Shootings at Dance Club
description: The spray of gunfire in a Manhattan rap club early yesterday began with a shoving match and ended with a stampede of 300 youngsters down East 29th Street. When it was over, eight youths -- including at least one New York University student and one 15-year-old -- were left wounded on the dance floor at the club, the Melting Pot.

title: Executive Shifts At Three Agencies
description: Three agencies have announced changes involving creative executives.

title: 'Oscars' Made Of Tin
description: No one would dispute that children thrive when they feel respected, important and cared for by others, or that they falter when they lack the pride and self-confidence that comes with such approval and support.

title: Cult Leader In Swiss Case Still Missing
description: The Swiss police confirmed tonight that the financial mastermind of the Order of the Solar Temple was among 48 members of the religious sect found dead here last week, but the whereabouts of the group's charismatic spiritual leader remained a mystery.

title: Voter Registration
description: Today is the last day to register to vote in New Jersey. Municipal buildings and town halls will be open until 9 P.M. Mail registrations must also be postmarked by today. Information is available by telephone from the local town or city hall.

title: Bandag Inc.(BDG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Village Mourns Marchers Mowed Down by Van
description: This roadside hamlet of mud and concrete huts was in shock today, as relatives and friends grieved for those killed and injured on Sunday when a van of army sympathizers drove through a crowd of pro-democracy demonstrators.

title: In March of the Politicians, Pride and Proximity Count
description: New York's politicians honored Columbus with an election-year armada up Fifth Avenue yesterday, Republicans and Democrats tempest-tossed together in a journey in which position can be all.

title: Microchip Technology Inc.(MCHP,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Virginia E. Montes, 50, Women's Rights Advocate
description: Virginia E. Montes, a former national secretary and lobbyist for the National Organization for Women, died Thursday at her home in Atlanta. She was 50.

title: N.H.L. Players Present New Plan to Owners
description: National Hockey League players proposed a 7 percent solution to their dispute with owners today, but the proposal most likely won't be enough to make the owners 100 percent certain they want to open the season on Saturday.

title: Big Acquisition by Panhandle Eastern
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation agreed today to buy the Associated Natural Gas Corporation for $830 million in stock and assumed debt, in a deal that would create one of the nation's largest diversified natural gas companies.

title: Prairie Ducks Return in Record Numbers
description: FEW birds are more avidly sought after by nature fanciers and hunters alike than the ducks, and a lot of people have been distressed to watch the sharp decline of wild duck populations over the last decade.

title: COMPANY NEWS: Enhancing by Subtracting; Tobacco Giant Promises A Less Smelly Smoke
description: The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, which introduced a "smokeless" cigarette a few years ago that failed to catch on with smokers, says it will sell a cigarette with smoke that leaves less of a lingering stale smell.

title: Daniel J. Melia, 75, Retired Pediatrician And Police Official
description: Dr. Daniel John Melia, a retired pediatrician and longtime Police Commissioner of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., died on Sunday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 and had lived in Irvington, N.Y., since 1990.

title: School Opens in Haiti, But Who Is in Charge?
description: Diderot Belizaire, the director general of Haiti's Department of Education, spends his days in a locked air-conditioned office. Every time he has a visitor, his assistant must jump from her desk to fish out a ring of keys. Inside, the director general sits before a wall-size map, suave and neat in a suit and tie, conveying a sense of purpose.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about overcrowding in New York City kindergartens referred incorrectly in some copies to the school shown, where kindergarten classes were held in the cafeteria. It was Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, not Public School 16.

title: Abbott Laboratories (ABT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results included net losses on foreign exchange of $ 1,927,000 and $ 29,461,000 for the latest third quarter and 9 months, respectively, and net losses on foreign exchange in the year-ago periods of $ 11,836,000 in the quarter and $ 30,994,000 for the 9 months.Sales represented total worldwide sales.

title: Most Markets Open in U.S.
description: Most financial markets in the United States were open yesterday, although the cash market for Treasury securities was closed in observance of Columbus Day. All the United States commodities markets were also open and futures on Treasury securities were traded.

title: The 13-Year Cleaning Job; After $53 Million, a $17 Million State Building Finally Is Declared Safe From Toxins
description: In the early morning of Feb. 5, 1981, a 30-minute basement electrical fire filled the state office building in Binghamton, N.Y., with a thick cloud of toxic smoke, spreading PCB's and dioxins over everything, from the lottery tickets in the lobby to the law books on the 18th floor.

title: Market Place; Think air bags, not credit reporting, when evaluating TRW.
description: MENTION the name TRW and for many people what comes to mind is a credit bureau that provides consumer reports to lenders and merchants.

title: The City's New Prosecutors Test Their Legal Legs
description: It was a normal day in Judge Karen B. Yellen's eighth-floor courtroom in Brooklyn Criminal Court. The cases were being called at a rate of one every two or three minutes. Most were swiftly settled with plea deals.

title: Bellcore Denies Report on Sale
description: Bell Communications Research, the research and engineering consortium of the regional Bell operating companies, said today that it had made no plans to sell the research division.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Chess
description: Everything went wrong for Michael Adams last month in Linares, Spain, during his semifinal match for the Professional Chess Association's world championship. The 22-year-old English grandmaster was caught unacquainted in one game with an opening system that anyone playing on his high level should know. In another game, he came prepared with a surprise improvement, but half way through the series of critical moves, he discovered a critical flaw in his analysis. In still another game, he adopted a solid opening but was confronted with superior solidity and ground down.

title: Superior Industries Intl.(SUP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Budapest Journal; Crisis of Goulash Capitalism: Where's the Paprika?
description: The Hungarians, a nation of hearty eaters who lace their food with lashings of paprika, are facing serious withdrawal pangs.

title: Prices of Treasury Futures Rise
description: Prices of Treasury futures ended slightly higher yesterday, while the Treasury market was closed in observance of Columbus Day.

title: Smithsonian A-Bomb Display Distorts History
description: To the Editor:

title: Shirley Chernela; Temple Administrator, 73
description: Shirley Chernela, a former administrator of Temple Shaaray Tefila in Manhattan and the first woman to be president of the National Association of Temple Administrators, died Saturday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 73 and lived in Manhattan.

title: INSIDE
description: 2 Americans Share Nobel Prize in Medicine

title: The Japanese Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Could it be that ALAN M. DERSHOWITZ, a member of the O. J. Simpson defense team, doesn't have enough to do?

title: Stocks Rise in Light Trading; Dow Up 23.89
description: Stock prices rose sharply for the second straight day, led by technology and auto issues -- both of which were among last week's laggards.

title: Generals and Privates, the Marines Head Back to an Old Haunt
description: "Again! We're doing it again!" said Lieut. Gen. Anthony C. Zinni, clapping a marine on the back as his troops lined up in the baking sun here today for their desert boots, camouflage uniforms and field rations, preparing for the order to head for the Persian Gulf.

title: Race for Governor: Pataki Criticizes Cuomo's Tax Record
description: CANDIDATE George E. Pataki PRODUCER Russo, Marsh & Associates, Alexandria, Va., and Sacramento, Calif. VISUAL: The ad almost looks like a video game, with a photograph of Mario Cuomo on the top of the screen with the heading, "Mario Cuomo's record on taxes and fees." A seemingly endless list of taxes scrolls up from the bottom, then from the lower right-hand side with computer-drawn images of a phone, a dog, a tree and a car. The ad is 30 seconds long.

title: MYLAN LABS SHARES RISE ON PLANS TO SELL GENERIC CECLOR
description: The shares of Mylan Laboratories Inc. rose 8 percent yesterday after the company, a generic drug maker, said that it would sell a generic version of Ceclor for Eli Lilly & Company. Ceclor was Lilly's second-best-selling drug in 1993, with worldwide sales of about $910 million. The company's manufacturing patent on the antibiotic expires in December, paving the way for tough competition from generic drug makers. The agreement may hamper that competition while providing Mylan with a lucrative source of revenue, analysts said. Mylan shares rose $2.25, to $28.375, on volume of almost 1.6 million shares. Lilly's shares closed unchanged at $58.

title: Companies Say Drugs Slow M.S.
description: RESEARCHERS from two companies said yesterday that two new drugs seem to be effective in slowing the progression of multiple sclerosis, an incurable neurological disease.

title: The Personal Approach To Vietnam Revisited
description: The Vietnam War -- with its moral ambiguities, its surreal jungle conditions and the episodic quality of its fighting -- has tended to defy conventional narrative treatments. In "Dispatches," Michael Herr found a nervous, willfully subjective voice that captured the chaotic texture of that war, and in "Going After Cacciato," Tim O'Brien employed the devices of magical realism to convey its disorienting psychological effects.

title: Minnesota's Old Man Riddles a Corps of Kids
description: It is common knowledge that the Giants' most glaring weakness this season is their secondary. Tonight, the weakness showed more than ever.

title: Legal Aid Questions Contract's Termination
description: In what some consider an attempt to save face as well as to restore a few months to a defunct contract with the city, leaders of the Legal Aid Society have sent letters to two officials claiming that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani did not have a legal basis for terminating the society's contract to represent the indigent.

title: With Click, Animation For Young
description: ON the screen is a picturesque village, English perhaps. In the foreground, a monkey stands in the road leading into the village. A click of the mouse button and the monkey scampers down the road, up the side of a building and onto the roof, where it chatters.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 MORE U.S. FIREPOWER TO THE GULF Iraq said that it was pulling back troops from the Kuwaiti border, but President Clinton said the United States was dubious and that he was sending in more warplanes. A1

title: WESTERN COMPANY AND BJ SERVICES TO EXCHANGE DATA
description: The Western Company of North America said yesterday that it had signed confidentiality agreements to trade data with the BJ Services Company, though it continued to rebuff BJ's bid to buy the company for $18.50 a share. Western said the move was consistent with its agreement with BJ Services to continue talks about a possible merger of the two oil-service companies. The agreement forbids either party to solicit proxies until after Nov. 3, allowing the management of Western to work on a resolution to BJ Service's bid to buy it for $450 million. Western rejected that offer last month as inadequate. Price was not the only issue. It also said it preferred a tax-free pooling of interests over BJ Services' offer to pay with cash and stock.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BINDLEY WESTERN INDUSTRIES, Indianapolis, a wholesale distributor of drugs, and health and beauty aids, said it had completed the purchase of the assets of Kendall Drug Company, Shelby, N.C.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Think you have a gift for song writing? Never mind that, says GERALD MARKS, whose songs include "All of Me" and "Is It True What They Say About Dixie?" Success rests almost totally in the accidents of luck.

title: William W. Lapsley Dies at 84; Retired General Led Con Edison
description: William W. Lapsley, a retired major general in the Army Corps of Engineers and former president of the Consolidated Edison Company, died on Thursday at his home in San Antonio. He was 84.

title: Kuwait Crisis: Hussein Gambles to Keep Power
description: Saddam Hussein's latest confrontation with the United States illustrates both the success and the failure of Washington's handling of the Iraqi leader.

title: NATO Requests a Broader Right to Attack Targets in Bosnia
description: In a challenge to the United Nations, NATO has formally requested radical changes in its mandate in Bosnia, including the right to strike against numerous targets at once.

title: Cablevision's Dolan, One Savvy Visionary
description: A decade or so ago, before Chuck Dolan was worth $715 million, the chairman of Cablevision Systems wanted to buy Madison Square Garden when it was owned by Paramount Communications (formerly Gulf & Western). "They said if they were going to sell, it would be $300 million," he said.

title: Corrections
description: A notice in Business Day yesterday about the Columbus Day schedules for the financial and commodities markets referred incorrectly to the New York Cotton Exchange. It was open yesterday.

title: MacNeil to Retire From 'Newshour' In '95 After 20 Years
description: Robert MacNeil said yesterday that he would retire as a co-anchor of the "MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour" next October after 20 years with public television's nightly news program. The program, which is suffering budgetary constraints, is to close down its operation in New York and base itself in Washington.

title: New York City Is Vengeful in the Face of a 'Raid' by Connecticut
description: Just weeks after losing a spirited battle to keep Swiss Bank from leaving Manhattan, the Giuliani administration has taken out large display ads in Connecticut newspapers urging Connecticut residents to reject "this blatant and unneighborly raid."

title: RPM Inc.(RPOW,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: Year-ago first quarter was restated to reflect the Oct. 26, 1993, acquisition of Stonhard Inc.RPM said that its increased sales were split between core growth and sales associated with the June 28 acquisition of Rust-Oleum Corp.

title: At a Book Fair, Brazil Is the Theme. Who Cares?
description: The theme of this year's Frankfurt Book Fair was the literature of Brazil, but you wouldn't have known it to talk to any of the hundreds of American publishers, editors, rights directors and literary agents who have spent a week here, wheeling and dealing like mini-Wall Street sharks.

title: Data on Derivatives Offered
description: J. P. Morgan & Company, one of the biggest traders in the $14 trillion derivatives market, said yesterday that it would supply daily information on more than 300 derivatives and other securities to help corporations keep track of the value of their holdings of these complex instruments.

title: Transcript of Clinton's Address: No Evidence the Iraqis Have Pulled Back
description: Following is President Clinton's televised speech to the nation last night about United States actions in the Persian Gulf area and in Haiti, as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: A Shaken Jerusalem Tries to Get Back to Normal
description: Jerusalem, bruised and its wind knocked out, scrambled back to its feet today after its worst terrorist attack in years. But the city was still shaken by two Arabs who came from the Gaza Strip and sprayed automatic-rifle fire along a crowded street of pubs and cafes, killing 2 people and wounding 13 others before the assailants were shot to death.

title: Sports of The Times; L.T.'s Rush Helped Sack Phil Simms
description: BY the time the workout was over, a couple dozen kids were outside the practice field, in the shadow of Giants Stadium, waiting for the quarterback. Like a horde of sleepy buffalo, the other players trudged out the gate, past the kids, into the parking lot, toward the locker room.

title: History of a Song
description: To the Editor:

title: Ailing Spacecraft to Destroy Itself on Venus
description: AFTER orbiting Venus more than 15,000 times in the last four years, the ailing Magellan spacecraft is to receive its final radio command today, sending it into a suicidal descent into the planet's atmosphere for one last-gasp experiment that could improve the design and operation of future spacecraft.

title: Esiason's Contribution Surpasses His Statistics
description: Fans remember the fourth quarter, not statistics.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a self-defense class at the 92d Street Y in Manhattan misidentified the instructor shown. He was Abner Diaz, not Peter Ticali.

title: Critics Talk the Talk, but Bills Walk the Walk
description: Jim Kelly said he has been listening to doomsayers each week proclaiming that Buffalo, the four-time American Football Conference champion and four-time Super Bowl loser, had finally run out of steam.

title: BB&T Financial (BBTF,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
In Preliminary Work, New Test Detects Three Types of Cancer
description: A new test that can detect several kinds of cancerous human cells was reported yesterday by scientists from the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore. The scientists say they can quickly develop the test into a general method for screening healthy people for the incipient stages of most kinds of cancer.

title: Scott Paper Unit Draws $1.6 Billion
description: Sappi Ltd. of Johannesburg and two other investors agreed to buy America's largest maker of glossy paper from the Scott Paper Company for $1.6 billion, the companies said yesterday. Executives said it would be the biggest American investment by a South African company in more than 20 years.

title: General Cedras Departs
description: With the resignation of Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, the Clinton Administration has reason to hope that its ill-considered Haitian gamble has worked. After the earlier resignation of Brig. Gen. Philippe Biamby, and the flight of Col. Michel Francois to the Dominican Republic, General Cedras's departure has paved the way for the return of President Jean-Bertrand Aristide.

title: The Irishman as Barometer for Bigotry's Nuances
description: Daniel Magee's "Paddywack," the turbulent new Irish drama at the Long Wharf Theater here, puts two questions before an audience.

title: 'Me and You': No. 56 Bids His Fans Sweet and Fond Farewell
description: Wearing his blue "56" jersey, Lawrence Taylor looked up at 77,294 faces tonight in Giants Stadium.

title: A Prudent Agreement
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Faction Doesn't Get Fair Hearing
description: To the Editor:

title: Observer; The Butler, Maybe?
description: Many persons have begged me to reveal the secret of how to write a newspaper column, and I now do so gladly, for --

title: Grupo Televisa
description: The global depository receipts of the Mexican media giant Grupo Televisa S.A. fell sharply yesterday after Goldman, Sachs & Company lowered its earnings estimates by 26 percent for 1994 and 24 percent for 1995, saying the company could be hurt by weakness in the Mexican advertising market.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO. (IP,N)
description: The International Paper Company said yesterday that its third-quarter profit rose 47 percent on rising demand for its containerboard and packaging products.

title: Review/Fashion; Back to the Future: An Elegant Edge
description: If the retro clothes on the runways really are the future, designers are making a curious case for their own obsolescence. Today, though, three design houses -- Rifat Ozbek, Yohji Yamamoto and Mariot Chanet -- offered a stirring demonstration of fashion ideas.

title: Barton A. Cummings, 80, Leader Of Major Advertising Concerns
description: Barton A. Cummings, who headed one of the United States' largest agencies, Compton Advertising, before becoming chairman emeritus of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, died on Sunday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 80.

title: Bruce Quits as Arena Football Coach
description: EARLE BRUCE, the former head coach at Ohio State and Colorado State, resigned as coach of the Cleveland Thunderbolts team in the Arena Football League yesterday, saying he did not have enough time to attend to the team and meet other responsibilities.

title: Professor, Husband and Wimp
description: Even viewers who have never seen the classic 1951 film "The Browning Version," with Michael Redgrave as an emotionally chilly professor at a boys' school, will recognize the ghost of the past in the new film directed by Mike Figgis. Today's "Browning Version," with Albert Finney as the classics professor, has been updated but not substantially changed. It carries the unmistakable whiff of a musty tale dragged into the 90's, where it seems conspicuously out of place.

title: Another Bank Dividend
description: The Bank of New York Company raised its quarterly stock dividend by 16 percent yesterday, joining a wave of banks that have chosen to give more cash to shareholders this year. Bank of New York increased the dividend to 32 cents a share from 27.5 cents, its third increase since July 1993.

title: Now Let Jewish Women Seeking Divorce Find Religious Justice; State Unduly Interferes
description: To the Editor:

title: State Dept. Stops Free Speech at the Border
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Fashion; Chloe's Lacy Dream World
description: Karl Lagerfeld did it again. He brought the Paris fashion scene to brilliant life in the Chloe spring collection he showed on this morning.

title: Football Bedfellows: If Notre Dame Loses, NBC and ABC Do, Too
description: Each year, it seems, Notre Dame is at the center of televised college football. It is the best TV attraction, the only university with its own deal, for six home games on NBC. Whether the Fighting Irish's games are on ABC or NBC, the hope at the network end is that Lou Holtz's team will be ever in the hunt for a national championship. But last week, when Notre Dame was thrashed, 30-11, by Boston College on ABC, its title hopes were virtually squashed.

title: T.W.A. Seeks to Reduce Debt in Revamping
description: Trans World Airlines proposed a sweeping financial restructuring yesterday, the latest step in its continuing struggle to flout predictions of its demise.

title: 3 Economists Share a Prize for Insights Into How Rivalries Function; Reinhard Selten
description: Reinhard Selten says that he plays no sports, except perhaps hiking, "if one can say that is a sport."

title: Coffee, Tea Or Ouch?
description: THE conventional wisdom used to be that a steaming-hot cup of coffee was preferable to a tepid one.

title: Seeking a Way to Stop Hamburger Fatalities
description: Tonight's "Turning Point" retells the story of the appearance of E. coli bacteria in ground beef in California and Washington State in 1992 and '93. "Deadly Meat: When a Hamburger Can Kill" focuses on the families of four children who died and of others who became seriously ill, in most cases after eating undercooked hamburgers from Jack-in-the-Box fast-food outlets. In standard news magazine fashion, there are snapshots and home movies of the pretty children before they were stricken, followed by grim hospital scenes. The reporter, Meredith Vieira, goes on to accuse the Federal Department of Agriculture of not doing enough to protect consumers from contaminated meat.

title: Park Electrochemical Corp.(PKE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 28
Pine Chip Gets the Rail
description: Pine Chip, the world's fastest trotter, who will be making the final start of his career, drew the rail yesterday for the $300,000 Cadillac Breeders' Crown Open Trot at Freehold Raceway Saturday. He was installed as the 3-5 early favorite in the six-horse field.

title: Argonaut Group Inc.(AGII,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included investment gains of $ 400,000 in the quarter and $ 2.7 million in the 9 months, compared with investment gains of $ 1.6 million and $ 2.8 million in the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Clinton Lauds His Policies, But Listeners Are Sparse
description: President Clinton took his autumn campaign for Democratic candidates on its first road test today, flying to a booming Ford assembly line to sit in a red Mustang, lift the hood, check the dipstick and tell auto workers that the Republican Party was determined to ruin their newly found prosperity.

title: Borden and Grey Part On Two Accounts
description: Borden Inc. and Grey Advertising Inc. said yesterday that they had agreed to part ways on the company's cheese and dairy products accounts, which had been consolidated at Grey in November 1992. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Chiquita Brands International
description: Shares of Chiquita Brands International have fallen sharply since reaching a six-month high of $17 on Sept. 22, though it edged up slightly yesterday. On Monday, the produce company said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter.

title: Profit News Helps Dow Rise 55.51
description: A flurry of strong third-quarter earnings reports helped propel the stock market to its largest gain in a month.

title: Treasury Issues Rise; Bill Rates Are Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday, with much of the activity coming early in the session on buying left over from Friday's rally, which was ignited by a weaker-than-expected employment number.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: PATAKI URGES LONGER PRISON TERMS

title: Weis Markets Inc.(WMK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
Kidnapping of Soldier Leads Israel to Halt P.L.O. Talks
description: Israel broke off negotiations with the Palestine Liberation Organization tonight after the militant Islamic group Hamas announced it was holding an Israeli soldier hostage.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Somewhere out there, someone, probably a child, is bereft over the loss of a teddy bear. JANE PAULEY is determined to reunite owner and bear.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: When Nets Call Benjamin, He Better Start Running
description: Benoit Benjamin casually stepped onto the scale in the training room today as he was leaving practice at Princeton University. He peeked as the needle sailed passed 250 pounds, the limit on the scale.

title: Bush Campaigns for Son But Stays Out of the Issues
description: There were 500 people for lunch at $500 a head. There were centerpieces in red, white and blue and a "Jeb for Governor" banner over the head table.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about Darryl Stanley, a United States marine officer checking his boots as he prepared to leave for the Persian Gulf, misstated his rank in some editions. The Marine rank is lieutenant colonel, not lieutenant commander.

title: MCCORMICK TO TAKE A CHARGE FOR CLOSINGS AND JOB CUTS
description: McCormick & Company said yesterday that it would take a charge of $44 million to cover two plant closings and the elimination of about 600 jobs, among other steps. The job cuts will affect about 7 percent of the work force at McCormick, a producer of spices, seasonings, flavorings and specialty foods based in Sparks, Md. The company has about 40 percent of the consumer spice market in the United States. McCormick also plans to sell its Golden West foods unit, which makes onion rings for the fast-food industry. Shares of McCormick rose 50 cents, to $20.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: First Union Corp.(FTU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Stocks Higher in Japan
description: Stock prices rose today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 268.26 points, or 1.35 percent, at 20,089.72. On Tuesday, the Nikkei gained 76.71 points.

title: Bucks Ignore Robinson and Sign Mobley
description: Unwilling to meet a small forward's demand for $100 million, the Milwaukee Bucks signed a big center for considerably less yesterday, coming to terms with ERIC MOBLEY on a four-year contract worth $4.64 million, according to his agent, DONALD WALTON.

title: Jets' Glenn Sidesteps Rookie Label With Veteran Moves
description: It was time for the rookie to look at some serious videos yesterday. So Aaron Glenn returned "A Bronx Tale" to the rental store, and headed for the Jets' training camp complex in Hempstead, L.I.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ABC RAIL PRODUCTS CORP., Chicago, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell one million common shares owned by KARC Acquisition Co., an affiliate of Kohlberg & Co., Mount Kisco, N.Y. CHESAPEAKE CORP., Richmond, , a paper and packaging concern, said it planned to spend $48 million to expand two paper plants.

title: Crown Hts. Judge Won't Step Down
description: A Federal judge denied a defense motion yesterday that he step down from the case of a teen-ager charged with violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar who was fatally stabbed during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn.

title: First Empire State Corp.(FES,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: First Empire recorded a gain of $ 128,000, or 1 cent a share, from the sales of investment securities in the latest third quarter and 9 months, compared with gains of $ 68,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year-ago quarter, and $ 870,000, or 7 cents a share, in the year-ago 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about a rise in foreign investment in Russia misstated the affiliation of Eugene K. Lawson. He is president of the U.S.-Russia Business Council, not the Council for Trade and Economic Cooperation.

title: Suits for Both Sexes, Starting in the 1500's
description: Sex and Suits By Anne Hollander Illustrated. 212 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: Indurain Finds a '95 Route to His Liking
description: No Tours de France are easy but some are easier than others, which explains why Miguel Indurain was trying to restrain a smile today.

title: Personal Health; No, the food you eat will not be radioactive.
description: THE arguments against food irradiation have a familiar ring. At the turn of the century, people opposed to another new process to safeguard food voiced similar complaints, arguing:

title: Gap Narrowing for Poor School Districts, Study Finds
description: In the first detailed academic analysis of New Jersey's controversial four-year-old effort to funnel millions of dollars to poor school districts to narrow the gap with wealthier ones, a group of independent researchers has concluded that the money has been well spent.

title: Mitsubishi Bank to Give Aid to Nippon Trust
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 12 -- Mitsubishi Bank said today that it would provide extensive financial assistance for the troubled Nippon Trust Bank.

title: CRYSTAL BRANDS SAYS IT WILL SELL ITS JEWELRY GROUP
description: Crystal Brands Inc. said yesterday that it would sell its jewelry group for about $78.7 million to Chemical Venture Partners and two private investors. The group makes costume jewelry under the brands Monet, Trifari and Marvella. Crystal Brands, which filed for bankruptcy protection in January, also produces sportswear for men and boys under the brands Gant, Salty Dog and Izod. The buyer is a new company formed by the investors Richard E. Rainwater and Raymond G. Chambers and Chemical Venture Partners, whose sole limited partner is the Chemical Banking Corporation.

title: Judge Complains About Test Delays in Simpson Case
description: Judge Lance A. Ito suggested today that prosecutors in the O. J. Simpson murder case had taken indefensibly long to test crucial blood samples, including blood taken from the Ford Bronco and from a glove retrieved outside his home, that he might exclude the evidence.

title: D.M.B.& B. Official Is Planning to Retire
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles said yesterday that George J. Simko, president of its European and Mideast operations, would retire after 34 years at the agency, effective Jan. 1.

title: Market Place; Ethan Allen revamps its furniture, and its stock outlook.
description: PERHAPS one of the best-known names in American home furnishings is Ethan Allen Interiors. The company's colonial-style furniture has graced middle-class homes for decades. But after a buyout that brought new management, Ethan Allen has an entirely new design style -- hip, contemporary and fresh -- and that also describes its new investment outlook.

title: ALOFT WITH: Franklin Graham; On a Wing and a Prayer
description: CLIMBING to 14,000 feet above the North Carolina Piedmont, the controls of a six-seater airplane at his fingertips, Franklin Graham set a course to Asheville, in the Blue Ridge Mountains, to pick up his parents.

title: Continental Corp. to Sell Insurance Subsidiary
description: The Continental Corporation, an insurance company in the midst of rebuilding its financial strength, said yesterday that it was selling a profitable workers' compensation insurance subsidiary to the Fremont General Corporation for $250 million.

title: Nuveen Plans Buyback
description: John Nuveen & Company has announced plans to buy back up to 600,000 shares, or 6.7 percent, of the company's class A common stock. The repurchased stock would be used to finance the company stock option program, Nuveen said. Nuveen recently completed a repurchase program that resulted in the buyback of 1.2 million shares of class A common stock.

title: Book Notes
description: Booker Prize Winner

title: MBNA Corp.(KRB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an $ 89.8 million tax benefit related to the recognition of tax deductions for the amortization of customer-based intangible assets acquired in connection with the 1991 public offering of the company's common stock. The period also included a charge of $ 92.9 million, net of tax, (of which $ 7.2 million occurred during the three months ended Sept. 30, 1993), for the termination of a marketing agreement with an independent third-party marketing organization.

title: Game Theory Takes Prize in Economics
description: The Nobel Memorial Prize in economics will be divided among three pioneers in the field of game theory. The award underscores a radical shift in thinking, as classical economics -- with its focus on how markets behave -- gives way to game theory, an approach that focuses on the give and take among "players."

title: Supreme Court Roundup; A Cross High Above San Diego Is Dealt Another Setback
description: The Supreme Court declined today to review a lower court's ruling that a 43-foot cross, a San Diego landmark that sits on the highest point of the city, cannot remain on public land.

title: Runners Far Ahead In Aging Healthfully
description: ACTIVE Americans do not wear out, but sedentary ones are likely to rust out, according to the findings of an eight-year study of nearly 800 people 50 and over. As they age, the study showed, those who regularly engage in vigorous aerobic exercise like running are much less likely to develop life-inhibiting disabilities.

title: Hard Work in Off Season Finds Knicks' Harper in Championship Form
description: Derek Harper reported to Knicks training camp in better shape than anyone else. So said Pat Riley, who puts great importance on such things.

title: Burton Abrams, 70, A Corporate Lawyer Active in Charities
description: Burton M. Abrams, a well-known New York lawyer who specialized in corporate and securities law, died on Sept. 23 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mr. Abrams, who lived in Brick Town, N.J., was 70.

title: 3 Economists Share a Prize for Insights Into How Rivalries Function; John C. Harsanyi
description: Born May 29, 1920, in Budapest, John C. Harsanyi has spent virtually his entire career at the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley. He was appointed a visiting professor there in 1964 and a professor in 1965.

title: Prodigy's Debut: Hotel, Nap, Snack, Taxi to Hall
description: YES, that was a big-name television personality a few tables away (Paul Shaffer, the band leader on "Late Show With David Letterman"). Never mind. What captivated Hilary Hahn were the waiters whizzing by on roller skates.

title: CALIFORNIA ENERGY PLANS PROXY FIGHT FOR MAGMA POWER
description: The California Energy Company said yesterday that it would wage a proxy fight to replace the board of the Magma Power Company, a geothermal energy concern in San Diego. The move came after Magma's board unanimously recommended that its shareholders reject California Energy's bid of $35 a share, or $434 million, for 51 percent of Magma. California Energy, based in Omaha, said it would seek a meeting of Magma's shareholders.

title: 'Homicide' Is Back, in a Cloud of Tension
description: As an unconventional show that has already had two unsuccessful runs in prime time, the critically acclaimed crime drama "Homicide: Life on the Street," returning on Friday night at 10, needs all the help it can get. But a dispute has arisen over whether NBC -- which broadcasts the show, and this year even owns it -- is giving it any help at all.

title: Some Educators See Experimental Hybrids As Country's Best Hope for Public Schools
description: In a strip shopping center, just past Dr. Wally Unruh's Chiropractic Arts center and the Cat's Meow florist, sits what many people are increasingly touting as the best hope for saving America's public schools.

title: Baked Eggplants of Autumn Balance a Year-Round Dish
description: IN searching out the freshest, most economical food for this menu, I confirmed the obvious: seasonal foods are the best buy. Granted, it is sometimes difficult now to determine what is "in season"; so many foods are available almost year-round that the line between what is and what is not in season has blurred.

title: Business Owners Fear Chaos at the Hands of Mobs When Aristide Returns
description: Up in the hills, where the air is sweet, the lawns are trimmed and life is lived in languor, they call him "the little monkey" and "the little jerk," and add that eight months of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide as President were enough to lay a road to civil war.

title: Mother Tells Of Pressures On Jewish Son By a Rabbi
description: Crying on the witness stand, the mother of a Jewish teen-ager who prosecutors say was kidnapped by an ultra-Orthodox rabbi and his wife testified yesterday that shortly before her son disappeared for nearly two years the defendants intensely pressured her to leave the boy with them.

title: Peter W. Allport, 74; Led Ad Association
description: Peter W. Allport, former president of the Association of National Advertisers, died on Oct. 3 at the Royal South Hants Hospital in Southampton, England. He was 74 and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: A Few Miles Offshore, Thousands of Marines and Sailors Wait for Their Call
description: The ammunition boxes are lashed to trucks and jeeps, the grenade launchers stand oiled and mounted and the amphibious landing craft sit ready to be disgorged from the bowels of this vessel into the placid, emerald-green waters.

title: Holtz Second-Guesses Handling of Powlus
description: Coming off a 30-11 blowout at Boston College last Saturday, Coach LOU HOLTZ of Notre Dame (4-2) is re-evaluating his approach with quarterback RON POWLUS and mulling some lineup changes for Saturday's home game against Brigham Young (5-1).

title: Suntrust Banks Inc.(STI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MISSION TO HAITI: U.S. Troops Take Over Government Buildings; Christopher to Go to Haiti
description: Secretary of State Warren Christopher will almost certainly accompany Father Aristide to Haiti when he returns on Saturday, Administration officials said today.

title: A Rarity, An Uproar At Weekly Reader
description: An article on smoking has created a firestorm at what is seldom thought of as a cauldron of controversy -- Weekly Reader, a staple in classrooms around the country.

title: Baram Journal; Scene: A Purist Kibbutz. Topic: Bringing Up Baby.
description: Elam Minerbo does not realize it -- he is only 3 years old, after all -- but he has painfully divided this kibbutz on Israel's border with Lebanon.

title: Jazz's Attic Now Looks Like a Proper Institute
