title: U.S. and Balkans: Shifting Stance
description: Maneuvering again to use Serbia as the unlikely instrument of its Balkan diplomacy, the Clinton Administration is now pressing the Serbian President to grant diplomatic recognition to Bosnia and Herzegovina and to Croatia.

title: Harley-Davidson Inc.(HDI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-After a charge of $ 30,300,000, or 40 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of accounting changes.Latest 9 months results included a provision of $ 42.1 million which included a $ 4.6 million one-time tax benefit related to the legal reorganization and recapitalization of Holiday Rambler.Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect Sept. 12, 1994 2-for-1 common stock split.Sales represented net sales.

title: Anderson's Return Big On Agenda
description: Picture the Nets as you would a roomful of musicians -- tuning their instruments, rehearsing for their first performance. They are ready to play, but their maestro needs more time.

title: W. R. GRACE TO SELL ITS PRINTING BUSINESSES
description: W. R. Grace & Company said yesterday that it would sell its printing products business and a related unit for about $144 million to different buyers. The sale is part of the company's previously announced plan to divest itself of nonessential operations to focus on specialty chemicals and health care products. Grace will sell the printing products business to a new company to be formed by the unit's management and an investor group. Grace, based in Boca Raton, Fla., has signed an agreement in principle to sell the related unit to an unidentified party. Grace's printing products business produces photopolymer printing plates, offset printing blankets and rubber-based covers for industrial rollers.(Reuters)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about apparent suicides among American troops in Haiti misstated the recent trend in the number of suicides in the military. It has declined this year, after increasing in 1993; it has not been increasing steadily.

title: Big Modem Maker Buying Small Rival
description: U.S. Robotics Inc., a leading maker of computer modems, said yesterday that it would acquire the Megahertz Holding Company, a smaller rival, in a stock swap valued at $213 million.

title: Thermal Journal; Tribe Smells Sludge and Bureaucrats
description: In the glow of a campfire and the stench of a half-million-ton mountain of human waste, tribal dancers beat their leather drums and sang of a time when the Indians who lived here marked their tribulations more simply, in earthquakes and droughts.

title: Futures
description: Some insider tips for 1995 from your friendly political stock broker:

title: Rangers Turn to Oates As Their New Manager
description: JOHNNY OATES knows pitching and defense. He will be tested to the limit in teaching those skills to the Texas Rangers, his new employer. "I think Texas is very close to being a winner," Oates said yesterday in Arlington, Tex., after being hired as manager and signing a two-year contract. "I know I was certainly intimidated at times by their offense. But there is more to baseball than just offense."

title: Israeli Soldier Died As a Peace Stand-In; Ben-Gurion and Irgun
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Blocks Police Merger In New York
description: In a blow to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's plan to merge the housing police with the New York City Police Department, a State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the Mayor would first need to win the approval of the City Council and the State Legislature to consolidate the forces.

title: CMS Energy (CMS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Buyer of Western Union Will Assume Pensions
description: Bowing to pressure from the Federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, the prospective buyer for Western Union's money-transfer business said yesterday that it would reduce its bid by $300 million and assume full responsibility for the pensions owed to 16,000 Western Union employees and retirees.

title: Dylan, Musician, Just Doing His Job
description: Bob Dylan doesn't act as if his songs are classics. He is a throwback to an era when a musician's job was to perform live, not to perfect a studio arrangement. His music stays in the present tense. Mr. Dylan won't recreate his old recordings; with every new band, and sometimes with each performance, he toys with tempos, rhythms and melodies, rarely content to sing a line the same way twice. Over a three-decade career, some of his live efforts have been garbled, even perverse. But with his current band, Mr. Dylan has reclaimed his place as a great American musician: an improviser with deep, broad roots.

title: The Governor's Plan for Lilco
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo's proposed takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company is clearly an election-year ploy. Three weeks before elections, he says the takeover would yield a 10 percent cut in electricity bills for Long Island voters. But whatever the Governor's motive, his proposal warrants serious attention. Indeed, with additional safeguards the plan could yield sizable benefits to Lilco shareholders and customers.

title: GM Hughes Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 30,400,000, or 8 cents a share, from change in accounting for postretirement benefits.c-Included $ 89.7 million pretax gain on sale of interest in Japan Communications Satellite Co. in both the quarter and 9 months.Latest quarter and 9 months' share earnings are based on net income of $ 244.2 million, before negative effect of General Motors Corp. purchasing accounting adjustment of $ 31 million and $ 793.6 million, before negative effect of General Motors Corp. purchasing accounting adjustment of $ 92.9 million, respectively.Year-ago quarter's share earnings are based on net income of $ 224 million, before negative effect of General Motors purchasing accounting adjustment of $ 30.9 million and the year-ago 9 months' earnings are based on net income of $ 645.3 million, before negative effect of General Motors Corp. purchasing accounting adjustment of $ 92.8 million.GM Hughes Electronics Corp. is a unit of General Motors Corp.

title: Discipline Meets Show Biz, Amicably
description: One of the most popular dance groups on the national circuit, surprisingly, did not make its Manhattan debut until Tuesday night. In the last five years, Hubbard Street Dance Chicago, until recently known as Hubbard Street Dance Company, has been in special demand at American and European festivals; the reason was obvious in this first of several programs in the troupe's two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea).

title: Bowater Inc.(BOW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net lossOn February 4, 1994, the company completed the public offering of 7 percent series B convertible preferred stock and 8.40 percent series C cumulative preferred stock. Preferred dividends relating to these issues decreased earnings per share by 10 cents for the quarter ended October 1, 1994, and increased the loss per share by 28 cents for the 9 months ended October 1, 1994.Latest quarter's share earnings included 29 cents per share gain on the sale of non-strategic timberlands, primarily in Nova Scotia.Year-ago quarter's share earnings included nonrecurring charges of 33 cents per share, consisting of 17 cents for the restructuring of Great Northern Paper and 16 cents for the increase in federal corporate tax rates.Sales represented net sales, which are net of distribution costs.(Loss)

title: Bridge
description: Books on bidding, like some wines, do not usually travel well. But there is now an exception to this generalization: "Partnership Bidding at Bridge," by Andrew Robson and Oliver Segal, is one of the best books to appear in the last decade, and also one of the biggest. It has 408 pages and is an excellent value for $17.95, including mailing, from C & T Bridge Supplies, (310) 598-7010.

title: As Labor Wars Go, This Is Different
description: There once was a time when one couldn't talk labor wars without certain images pushing to the fore.

title: A Hint Of Hope By Baseball Owners
description: If the words their chief labor executive spoke today were not simply rhetoric, major league baseball club owners may be backing away from their "three-imp" plan: impose a freeze on free-agent signings, declare an impasse in negotiations for a new labor agreement and implement the salary cap they covet.

title: Fruit of the Loom (FTL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss on early retirement of debt of $ 8,600,000, or 11 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 3,400,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to sell $400 million of debentures tomorrow.

title: Less Money and Time for Charity, Study Says
description: With little time and even less money to spare, Americans are declining to give to charity.

title: THEATER
description: Male Growing Pains, Childhood to Maturity Judith Anderson Theater

title: Flooded Texas Area Gets Some Relief After 4 Days
description: The sun came out over southeastern Texas for a time today, bringing a measure of relief from the four days of miserable rain and flooding that killed at least nine people and drove thousands of people from their homes. But many rivers, bayous and creeks remained at record levels, and the authorities warned that even a small amount of rain could cause new devastation.

title: At Zabar's, a Realignment at the Top
description: For the last four decades, Murray Klein has helped guide one of New York's most famous institutions. So yesterday, when Mr. Klein announced his retirement from Zabar's food emporium, it was something of an upheaval to the salmon-and-Cuisinart set, not to mention to food retailers.

title: UNITED ASSET MANAGEMENT UNIT TO BUY JMB SUBSIDIARIES
description: The United Asset Management Corporation said yesterday that its Heitman Financial Ltd. unit would buy two affiliates of the JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago, forming one of the world's largest managers of institutional real estate assets. Under the agreement, Heitman will buy JMB Institutional Realty and the JMB Properties Company and form a new company called the Heitman/JMB Advisor Corporation. The transaction will bring together the $6.6 billion of commercial real estate assets managed by Heitman and the $5 billion of assets managed by the JMB subsidiaries.(Bloomberg Business News)

title: Alaska Air Group (ALK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: On the No. 5 Bus Line, A Thud, Then Silence
description: Shmulik Sadan had no idea at first what hit him.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The Burstein clan will get together for a party at Elaine's tonight. But KAREN S. BURSTEIN, the Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, will not be the guest of honor.

title: Fore! Here Comes the Champ
description: The search for a mythical world golf champion will be undertaken in a new event that will feature 32 players vying for the $1 million winner's prize.

title: U.S. Is Ready to Ask U.N. to End Bosnia Arms Ban
description: The Clinton Administration said today that it would introduce a Security Council resolution next week calling for the automatic lifting of the arms embargo against Bosnia's Muslim-led Government in six months.

title: Market Place; U.S. Investigating Nasdaq's Pricing Practices
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that it was investigating the dealers who make Nasdaq markets, an inquiry that intensifies the pressures on Nasdaq to change in ways that could fundamentally alter the nature of the market. At a minimum, the pressures seem likely to cut profit margins for the dealers at the center of the market.

title: S.& L.'s See New Threat, This Time From Banks
description: Just as the $200 billion bailout of the savings and loan industry nears its end, Federal regulators are voicing fears about a new threat to the industry.

title: 'We Can't Wait Forever,' Executor Says
description: CHARLES MOORE'S heirs say that they are not sure what to do with the architect's house now that the University of Texas has rejected it but that they would prefer not to put it on the market. A movement has begun to create a private foundation to operate the house in cooperation with the Austin chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

title: Transactions
description: Basketball National Basketball Association

title: FIRST TENNESSEE TO ACQUIRE PEOPLES COMMERCIAL
description: The First Tennessee National Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Peoples Commercial Services Corporation, the parent company of Peoples Bank, subject to approval by regulators and Peoples shareholders. First Tennessee said Peoples Bank, based in Senatobia, Miss., had $96 million in assets, $84 million in deposits and $11 million in stockholders' equity. First Tennessee, based in Memphis, said Peoples Bank would retain its name, charter and management.(Reuters)

title: Teledyne Inc.(TDY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 75 million after-tax charge for an agreement and preliminary agreement to resolve U.S. government contracting matters.c-After extraordinary income of $ 20.5 million, or 37 cents a share, which included a gain of $ 24.2 million, or 44 cents a share, on the sale of Litton Industries stock and a charge of $ 3.7 million, or 7 cents a share, on the redemption of debt. The period was also after a charge of $ 185.6 million, or $ 3.35 a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and included a $ 6.2 million after-tax charge relating to settlement of certain government contracting matters.(Loss)

title: Economic Scene; Big government and the Big 3 pass the air pollution buck.
description: FOUR years ago Congress got a big round of applause for requiring the states to reduce ozone air pollution to levels that don't send asthmatics to early graves. But it left the details to the states. And -- no surprise -- regulators in the heavily polluted Northeast, who must answer to diverse interest groups, are at a loss on how to get from here to there.

title: Arthur Siegel Memorial
description: A memorial service for Arthur Siegel, a songwriter and pianist, is to be at 7:30 P.M. Monday at St. Peter's Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Mr. Siegel, whose best-known song was "Love Is a Simple Thing," died of heart failure in September at the age of 70. His colleagues from the world of musical theater and cabaret will offer remembrances and perform some of his songs. The public is invited.

title: Putting the Magic Back
description: MAKERS of Oriental carpets have used chemical dyes and machine processes to guarantee a sometimes overly uniform product. Black Mountain Looms, a new company, produces a collection of Oriental folk rugs handmade by artisans in India, Turkey and Romania and marked by a patina of gently uneven colors and nubby textures, the product of vegetable dyes and hand-spun wool.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-16 BOMBING KILLS 20 IN TEL AVIV A powerful bomb tore apart a crowded bus in Tel Aviv, killing at least 20 people and wounding 48. Israeli officials suspect that the attack was carried out by an Islamic militant on a suicide mission. A1

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International The United States' trade deficit with Japan swelled 2.4 percent in August. The report sent the dollar falling to near a record low against the yen. But the trade deficit with the rest of the world narrowed sharply on a surge in exports. [ Page D1. ] The former chief executive of B.C.C.I. was imprisoned for more than eight years. Bank creditors agreed to accept $1.8 billion in compensation from Abu Dhabi, the bank's largest owner. [ D2. ] Companies A meeting between executives of MCA and its parent, Matsushita, left open whether Matsushita might sell MCA to end its deteriorating relationship with the American unit's management. [ D1. ]

title: Moscow Journal; At Court of Yeltsin, Royalty and Hints of Intrigue
description: Some Russians were wondering today about the future of Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, who hotly denied resignation rumors that floated into print on Tuesday night. But many more were wondering where President Boris N. Yeltsin and his aides got the dinner jackets they wore at the state banquet for Queen Elizabeth II on Tuesday, the first black-tie affair in the Kremlin since 1917.

title: General Dynamics Corp.(GD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain on disposal of $ 15,000,000, or 24 cents a share.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 3,000,000, or 5 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 615,000,000, or $ 9.73 a share, which included a gain of $ 645 million, or $ 10.20 a share, on disposal.Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Fabrics From Memory
description: THE textile designer Liora Manne is best known for an award-winning line of rugs inspired by memories of her native Israel. The rugs echo ancient tile patterns, like one on a fountain in her grandmother's garden in Old Jerusalem.

title: Borden Sells Two More Businesses
description: Borden Inc., the beleaguered food company that has agreed to be acquired by a subsidiary of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in a stock deal valued at some $2 billion, said late yesterday that it had agreed to sell two of its North American salty snack foods businesses to Pittsburgh Food and Beverage Inc., a privately held brewing and candy company.

title: Independent Votes Hold Key to 8th District
description: Both Herb Klein and Bill Martini are lawyers who live in Clifton. Beyond that they have little in common, except that Mr. Klein, a Democrat, is the Congressman from the Eighth District and Mr. Martini, a Republican, wants to be.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: METRO DIGEST CLINTON HELPS CUOMO RAISE MONEY President Clinton joined Governor Cuomo in a fight for their mutual political futures, helping to raise $2.5 million to keep the Governor's job in Democratic hands. A1. Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey helped State Senator George E. Pataki. B10. REPORT FAULTS BILINGUAL EDUCATION The Board of Education released a study critical of programs that educate thousands of students in their native languages. A1. School maintenance overhaul is sought. B4. NEW YORK CITY MAN QUESTIONED IN QUEENS SEX ATTACKS A 29-year-old man was being questioned about sex attacks in Jackson Heights, Queens, after a plainclothes police officer said he followed a 15-year-old girl, then heard her say, "Please don't hurt me." B3.

title: President Is Gift-Laden on His Visit
description: In his effort to bolster Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's re-election campaign, President Clinton came to New York yesterday bearing a gift -- Federal permission for the state to experiment with its welfare program.

title: Regional School Planning On Integration Is Praised
description: State education officials and Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. today praised regional plans produced under a Connecticut law intended to promote racial integration across school districts, saying towns and cities had shown they were willing to cooperate on voluntary approaches.

title: John S. Nagel; Foundation Executive, 81
description: John S. Nagel, a retired Ford Foundation executive who focused on family planning in Latin America, died on Saturday at his home in Naples, Fla. He was 81.

title: Hofstra Dutchmen (6-0) Flying High
description: The way Joe Gardi remembers it, he was walking off the field on a cold November day in Missoula, Mont., two years ago.

title: New Rochelle Ponders a Trump Tower in the Sound; Where Some See a Park, the Developer Sees an Island of Condos, With a New Name
description: These days, the Mayor of this small coastal city finds himself on a first-name basis with one of the most flamboyant developers in the world.

title: Polaroid Corp.(PRD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge from the cumulative effect to Jan. 1, 1993 of changes in accounting principle for: postretirement benefits other than pensions, net of tax of $ 85 million, of $ 132.9 million, or $ 2.85 a share, a charge of $ 19.9 million, or 43 cents a share, for postemployment benefits, net of tax of $ 12.7 million, and a gain of $ 33.6 million, or 72 cents a share, for income taxes. The period also included income of $ 44 million from early retirement.Sales are total net sales.Year-ago periods were restated for the 1993 fourth quarter adoption of FAS 112 retroactive to Jan. 1, 1993.(Loss)Both latest periods and year-ago third quarter included the weighted average shares used to calculate primary earnings per common share which included assumed conversion of options outstanding.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TYCO INTERNATIONAL, Exeter, N.H., has received shareholder approval for its $1.2 billion acquisition of Kendall International Inc., Mansfield, Mass., a maker of disposable medical products and adhesive materials. ORNDA HEALTHCORP, Nashville, an operator of hospitals, psychiatric and substance-abuse centers, has signed an agreement with Charter Medical Corp., Macon, Ga., an international health care concern, to share resources in joint venture service offerings.

title: ON CAMPUS WITH: Dr. Judith Rodin; In an Ivy League of Her Own
description: ON Friday, when Judith Rodin is inaugurated as the seventh president of the University of Pennsylvania, she will become the first woman president of an Ivy League university and the chief executive of the largest private employer in Philadelphia. Dr. Rodin, 50, who is known for her research in eating disorders, will also be the only author of a self-help book to steer a major university toward the 21st century.

title: Sports of The Times; Baseball's Empty Office
description: THE World Series was scheduled to start this Saturday night, but the game of baseball isn't being played in stadiums now. Instead, the industry of baseball is being discussed in meeting rooms, as it was yesterday in Washington.

title: Hamelin Is Top Rookie
description: BOB HAMELIN of the Kansas City Royals was an easy winner yesterday as American League rookie of the year. Hamelin, 26, was the first designated hitter to win the award, and the first player from the Royals to earn it since LOU PINIELLA in 1969. The honor, now named the Jackie Robinson Rookie Award, was first presented in 1947. Hamelin batted .282 and hit 24 home runs. (AP)

title: Rankings Are Out: Biggio Is At Second
description: The new edition of baseball's ranking statistics doesn't highlight any names in capital letters or boldface type, but one name should have been accorded that treatment: Craig Biggio of the Houston Astros.

title: A Blue Year for the Purple-and-Green Dinosaur
description: Poor Barney. The plush purple-and-green Tyrannosaurus rex, beloved by toddlers if not their parents, is having a bad year.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Reuters in Business Day on Tuesday about a planned acquisition of Alascom by the AT&T Corporation misstated the effect on employees. The 674 employees who work under a joint agreement between the companies would not be dismissed but would become employees of AT&T.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an article about flooding in Texas showing an inundated highway was printed in mirror image in some editions. The buildings should have been at the right.

title: Fine Dining With Many a Golden Touch
description: WHEN dining in grand style, nothing can be more intimidating than not knowing when to use a particular piece of silverware. The only thing more daunting is when the silverware is made of gold.

title: Disregards to Broadway: Neil Simon's Next Play Will Be in 'Off' Category
description: Firing a shot across the bow of Broadway's unions and theater owners, Neil Simon has announced that his newest play will open Off Broadway when it comes to New York.

title: Iraq Religion Ministry Bombed, Killing One
description: A bomb exploded in an office of the Iraqi Ministry of Religious Affairs here today, killing one person and seriously wounding five others, Iraqi television announced.

title: New Report Is Critical of States on Regulation of Insurers
description: Representative John D. Dingell, who has long favored Federal regulation of the insurance industry, has prepared a new report that describes inadequacies of state insurance regulation and criticizes state regulators for failing to enforce insurance laws.

title: Electronic Data Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Electronic Data Systems Corp. is a General Motors Corp. unit.

title: Way Out Front on a Hot-Button Issue
description: Gov. Tommy G. Thompson strode into the dining room of the Governor's Mansion and plunged, with equal zeal, into his breakfast ham and the welfare record that has made the two-term Republican the envy of many politicians.

title: Panel Calls for Overhauling School Maintenance System
description: Advocating an end to "knee-jerk reaction to intermittent abuses," a special commission called yesterday for overhauling the maintenance and repair of New York City's schools.

title: Journal; The Last Tycoons
description: The only sure thing about Hollywood is that there's no such thing as a sure thing. Robert Redford's "Quiz Show," autumn's media darling, has already drooped at the box office. So has "The River Wild," the thriller everyone pegged to revive Meryl Streep's career by turning her into Harrison Ford.

title: No Vouchers for Jersey City
description: New Jersey wants to experiment with a school voucher plan for Jersey City, the state's second-largest school district. Gov. Christine Whitman and Jersey City's Mayor, Bret Schundler, support the idea; that could help propel this ill-advised plan through the State Legislature.

title: Essay; Of I.Q. and Genes
description: Back in the 50's, a group of feisty dreamers gathered for breakfast at 7 every week in the Madison Avenue eyrie of the realty tycoon William Zeckendorf.

title: Giuliani Could Use a Socrates at City Hall
description: To the Editor:

title: Haiti and U.S. Sign Pact to Stabilize Price of Gas
description: With gasoline prices shifting nervously from a street price of about $37.50 a gallon on Tuesday to one-fifth that sum today, President Jean-Bertrand Aristide signed a $15 million agreement with the United States Agency for International Development this morning that is intended to bring gas back to the pumps, stability to the market and a river of revenue to the state as it struggles to pay for everything from back salaries to light bulbs.

title: Mention of Daughter's Rape Is Generating Its Own Tempest
description: As sound bites from campaign debates go, it was not in the same political league with Lloyd Bentsen's withering riposte that Dan Quayle was "no John Kennedy." Nor was it in the same class as Ronald Reagan's patronizing comment to Jimmy Carter, "There you go again."

title: Report Faults Bilingual Education in New York
description: In a first step toward re-examining bilingual education in New York City, the Board of Education released a study yesterday concluding that the current efforts to educate tens of thousands of students in their native languages are flawed.

title: Up, Up and Away: Muted Carlesimo Starts Over
description: So P. J. Carlesimo, the new coach in town, by reputation yells too much. So, what's wrong with that? The guy he replaced supposedly whined too much, and that nobody-respects-me refrain grew old and tired, along with the legs of some of his stars.

title: Arvin Industries Inc.(ARV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $ 200,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 600,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,000,000, or 9 cents a share, in the 9 months.The company's Schrader Automotive unit is being treated as a discontinued operation. Although the agreement for the sale of Schrader has been terminated, the company is continuing to pursue the disposition of the unit.

title: Treasury Prices Ebb On More Inflation Talk
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for the second day after the latest trade report raised investor concern that the Fed's rate increases had not sufficiently slowed the economy to keep inflation in check.

title: Genuine Parts (GPC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 1,055,000 from cumulative effect of changes in accounting for postretirement benefits and income taxes.

title: High Noon For Arafat
description: Yesterday's bombing of an Israeli bus in which 22 people were killed shows that the only way to contain Hamas is to treat it like the violent terrorist group it is. Yasir Arafat's efforts to lure the extremists into the peace process are guaranteed to fail. If not stopped, Hamas will wreck the fledgling Israeli-Palestinian peace accord.

title: Digital Trims Loss; Market Lifts Stock
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported another big quarterly loss today but showed sufficient signs of improvement to satisfy Wall Street.

title: Ameritech Corp.(AIT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $ 270.1-million pretax charge ($ 168.2 million after-tax, or 30 cents a share) from work force restructuring for the quarter and a $ 800.1-million pretax charge ($ 501 million after-tax, or 91 cents a share) related to work force restructuring for the 9 months.c-Included a $ 85.7-million pretax gain ($ 61.7 million after-tax, or 11 cents a share) related to sale of shares of Telecom Corp. for the quarter and a $ 42.3-million pretax charge ($ 37.3 million after-tax, or 7 cents a share) related to restructuring at Telecom Corp., and a $ 85.7-million pretax gain ($ 61.7 million after-tax, or 11 cents a share) related to sale of shares of Telecom Corp. for the 9 months.Year-ago results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock effective Dec. 31, 1993.

title: Former B.C.C.I. Chief Given 8-Year Jail Term
description: A Federal judge today sentenced the former chief executive of the Bank of Credit and Commerce International to more than eight years in prison and ordered him to pay $255.4 million in restitution in one of the biggest bank frauds in history.

title: MCA Chiefs Fail to Sway Matsushita
description: A contentious meeting of top-level officials from MCA Inc. and its Japanese owner has ended with the Japanese company saying it would not cede greater control to MCA's executives.

title: Calendar: An Auction, A House Tour and Shows
description: Benefit Auction Takashimaya, 693 Fifth Avenue (54th Street); (212) 685-3480, extension 912.

title: Ex-Olympic Swimmer Is Lithuania's Most Likely to Succeed
description: As he climbed the victory stand to collect his medal at the 1976 Summer Olympics in Montreal, Arvydas Juozaitis approached a moment for which he had been preparing for years.

title: GTE Corp.(GTE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 48 million, or 5 cents a share, and $ 119 million, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both on the sale of non-strategic telephone properties.c-After an extraordinary charge on early retirement of debt of $ 90,000,000, or 10 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a provision of $ 46 million, or 5 cents a share, associated with voluntary separation programs.

title: Day's Sales of Problem Book: 10,000
description: The book that is causing all the fuss in Judge Lance A. Ito's courtroom sold about 10,000 copies yesterday alone, according to its publisher, Dove Books.

title: Giuliani Says His Neutrality Is a Deliberate Strategy
description: When he showed up halfway through the ground-breaking ceremony at a new printing plant for The New York Times yesterday in College Point, Queens, a red-faced Mario M. Cuomo sat down next to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who had already given his speech.

title: Martha Raye, 78, Singer And Comic Actress, Dies
description: Martha Raye, the big-mouthed, big-hearted entertainer whose career spanned the decades from vaudeville to videos, died yesterday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. She was 78.

title: Giuliani Proposes Bonds to Help Parochial School Construction
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his administration is considering helping religious groups finance the construction of parochial schools with tax-exempt municipal bonds.

title: Looking for the 'Real' Big Spender
description: In New Jersey's Eighth Congressional District, Representative Herb Klein and his Republican challenger, Bill Martini, are anxious to tag each other as fiscally irresponsible. Mr. Martini's Commercial

title: P.& G. Picks Grey For Giorgio Line
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it had named Grey Advertising in New York as the global agency on its newly acquired Giorgio Beverly Hills line of luxury fragrance brands. The assignment, which had been expected, consolidates P.& G.'s prestige fragrance business at Grey. Billings were not disclosed.

title: Albemarle Corp.(ALB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 6.7 million, or 11 cents a share, on the sale of the company's solimide business in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included charges of $ 7.1 million, or 12 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.Results in the latest 9 months and both 1993 periods are pro forma to give effect to Albemarle as an independent company. In actuality, Albemarle was spun off from Ethyl Corp. on March 1, 1994.

title: Harris Corp.(HRS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 10,100,000, or 25 cents a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: In Ocean Depths, Scientists Find Fast Growth
description: Solving a riddle of the sea, scientists are reporting today that the eerie thickets of snakelike creatures and towering chimneys of rich minerals that inhabit the sunless depths can form on the ocean floor not in eons, centuries or decades but as little as two or three years.

title: Rohm & Haas (ROH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossc-After a charge of $ 50 million associated with accrual for the Lipari landfill remediation and the write-down of a plastics operation in Louisville, Ky., in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a $ 5 million charge on a plant write-down and unit sale, and was after a charge of $ 19 million, or 28 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Marvel Head Leaves Post
description: Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. said yesterday that Bruce Stein had left the posts of president and chief operating officer, less than four months after he joined the company.

title: Moore's House Divided
description: TO build a house, the architect Charles Moore once wrote, "you bind the goods and trappings of your life together with your dreams to make a place that is uniquely your own."

title: 20 KILLED IN TERRORIST BOMBING OF BUS IN TEL AVIV; 48 ARE HURT
description: A powerful bomb tore apart a crowded bus in the heart of Israel's main commercial city today, killing at least 20 people and wounding 48 others in one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in Israeli history.

title: Australian Surfers' Boots
description: IN Australian slang, "ughs" are sheepskin booties, designed by surfers in the 1960's to coddle feet weary after "shooting the curl."

title: Airline Stocks Jump as AMR's Net Surges
description: With little to cheer about in recent years, investors in airline stocks celebrated surprisingly strong third-quarter earnings by the parent of American Airlines yesterday by bidding up shares of most major carriers.

title: The Pop Life
description: In the Face of Adversity

title: Government Revises Case On Terrorism
description: With less than six weeks left before a Muslim cleric and his followers are scheduled to stand trial on terrorism and conspiracy charges, the Government, in court papers filed yesterday, fine-tuned its case, focusing more heavily on the roles of the cleric and the man who was acquitted in the killing of Rabbi Meir Kahane.

title: Sprint Corp.(FON,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraordinary losses of $ 14.5 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 28.2 million, or 8 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Net loss, which included a loss of $ 12.3 million, or 4 cents a share, from discontinued operations, and after a charge of $ 384.2 million, or $ 1.12 a share, from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles.Year-ago periods also included merger, integration and restructuring costs of $ 44.5 million in the quarter and $ 292.5 million in the 9 months.Revenue represented net operating revenues.(Loss)Effective Jan. 1, 1993, Sprint changed its method of accounting for postretirement and postemployment benefits by adopting Statements of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106 and No. 112, respectively, and effected another accounting change.

title: A Police Official Pays The Price of Conscience
description: IT'S sort of amusing. Michael Julian is getting raves for doing in the second place what he readily concedes he should have done in the first.

title: Kohl's Free Democratic Allies Shaken by Big Election Losses
description: For Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and his tiny Free Democratic Party, everything was at stake in the German elections last Sunday, as campaign posters with his picture proclaimed.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the sexual behavior of octopuses omitted a credit. The article was by The Associated Press.

title: Ground Broken For Times Plant
description: The New York Times broke ground yesterday for a sprawling new printing plant in College Point, Queens, one of the largest manufacturing structures to be built in New York City in years.

title: Clinton Ups Atom Stakes
description: In its rush to strike a nuclear agreement with North Korea, President Clinton is gambling that the promise of $4 billion in energy aid can turn what he has labeled "a rogue state" into a responsible member of the global community.

title: Clinton Going Ahead With Mideast Visit
description: The White House said yesterday that President Clinton would go ahead with plans to visit Israel and Jordan next week despite the deadly terrorist bombing in Tel Aviv, which Mr. Clinton called "an outrage against the conscience of the world."

title: Publishers Push a Book By the Pope
description: In an unusually aggressive marketing campaign, the Vatican and publishers have issued a book of personal reflections by Pope John Paul II on his papacy, his faith, his upbringing in Poland and a range of issues related to religion and morality in the modern world.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor RAUL JULIA was reported to be in guarded condition in a Manhattan hospital yesterday following a stroke that he suffered on Sunday.

title: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.  (BMY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Key Has Surgery
description: JIMMY KEY, the ace Yankee left-hander who went 17-4 with a bothersome shoulder in a strike-shortened season, underwent arthroscopic surgery in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday. Afterward, the Yankees said that Dr. JAMES ANDREWS had found two possible sources of the problem and had treated both of them, a rotator cuff problem dating to 1989 and a bone spur. Despite the surgery, the Yankees said they did not know if Key would be ready to start the 1995 season.

title: NBC Attacks Rival's Application for a Television Station
description: NBC lost no time yesterday in attacking a revised application filed by SF Broadcasting to purchase a Wisconsin television station, contending that the new papers were incomplete and still represented an effort by the Fox network to mask the true extent of its control over ownership of the station.

title: No Headline
description: "My eyes closed, and when I opened them everything was black. I looked to see if everything was O.K., and then I jumped through the window. What used to be the window. I looked back and realized what I was saved from. My first thought was that I'd come out alive." -- SHMULIK SADAN, a survivor of the bus bombing in Tel Aviv. [ A16:1. ]

title: Zimmerman Chosen For Mitsubishi Work
description: Zimmerman & Partners Advertising in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said it had been awarded the accounts of 3 additional Mitsubishi dealer associations, bringing the total it handles to 15, with combined billings estimated to exceed $30 million.

title: Garden Q. & A.
description: Two New Reference Works

title: E-Systems (ESY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a special charge of $ 24,495,000 related to write down of certain productization costs associated with some new ventures in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge of $ 8 million, also recorded in the third quarter, to reflect a lawsuit judgment and associated legal expenses recently rendered in the Air Sea Forwarders Case.

title: Petersen Plans to Acquire Sassy Magazine
description: In a move that is bound to change the dynamics of the teen-age magazine field, Petersen Publishing has signed a letter of intent to acquire Sassy magazine from Lang Communications.

title: McKeon Steps Down As N.Y.R.A. President
description: The political struggle for control of horse racing in New York State took a sharp turn yesterday when Gerard J. McKeon resigned as president of the New York Racing Association after months of a running feud with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Let's Be Ready for Next Epidemic
description: To the Editor:

title: Allegheny Power Systems (AYP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov. 4, 1993.

title:
IN PERFORMANCE;
DANCE
description: A (Fascinating) LifeAnd (So Many) Loves La Mama E.T.C.

title: INSIDE
description: Respite From Rain

title: Times Co. Has Profit of $120.6 Million
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its earnings surged in the third quarter, reversing a loss from a year earlier, as all three of its major business lines showed improvement.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Beleagured by the fallout from two new books dealing with her supposedly loveless marriage and reported infidelity, the PRINCESS OF WALES flew to New York yesterday for a respite.

title: A New Ayer Unit For Event Marketing
description: Ayer Inc. in New York said it had created Ad: Vent, a subsidiary specializing in event marketing, from the agency's strategic events marketing group division. The new unit, with 17 employees, opens with existing Ayer clients like AT&T and Gillette, and two new ones: Tommy Hilfiger U.S.A. and General Motors. Mark Dowley, 30, who was a senior vice president and management supervisor at Ayer's New York office, was named to head the subsidiary as senior vice president and managing director.

title: Season Opens For Folk Art
description: ON your mark. Get set. Go -- for that sponge-ware pitcher!

title: Chesapeake Corp.(CSK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Northrop Grumman Corp.  (NOC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 20 million pretax loss provision related to the AGM-137 Tri-Service Standoff Attack Missile, or TSSAM, program. The periods also included $ 1 million loss on a 747 jetliner program, and a benefit from the delivery of two B-2 bombers to the Air Force.c-Included pretax loss provision of $ 14 million for the TSSAM program, and an $ 18 million retroactive tax increase enacted in August 1993, in the quarter and 9 months.

title: BOOKER TO ACQUIRE NEW JERSEY FISH-FARM COMPANY
description: Marine Harvest International Inc., a fish-farm company based in Woodbridge, N.J., agreed yesterday to be acquired by Booker P.L.C. of Britain for $122 million. Marine Harvest, which produces Atlantic salmon in Scotland and Chile and western white shrimp in Ecuador, said Booker was making a cash tender of $10.20 for each of Marine Harvest's shares. Shares of Marine Harvest rose 87.5 cents, to $10, on the American Stock Exchange. Booker said the purchase of Marine Harvest would make it one of the world's leading producers of farmed Atlantic salmon and would give the company better access to the growing salmon market.(Reuters)

title: Militants, Once Seen as Useful to Israel, Are Now Its Main Foe
description: There is a lingering paradox in the rise of Hamas, the militant Islamic group that took responsibility for the attack in Tel Aviv today.

title: Pfizer Inc.(PFE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net lossc-Included a $ 750 million pretax charge for certain restructuring and unusual items including personnel reductions and the write-down of certain tangible and intangible assets, in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a pretax gain of about $ 60 million from the sale of the company's interest in Minerals Technologies Inc., offset by $ 62 million in pretax charges for restructuring, consolidation and streamlining of certain businesses.(Loss)

title: Hornets' Johnson Out
description: LARRY JOHNSON of the Charlotte Hornets could be out for two months with a possible stress fracture in his left foot, the club said. Johnson, who has a 12-year, $84 million contract, missed 31 games last season with a deep lower back sprain.

title: Hold the Little-Pig Jokes, Please
description: ENOUGH already about the three pigs: houses built of straw bales are being rediscovered as a viable form of "alternative architecture." Straw is a cheap resource that is rarely put to efficient use, says Catherine Wanek, a New Mexico videographer and straw bale proponent.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fee Reduced For Drawing District Map In Nassau
description: A Federal judge has cut $60,000 from the bill submitted by a special master whom the judge named in July to draw district maps for the proposed Nassau County Legislature.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: American Quartet Repertory In the Chromatic Area Miller Theater

title: Magnifying Metaphors in a Work Rich in Them
description: "Let me tell you about metaphor," a 17th-century witch says to the child of an adulterous liaison in Phyllis Nagy's perversely breezy adaptation of "The Scarlet Letter" at the Classic Stage Company. The instructions probably aren't necessary, since the witch is talking to a living metaphor. The little girl, Pearl, is played by an indisputably adult actress (Erin Cressida Wilson) in a sexy crimson gown that keeps falling off her shoulders.

title: Davies and Nicholas Use Power and Finesse
description: They are the Mutt and Jeff of European women's golf, the long and short of it, a par 5 and a par 3. They are to the European Solheim Cup team what Seve Ballesteros and Jose Maria Olazabal are to the European Ryder Cup team. They are Laura Davies and Alison Nicholas, best of friends and Europe's best pairing in the Solheim Cup.

title: Memorial Service Is Set For Ungerleider-Mayerson
description: A memorial service for Joy Ungerleider-Mayerson, a former director of the Jewish Museum in Manhattan, will be held at 6 P.M. on Oct. 27 at the museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue at 92d Street in Manhattan. At her death, on Sept. 7, Mrs. Ungerleider-Mayerson was president of the Dorot Foundation, whose interests include biblical archeology and Jewish education. She was also chairman of the Albright Institute for archeological research in Jerusalem and served on the boards of several cultural and educational organizations.

title: Princeton Stadium Slowly Crumbling
description: Fans attending Princeton University football games this season have been noticing some unsettling changes around the school's 80-year-old Palmer Stadium. Not only is one section of seats off-limits, but the undersides of the bleachers are lined with orange and black tarps designed to catch any chunks of concrete that might fall.

title: Morton Intl.(MII,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
After Two Decades, How Much Longer?
description: Like some aging life of the party who can no longer depend on nips and tucks to maintain the illusion of youth, "Saturday Night Live" is discovering the futility of makeovers. Celebrating its 20th anniversary this season, this NBC show has been in some sort of turmoil since almost the beginning. But back then it was largely a matter of creativity bursting at the seams. These days it's more a pedestrian question of survival, of trying to at least simulate some of that early exuberance. It's not happening.

title: Harassment in Singapore
description: Many Americans applauded Singapore's brutal caning of the teen-ager Michael Fay earlier this year. They should now ask themselves whether they like the way the tiny city-state is dealing with another American citizen, Christopher Lingle.

title: CHRYSLER PLANS JOINT VENTURE IN VIETNAM
description: The Chrysler Corporation is planning a joint venture in Vietnam to assemble and eventually manufacture Jeeps, pickup trucks and other vehicles, a company representative said yesterday. The company hopes to sign an agreement with a Vietnamese partner within six weeks, said Mark Gelinas of the consulting firm Vatico, Chrysler's representative in Hanoi. Chrysler would become the first American auto maker to assemble vehicles in Vietnam. Chrysler initially plans to assemble vehicles from imported kits.(AP)

title: Sale of Farrar, Straus Is Near, Its President Says
description: Farrar, Straus & Giroux, the family-run publishing house that has maintained a steadfast independence through extraordinary times of industry turmoil, says it will soon be sold to a larger firm.

title: The Ultimate Hollywoodian Lives an Anti-Hollywood Life
description: Years ago George Lucas fled Hollywood, a town and a state of mind that appalled him. He poured his fortune into creating Skywalker Ranch, a secluded Victorian-style work paradise surrounded by groves of eucalyptus and redwood in Marin County, just north of San Francisco.

title: Removal of Weil, Gotshal Sought in Leslie Fay Case
description: In a stinging rebuke of one of the country's richest and most prestigious law firms, a Federal official recommended yesterday that Weil, Gotshal & Manges be removed from the Leslie Fay bankruptcy case and be forced to forfeit part of the $5.3 million in fees it has billed to date.

title: Ailing Toe Can't Deter A Determined Oakley
description: So far, nothing has stopped Charles Oakley during the preseason. He has played well despite a partly dislocated right toe. He has played well despite lingering dissatisfaction with his contract.

title: Simpson Judge Seeks Delay of Broadcasts
description: Judge Lance A. Ito, struggling to control intense publicity about the O. J. Simpson murder case, asked three television broadcasters to delay interviews with the author of a new book about Nicole Brown Simpson. He also indicated that he plans to sequester the jury for at least part of the trial.

title: Tribune Co.(TRB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-Included income of $ 3,923,000 in the quarter and loss of $ 5,836,000 in the 9 months, from equity in QUNO. The 9 months also included a pretax gain of $ 39,381,000 on sale of QUNO stock. On April 14, 1994, Tribune sold 5.5 million shares of QUNO common stock for approximately $ 95 million, which resulted in a pretax gain of $ 39.4 million, or about $ 13 million after-tax. This sale increased primary net income per share by 19 cents. With this sale, Tribune reduced its equity interest in QUNO from 59 percent to 34 percent.c-Included losses of $ 5,849,000 in the quarter and $ 11,317,000 in the 9 months, from equity in QUNO.

title: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: CALIFORNIA SENATOR Struggle for the Senate; In California, a Daily Quest for Cash
description: Occasionally, Senator Dianne Feinstein makes a speech. Sometimes she actually campaigns, as she did in the San Fernando Valley on Monday. Once in a great while, she relaxes.

title: Cavs Lose Wilkins
description: Already scrambling to fill vacancies created by LARRY NANCE's retirement and BRAD DAUGHERTY's bad back, the Cleveland Cavaliers learned yesterday that starting guard GERALD WILKINS will miss the 1994-95 season because of a ruptured Achilles' tendon. Wilkins was injured Tuesday night during the second quarter of an exhibition game against the Boston Celtics in Providence, R.I. (AP)

title: Nothing Is So Wrong With Esiason That Running Game Couldn't Help
description: Elegance is for San Francisco, where they should have a separate category for style points next to touchdowns.

description: b-Included loss from discontinued operations of $ 800,000, or 1 cent a share.c-Included loss of $ 800,000, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations, and the income tax provision for the first quarter of fiscal 1994 included a favorable adjustment of $ 1.4 million, or 2 cents a share, from tax law changes.

title: MICROSOFT CORP. (MSFT,NNM)
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose more than 32 percent on strong sales of its Windows operating system and Office package of business programs.

Simpson murder case, asked three television broadcasters to delay interviews with the author of a new book about Nicole Brown Simpson. He also indicated that he planned to sequester the jury for at least part of the trial.

title: Report Leads Germany to Review Bizarre Death of Politician
description: A tale of international intrigue and the possible murder of one of Germany's most promising young politicians is gripping the country.

title: Aristide Vows to Include Wealthy in Haiti's New Cabinet
description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, elected as the revolutionary champion of Haiti's poor, pledged today that his new administration would include members of the tiny, wealthy elite that has long held sweeping power in Haiti.

description: A LONG LINE OF DEAD MEN By Lawrence Block 285 pages. William Morrow & Company. $20. WILD HORSES By Dick Francis 319 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

title: Regulator's Plan on Insurers
description: The Washington State Insurance Commissioner, Deborah Senn, announced proposals yesterday to make it easier for policyholders to collect from their insurance company on claims for cleaning up enviromental damages.

title: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: PENNSYLVANIA SENATOR Struggle for the Senate; In Pennsylvania, Round 2 on Healt
description: Just months ago, most analysts, and many people in his own Republican Party, had dismissed Representative Rick Santorum, who is challenging Senator Harris Wofford, as too far to the right to suit the political tastes of most Pennsylvanians.

title: M.T.A. Committee Presses City For Coliseum Development Plan
description: Eager to start producing revenue from the largely dormant New York Coliseum, members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday pressed the city to either support a plan for an interim use of the complex, or make a concrete proposal to sell it.

title: Weapons Makers Report Rise in Profits for Third Quarter
description: Three weapons makers, McDonnell Douglas, Northrop Grumman, and General Dynamics, reported higher third-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: Speeding Rookie Is Spotted By Reeves
description: He is shy, and at first Thomas Randolph didn't want to be interviewed. He would rather focus on what's ahead, the task facing him this Sunday. He is a rookie cornerback who will be thrown into the fire, and he doesn't want to get burned.

title: In a Shaken Tel Aviv, Fear Now Rides the Buses
description: Yitzhak Razimor had one overwhelming concern today as he rode the No. 5 bus down Dizengoff Street, past the stores selling books and fashion boots and jewelry, past the fast-food outlets and past the little makeshift shrine of candles and flowers where at least 21 people died in a suicide bomber's attack on the same bus line on Wednesday.

title: Martin Marietta (ML,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Stocks Are Off Sharply As Interest Rates Rise
description: The stock market, rising for much of the month because of a steady string of higher earnings reports, plunged yesterday in heavy trading.

title: G.M. Stock Falls on Results
description: Panicked investors dumped shares of the General Motors Corporation today after the company announced that despite strong car and truck sales and overall profitability, its core North American automotive operations fell back into the red during the third quarter.

title: On My Mind; Terror And the West
description: The bus creeps along, stops an instant for a traffic signal and disintegrates. Later, police have a difficult time separating the bits of bone, deciding which belong to the corpses of passengers and which to the people torn apart in their offices and shops on Madison Avenue.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Working District, Working Lunch

title: Commercial Metals Co.  (CMC,N) reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Commercial Metals said the increase in the latest fiscal year rose despite pretax startup costs of about $ 3 million related to the new melt shop at the Birmingham, Alabama steel minimill and a pretax charge of $ 9.5 million from the LIFO effect on inventory valuation.

title: Article 593494 -- No Title
description: Jean-Claude Iacovelli has few peers when it comes to making sophisticated, inventive cuisine affordable. Jean-Claude, the intimate little boite he opened on Sullivan Street in SoHo in 1992 quickly drew crowds for its bold, up-to-date French bistro fare. Now, at Caffe Lure, north of Houston Street, Mr. Iacovelli has done it again.

description: b-After a charge of $ 97 million, or 64 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.Year-ago 9 months' results included the OrganoSilicon business, sold in July 1993.

title: Five Years Later: Eastern Europe, Post-Communism -- A special report; East Europe Watches the Bear, Warily
description: For nearly 50 years, from the West German border to the Pacific Ocean, the Soviet Union ruled its imprisoned republics and satellites with brutal, calculated imperialism backed by fearsome military strength.

title: Southwestern Public Service Co.(SPS,N) reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
A Romeo Plays a Romeo. Hmm.
description: Warren Beatty isn't quite Cary Grant in "Love Affair," though he plays the same ladies' man Grant made so fabulously debonair in Leo McCarey's 1957 "An Affair to Remember." (Charles Boyer also played this role, in 1939.) Surprisingly, he isn't quite Warren Beatty either.

title: Back Is a Pain for Graf and Lendl
description: The bad back syndrome is striking the men's and women's tours with equal severity: top-ranked Steffi Graf isn't sure when or whether she'll play again this year, and 34-year-old Ivan Lendl is starting to wonder whether he'll play again at all. Neither has been physically able to compete since the United States Open.

title: AT&T Corp.(T,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and after a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 9,608,000, or $ 6.22 a share.Latest and year-ago results included merger with McCaw Cellular Communications. Without the shares or merger costs associated with McCaw, the company's revenues were $ 17,992,000,000 and net income was $ 1,191,000,000, or 87 cents a share, in the 1994 period, compared with revenues of $ 16,663,000,000 and net income of $ 1,051,000,000, or 78 cents a share, in year-ago period.(Loss)

Also included an increase of $ 5.1 million, or 7 cents a share, in the provision for income taxes due to the 1 percent increase in the tax rate.(Loss)

description: b-Included a write-off of $ 249,300,000 for purchased research and development.

description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 2,925,000, or 4 cents a share.c-Included gain of 10 cents a share from the sale of residential telephone equipment unit.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge related to early extinguishment of debt of $ 7,800,000, or 1 cent a share, in the quarter and $ 63,200,000, or 12 cents a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 67,400,000, or 14 cents a share.Year-ago quarter and 9 months income from continuing operations of $ 442,400,000, or 89 cents a share, and $ 1,286,700,000, or $ 2.59 a share, respectively, both included charges totaling 9 cents a share for the impact of a higher corporate income tax rate and debt refinancing.

title: Uneasy Poses Along Campaign Trails of the Past
description: With Election Day just over the horizon, the Museum of Modern Art is offering a lively, if ultimately unsatisfying, examination of that modern electoral phenomenon, the complex mating dance between the politician and the camera. "American Politicians: Photographs From 1843 to 1993" looks at the often convoluted relationship between photography and politics in the United States.

title: F.C.C. Issues Video-Network Rules
description: The Federal Communications Commission took steps today to let telephone companies move into the cable television business without forcing phone customers to foot the bill.

title: Detective Is Found Not Guilty Of Selling Secrets to the Mafia
description: A New York City police detective assigned to an elite Federal-city unit that battles organized crime was acquitted yesterday in a trial on charges that he sold confidential information to mobsters.

title: No Headline
description: "If God takes that Cadillac, it'll just have to go." GERALDINE CHERRY, looking at her car in flooded Liberty, Tex. [ A12:6. ]

title: Kuwait Journal; With War's Passions Spent, Love's in the Gulf Air
description: Most marriages here are arranged, couples on dates must often take chaperons, and magazines that discuss romance are heavily censored. But love has finally triumphed, at least on the airways.

title: Beverly Enterprises Inc.(BEV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $ 2,345,000, or 3 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.Year-ago quarter and 9 months' share earnings from continuing operations of a loss of 5 cents a share and income of 25 cents a share, respectively, both are after deducting $ 20 million, or 25 cents a share, for one-time redemption premium on preferred stock.(Loss)

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on Oct. 13 about a British scholar, author and former Government official, Chaim Raphael, omitted mention of part of his work. In addition to crime novels under the pen name Jocelyn Davey, Mr. Raphael wrote articles and books under his own name about Jewish life and history and related subjects. Those books include "A Feast of History," "The Springs of Jewish Life" and "The Road from Babylon," which the obituary erroneously included among the crime novels. The book was reprinted as "The Sephardi Story."

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Martinez Needs Only a One-Way Ticket The Wimbledon champion, Conchita Martinez, won't need a round-trip ticket to attend her coach's wedding in Switzerland after all. Martinez, who had planned to take a day off from the Brighton International tournament in England today to fly to the wedding and back, was upset, 6-1, 6-3, yesterday by Larisa Neiland of Latvia, who had not taken a set from Martinez in their previous four meetings. (AP)

title: Sounds Around Town
description: A Hampton Get-Together

title: City's Costly Cars Don't Fulfill Goal
description: Seeking to improve air quality, New York City has bought hundreds of cars, vans and trucks that can run on natural gas or methanol, paying up to $5,700 extra a vehicle.

title: Walker L. Cisler, 97, Advocate of Nuclear Energy
description: Walker L. Cisler, an engineer who became chairman of the Detroit Edison Company and achieved international renown as an advocate of the peaceful use of nuclear energy, died on Tuesday at his home in Grosse Pointe, Mich. He was 97.

title: VF Corp.(VFC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Included a 26 cents a share gain from an income tax settlement and a 15 cent a share capacity write-down in fleece and T-shirts, in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Abroad at Home; A Widening Freedom
description: Twenty-five years after Earl Warren retired as Chief Justice, a conference at the University of Tulsa Law School last week considered what legacy his Supreme Court left. As the conferees spoke, a startling testament to the continuing influence of the Warren Court came from half a world away.

title: Thousands in Moscow Mourn Journalist Killed in Blast
description: With angry charges of murderous plots in high places, thousands of grieving Russians today filed past the coffin of a crusading journalist who has become the latest martyr in the campaign for democracy here.

title: Police Say Suspect Is Serial Rapist in Queens
description: Law-enforcement officials tried to assure the public yesterday that they had captured the man responsible for at least 14 sexual attacks in Jackson Heights, Queens, over the last three years, even though the suspect was formally charged in only five cases.

title: Eaton Corp.(ETN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Inside Art
description: First Lady's Garden Updates

title: After Years of Losing, the Columbia Lions Say It's Their Turn
description: Jim Hudnall had heard all the kind words since last Saturday at Franklin Field, when Columbia's football team experienced the type of afternoon that was once considered a victory. The Lions had held Pennsylvania, the unbeaten defending Ivy League champion, to four field goals. They were within 6 points late in the game before losing, 12-3.

title: Looking for the Magic in Painting
description: Elizabeth Murray'S works are smart, animated and sensuously painted. Contained within the curves and angled planes of her oddly shaped canvases are figures and objects: hands, babies, tables, coffee cups, palettes, brushes. It can take a while to decode them. They are nominally abstracted forms in flux, props in mostly domestic dramas of a psychological intensity and tenderness sometimes belied by the jazzy colors that Ms. Murray prefers. Her works suggest motion, fluidity. They're full of demotic shapes drawn from the comics (she thought of becoming a commercial artist when she was young). But they're also linked with painters like Cezanne, Miro, Klee, Johns and de Kooning.

title: U.S.-North Korea Accord Has a 10-Year Timetable
description: The new accord between the United States and North Korea outlines an elaborate timetable for steps by each side that would end in the complete dismantling of North Korea's nuclear program in about 10 years, according to details released today.

title: Sports of The Times; Lalas Fears He May Not Play at Home
description: THIS is not exactly political exile. Alexi Lalas walks out the door and is immediately recognized by his abundant red hair. He looks like a human tie-dyed shirt, circa 1967, the Summer of Love in San Francisco. He is the flamboyant, guitar-playing grunge-rock American who scored the goal that helped Padua beat Milan last Sunday.

description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 36,000,000, or $ 1.25 a share.

title: Devils Chip In And Buy Ice Time
description: With Bruce Driver, the team's player representative, leading the way, eight Devils skated for about 75 minutes this morning at the South Mountain Arena here.

title: Frank Battisti, 72, Federal Judge Presiding Over Demjanjuk Case
description: Frank Joseph Battisti, the Federal judge who presided over several important cases in Cleveland, including the deportation of John Demjanjuk, died on Wednesday at the Cleveland Clinic. He was 72 and lived in Cleveland.

title: A Kern Classic Lives On
description: Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein 2d may have changed the course of musical-theater history with "Show Boat" in 1927. But who remembers their fifth and final Broadway collaboration, "Very Warm for May," which opened 12 years later and ran for only 59 performances?

title: Second Mattingly Runs Onto Stage
description: The old sports order changeth, yielding place to new, and Don Mattingly fulfills his shattered athletic hopes in many ways, among others, it turned out yesterday, vicariously through his wife's planned participation in the New York City Marathon on Nov. 6.

title: Bryn Terfel Brings the Met A Spirited New Figaro
description: ON most occasions, it would be worth trading in half a century of ordinary repertory for the pleasures of Mozart's "Nozze di Figaro." On Wednesday night, I might have kept Bach in reserve but would have happily given up everything else. The performance at the Metropolitan Opera was extraordinary: supple, sometimes sexy and often achingly beautiful. As the characters passed from bewilderment to understanding, the word enlightenment, often associated with this work and its era, took on a literal meaning.

title: Drug-Fraud Prison Term
description: Jay Marcus, the former chief executive of the Halsey Drug Company, has been sentenced to 41 months in prison for conspiracy to defraud the United States Food and Drug Administration, the Justice Department announced today.

description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 7,037,000, or 8 cents a share, associated with the sale of two operating units.

title: Restaurants
description: Each time an Italian restaurant opens in New York City, the owners have to come up with a compelling reason for customers to patronize their establishment instead of the 2,200 other Italian restaurants in town.

title: In New Jersey Senate Race, Money From All Over
description: Senator Frank R. Lautenberg of New Jersey has sponsored a law that bans smoking on most airline flights, so tobacco executives from all over the country are giving money to his Republican challenger, Chuck Haytaian.

title: Riley Willing to Wait and See on Christie
description: Doug Christie said he has heard the rumors.

title: Big Business Is Shifting Donations to Democrats
description: Some of the nation's largest and most heavily regulated companies, which two years ago raised millions of dollars for the Republican Party, have given considerably more this year to the Democrats.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNA NICOLE SMITH, the voluptuous model, filed suit against New York magazine on Wednesday claiming unauthorized use of her photograph on the cover of its Aug. 22 issue for an article called "White Trash Nation." In the photo, she appeared squatting in a short skirt and cowboy boots and was eating a bag of chips.

title: Radio-Station Intrigue In a Lucas Creation
description: Some movies are so big and so bad that they're funny, like "The Specialist." Others are bad in a grim and boring way, like "Radioland Murders." Even George Lucas makes mistakes, and "Radioland Murders" is one of his whoppers.

description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that its board had authorized the repurchase of up to $100 million of its class A common shares.

title: Germany's Claimants
description: To the Editor:

title: Poems Coming Up On the Subway
description: In theory, "Poetry in Motion" puts up two new poems every month throughout New York City's buses and subway trains. In practice, the schedule may vary. Posters are also stolen, particularly in the subway. If you wish to own a poster, the Metropolitan Transit Authority prefers that you buy one. Sets of posters from the last year may be bought at the Transit Museum gift shop in the Main Concourse of Grand Central Terminal or at the Transit Museum at Boerum and Schermerhorn Streets in downtown Brooklyn. Each poster is $4.

title: I.B.M.'s Profits Exceed Wall St. Forecasts
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings were significantly higher than the estimates of most Wall Street analysts, on surprisingly strong sales of its mid-size and mainframe computers and continued cost-cutting efforts.

title: Alternative Fuel Program Starts Rough
description: New York City has bought hundreds of cars, vans and pickup trucks that can run on natural gas or methanol, but city departments appear to be running them mostly on old-fashioned gasoline instead, or not running them at all.

title: Dollar Hits Low Against Yen With More Declines Feared
description: The dollar continued its decline today, touching a record low, as traders reacted to renewed fears of inflation in the United States and comments by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen that Washington had no immediate plans to support the currency.

title: American Home Products (AHP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: To the Editor:

description: JOHN HART, principal architect of the Cleveland Indians' turnaround, received a five-year contract yesterday to remain the team's general manager through 1999. The deal includes club options for the years 2000 and 2001.

As a result, $ 12.1 million was returned to operating income, which was offset by $ 12 million provided in cost of sales for increased reserves relating to valuation of assets and liabilities, primarily for international operations.

title: Four Phone Companies Join To Create Wireless Network
description: Four of the nation's biggest cellular telephone companies teamed up today to build a nationwide wireless network. But their efforts to align with the MCI Communications Corporation, the long-distance company, apparently came to an abrupt stop.

title: Mondesi Top Rookie
description: Outfielder RAUL MONDESI unanimously won the National League rookie of the year award yesterday, the third consecutive Dodger winner. Mondesi, 23, batted .306 and led major league outfielders with 16 assists. Dodgers catcher MIKE PIAZZA was a unanimous winner last year; first baseman ERIC KARROS won a closer vote in 1992.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Wednesday about an agreement between the United States and North Korea referred incorrectly in some copies to the source of more than $4 billion in aid proposed for North Korea. As the article said, the bulk of the assistance would be provided by South Korea and Japan, not the United States.

description: The Seagram Company said yesterday that it had selected Grey Advertising in New York to handle advertising in the United States for three of its brands: Captain Morgan rums, Crown Royal Canadian whisky and Myers's rums. The account, with billings estimated at $15 million, had been at DDB Needham Worldwide in New York until that agency was dismissed in June.

SUMMIT'S EYE LASER IS RECOMMENDED, WITH CONDITIONS
description: An advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration yesterday recommended approval, with several conditions, of a laser treatment from Summit Technology Inc. to correct nearsightedness. A second analysis of the device's clinical trial must show that it meets minimum safety and effectiveness standards, the committee said. "The panel members felt that the data presented to it wasn't sufficient on its own" to recommend unconditional approval, said Dr. Michael Harris, the chairman of the panel. Earlier, shares of Summit fell $3.50, to $32.50, in Nasdaq trading after two experts told the panel of problems with the treatment. Trading was halted in the stock. Jonathan Cohen, an analyst at Smith Barney, said the vote later in the day was "a clearly positive event for the company," which is based in Waltham, Mass.

title: Rupture of Texas Pipelines Sends Gasoline Prices Up
description: Gasoline jumped yesterday to its highest price in eight weeks, pulling crude oil higher, after floods in eastern Texas caused two pipelines to rupture and forced others to close temporarily.

title: COCA-COLA CO. (KO,N)
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its earnings jumped 20 percent in the third quarter, its biggest quarterly increase in four years.
