title: McKesson Corp.(MCK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 8.4 million, or 20 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 18 million, or 43 cents a share, in the 6 months. The periods also included an extraordinary charge of $ 6.6 million, or 16 cents a share, due to a credit loss arising from a credit receivable involving a retail drugstore customer of McKesson Drug.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 7.2 million, or 18 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 13.9 million, or 34 cents a share, in the 6 months.The year-ago 6 months also included, on a pretax basis, a gain on the sale and donation of Armor All stock of $ 55.1 million, and partially offset by a contribution of Armor All stock to the McKesson Foundation of $ 4.3 million and a loss on the termination of interest rate swap arrangements of $ 13.4 million. After taxes, the special items amount to a gain of $ 24.5 million, or 60 cents a share. The period also included a charge of $ 4.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from debt extinguishment, and after a charge of $ 16.7 million, or 41 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Time Inc. Raises Its Multimedia Profile With an Internet Test
description: With much of the magazine industry still wary of interactive media, Time Inc. is intent on staking out a front-line position. On Monday, at the annual American Magazine Conference, it will announce the start of a test to offer Internet users an interactive version of some of its magazines.

title: Theafilm Names Its First Agency
description: Theafilm Distribution Network Inc., a new film distribution company in Los Angeles, has named Eisaman, Johns & Laws in Los Angeles as the first agency to handle its account. Theafilm, which plans to distribute films beginning in February, said on Friday that its annual advertising spending aimed at moviegoers was expected to total $60 million.

title: Differences on Ulster and Bosnia Take the Bloom Off U.S.-British Relations
description: During a radio interview the other day, Kenneth Clarke, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, was asked about the new opposition leader, Tony Blair. He replied by calling him "Clintonesque," then went on to define the term.

title: A Hasidic Tip of the Hat To Pataki Isn't Unanimous
description: They may dress alike, but the Orthodox Jews of Crown Heights are as divided as the rest of New York State over the race for governor. Yesterday, even as State Senator George E. Pataki clipped on his personalized yarmulke to pick up an endorsement from one neighborhood political group, a second group of Lubavitchers was praising Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and denouncing the first group.

title: IBP Inc.(IBP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 12,626,000, or 26 cents a share.

title: Cresta Awards Go To Pytka Again
description: For the second consecutive year, Pytka, the commercial production company in Venice, Calif., led by the director Joe Pytka, took top honors in the Cresta International Advertising Awards sponsored by the International Advertising Association and Creative Standards International. The winners will be honored at a ceremony on Nov. 9 in Budapest.

title: Pataki's Lottery Plan Raids School Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Ziar Nad Hronom Journal; Tarnished Aluminum Plant (but a Shiny Future?)
description: Rudolf Camaj doesn't quite know whether to trust the stories that one day the aluminum plant here will be so clean there might be an outdoor swimming pool for the workers. "It is almost unbelievable to us that the old factory will be replaced by a new factory that won't be harming the environment," said Mr. Camaj, a 39-year-old fire-safety worker who has toiled inside the smelters among the noxious fumes since he was 16.

title: Solaris to Handle Ortho Products
description: The Solaris Group division of the Monsanto Company in San Ramon, Calif., has named BBDO West in San Francisco to handle advertising for its Ortho lawn and garden products, which had been handled by J. Walter Thompson San Francisco for the last three years. Billings were estimated at $8 million to $10 million. BBDO was awarded the account on Friday after a five-week review that also included Cole & Weber in Seattle, the Glennon Companies in St. Louis and Ogilvy & Mather Los Angeles. A campaign is expected to begin early next year.

title: U.S. Begins Privatizing Internet's Operations
description: Having succeeded beyond its wildest dreams in nurturing the Internet computer web into a vital national communications system, the Federal Government has begun turning over to the private sector the job of operating and maintaining the network's major arteries.

title: Cipsco Inc.(CIP,N) reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
Treasury Plans to Auction Bills and Notes
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bill and note markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The Government will auction two-year notes on Tuesday and five-year notes on Wednesday.

title: A Houston Suburb's Week of Calamity
description: If there was an epicenter to the sundry miseries visited upon the Houston area in its four days of disaster last week, it was this unassuming industrial suburb of single-family houses 15 miles from the city's downtown skyscrapers.

title: Essay; Clinton's Concessions
description: The problem with Bill Clinton's trip to Syria to seek an agreement about the Golan Heights is that he has persuaded himself that his cave-in last week to North Korea was "a very good deal indeed."

title: TV News Magazine Shows Are Crowding One Another
description: News magazine programs, once in such favor that a network news president predicted one could succeed during each hour of the prime-time schedule, have suddenly become the most depressed genre in television.

title: Newell Co.(NWL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Newell attributed the increases in sales, net income and earnings per share for the latest quarter and nine months to internal growth, and the recent acquisitions of Lee/Rowan, Goody Products, and Home Fashions Inc. The nine months' results were also aided by the acquisition of Levolor.

title: Hornets Hear Good News About Johnson
description: LARRY JOHNSON, who was expected to miss up to eight weeks with yet another injury, doesn't have a stress fracture in his foot after all and may be ready for the Charlotte Hornets' season opener Nov. 4 in Chicago.

title: OPERA
description: A Degree of Decrepitude Suitable for 'La Boheme' New York State Theater

title: Huge North Carolina Study Seeks Clues to Beach Erosion
description: WILLIAM A. BIRKEMEIER was on a concrete pier, leaning into a howling gale. The sky was dark gray, the air was raw and the sea was crashing into the pilings below in breakers more than six feet high.

title: A Push to Revamp Municipal Bonds
description: Sometime before this year ends, the Securities and Exchange Commission plans to enact new regulations to change the way bonds are traded in the municipal bond market, where the nation's cities and towns go to borrow money.

title: Sports of The Times; Brown Hopes To Wear Out Giant Fans
description: TWO guys ran into each other in the rain in Giants Stadium on Sunday. They stopped and looked at each other. "Hey, what are you doing here?" one asked. "No," said the other, "what are you doing here?"

title: Campaigning On Economy, Clinton Plays The Teacher
description: Having played to voters' emotions in a weekend of campaigning, President Clinton went for their minds today, giving a group of business people a long tutorial on the Democratic school of economic theory, complete with numbers and charts.

title: Is Heisman a Hurdle Too High for McNair?
description: Steve McNair, the sensational Alcorn State quarterback, faces mighty hurdles in his longshot bid to win the Heisman Trophy. He plays for a Division 1-AA team that was prohibited by the National Collegiate Athletic Association from playing in the Liberty Bowl. No Division I-AA player has won the award. Jerry Rice, who played for Mississippi Valley State, finished ninth. Walter Payton, playing for Jackson State, finished 14th.

title: Allegheny Ludlum Corp.(ALS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included one-time gain of 7 cents a share from settlement of lawsuit and higher value of investment in a limited partnership fund.c-Net income(Loss)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Unit Is Suing Interpublic on Hiring
description: WPP Group USA said yesterday that it had sued the Interpublic Group of Companies, accusing Interpublic of violating an agreement not to hire certain executives from two WPP agencies, J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather.

title: U.S. Weighs Sending Ambassador to Zaire, a Dictator's Fief
description: In a sign of support for a new Prime Minister's reform efforts in a country led by one of Africa's most corrupt and repressive governments, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott made a brief visit here today and said Washington was considering sending an ambassador to Zaire.

title: Cedras's New Palace: 2 Bedrooms, Personal Computer
description: For nearly three years, he ruled Haiti with an iron fist, terrorizing anyone who would defy his military rule. But today, officials say, Raoul Cedras sits in a rundown hotel room here writing his memoirs and worrying whether his children will be harassed at school because of who their father is.

title: Padres Are Cleared
description: Six months after two members of the San Diego Padres were arrested in New York for allegedly soliciting police officers posing as prostitutes, a criminal court judge has dismissed the charges.

title: Rochester Gas & Electric Corp.(RGS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time charge of $ 33.7 million, or 59 cents a share, for reduction of work force, in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included charge of $ 600,000, or 1 cent a share, for write-off of unrecoverable gas costs.c-Included one-time charge of $ 5.2 million, or 9 cents a share, for reduction of work force for both periods.

title: Toyota Has Decided to Set Age Limits On Its Managers
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation wants a more youthful look -- not for its cars but for itself. Japan's largest automobile company has decided to set age limits for managers of certain ranks.

title: Wolfgang Behl, Sculptor and Teacher, 76
description: Wolfgang Behl, a sculptor and teacher, died on Oct. 17 at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford, the city where he lived. He was 76.

title: NEW YORK UNIONS AND MAYOR AGREE ON 7,600 JOB CUTS
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the leaders of New York City's municipal labor unions reached agreement yesterday on a plan to cut 7,600 more jobs from the city's payroll by offering a second round of severance packages as an alternative to layoffs.

title: Ruptured Pipeline Spreading Hot Oil In Russia's Arctic
description: A ruptured pipeline in the Russian Arctic has spilled two million barrels of hot oil, soaking the fragile permafrost and posing potentially major environmental damage to the region, according to reports received by the Federal Department of Energy.

title: Raul Julia, Broadway and Hollywood Actor, Is Dead at 54
description: Raul Julia, an actor who distinguished himself in classics on Broadway and off and also became a success in Hollywood movies, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. He was 54 and lived in Manhattan.

title: From 'Courageous' to a 'Disappointment'
description: George E. Pataki

title: Baghdad's Burden -- A special report.; Iraq Is Near Economic Ruin But Hussein Appears Secure
description: Children lie on filthy hospital beds, murmuring in pain as they die of diarrhea and pneumonia. Some of the Arab world's finest artists peddle their work for as little as $12 a painting. A 50-year-old retired policeman, victim of a stroke a year ago, limps from merchant to merchant in a food market looking for what he can afford on a pension driven down by inflation to the equivalent of $2 a month, barely enough to buy one chicken.

title: At a Civil War Prison, A Salute to All P.O.W.'s
description: What was once a field rank with pools of fetid water and odors of gangrene and death now gently rolls with hillocks of fluffy broom sage and gold and purple asters. One hundred and thirty years ago, when it was encircled by stockade walls and strewn with sway-backed tents, the field was Andersonville, the infamous Confederate camp where 45,000 Union troops were imprisoned, and where 13,000 died.

title: Kirby Corp.(KEX,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included non-recurring charge of $ 662,000, or 2 cents a share, from discontinuance of foreign flag containership service.

title: Beckman Instruments Inc.(BEC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 4.8 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 7.1 million, or 17 cents a share, in the 9 months, both for the ongoing implementation of its reorganization plan. The 9 months also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 5,100,000, or 18 cents a share.c-After income from an accounting adjustment of $ 26,200,000, or 93 cents a share, and a charge of $ 30,200,000, or $ 1.07 a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Beard Accuses The Nets Of Quitting
description: Excruciating pain used to be found only in Kenny Anderson's left hamstring, Kevin Edwards's sore right Achilles' tendon or deep inside Chris Morris's bruised thigh.

title: Rio Journal; Crime Reigns in the City Renowned for Romance
description: Back in 1900, with bubonic plague and yellow fever ravaging this tropical seaport, Brazilians chose a hilly farm far from the city limits as the site for what became Latin America's most prestigious school of public health.

title: USX-Marathon Group (MRO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included gains on the disposal of assets, an unfavorable noncash inventory market valuation adjustment and employee-related expenses associated with Marathon's ongoing reorganization efforts, for a net after-tax gain of $ 48 million.c-Included a pretax gain of $ 173 million from disposal of assets, a net credit of $ 36 million from the settlement of state tax issues, a $ 158 million favorable noncash inventory market valuation credit and employee-related expenses associated with Marathon's ongoing reorganization efforts. The net effect of all items in the period was an after-tax gain of $ 204 million.d-Included an unfavorable inventory market valuation adjustment, a charge relating to an international production concession, and a credit related to two federal income tax adjustments, for a net after-tax charge of $ 4 million.e-Included a $ 54 million inventory market valuation charge, a charge relating to an international production concession, and a credit related to two federal income tax adjustments. The net effect of all items was an after-tax loss of $ 42 million. The period was also after a charge of $ 23 million, or 8 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Corrections
description: The chart atop the Business Digest on Monday misstated the major financial indicators for last week in some editions. The Dow Jones industrial average closed the week at 3,891.30, down 19.17 points; the dollar was last quoted at 97.22 yen to the dollar, down 0.88 yen; the crude oil contract for December delivery closed at $17.38 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, up 41 cents; the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond ended at 7.97 percent, up 14 basis points.

title: Nalco Chemical Co.(NLC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $ 35.5 million, or 46 cents a share, from the formation of Nalco/Exxon Energy Chemicals L.P., and adoption of of a worldwide consolidation plan. The periods also included a gain of 4 cents a share from the sale of the company's automotive paint spray booth business to PPG Industries.c-Included an extraordinary loss of $ 10.6 million from retirement of debt, and after a charge of $ 56.5 million from an adjustment in accounting. The share figures total 96 cents a share for the combined loss on debt retirement charge and accouting change.

title: Yield on the Long Bond Ends the Day Above 8%
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell in light trading yesterday, with the yield on the long bond ending at more than 8 percent after toying with that significant threshold for two weeks.

title: In Farm Country, an Animal Haven
description: GENE BAUSTON couldn't find the cows. It happens sometimes. "They were here," he said, peering at a pasture where tell-tale signs that big animals had visited were all over.

title: Deluxe Corp.(DLX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $ 10 million, due to restructuring costs being less than anticipated in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: The Jets' Other Johnson Will Finally Get the Ball
description: They are a who's who of runners: Ricky Watters, Eric Dickerson, Marshall Faulk and Johnny Johnson. Anthony Johnson has lost out to every one of them.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Thunderbolt
description: You can line up the political cliches on this one. Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario Cuomo's re-election campaign was: a stunning development, a bombshell announcement, a defining moment. Hard-line Republicans will also call it a betrayal, and by the measurement of lockstep party loyalty, it was.

title: Boy's Father Testifies in Kidnap Trial of Rabbi
description: The father of a Jewish teen-ager testified yesterday that an ultra-Orthodox rabbi who is charged with kidnapping the youth asked the father to write a phony letter after the boy disappeared, authorizing the rabbi to hide the boy from his mother.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARRY TUCKER, president of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, wanted to give silver castanets to RISE STEVENS, the mezzo-soprano, at the foundation's benefit concert on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.

description: Barry Diller, chairman and chief executive of QVC Inc., warned magazine executives today that they were becoming "victims of your own hype" in the rush to new electronic media.

title: Higher Rates Worldwide Seen by Fed
description: Federal Reserve officials, struggling to hold down long-term interest rates in the United States, are increasingly convinced that an unusual convergence of global trends may keep rates high around the world for the next several years.

description: IF YOU ASK ME By Libby Gelman-Waxner A Wyatt Book for St. Martin's Press. 236 pp. $20.95.

title: By Spurning G.O.P., Mayor Gambles His Future
description: To many Republicans across the state and the nation, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to cast aside his party's gubernatorial candidate, George E. Pataki, and endorse Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was an act of betrayal not likely to be forgotten soon.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a bombing that killed 50 people in Sri Lanka misspelled the surname of a political leader who was among the dead. He was Gamini Dissanayake.

title: Appointments By Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company announced several appointments yesterday in its information services division, which includes The New York Times News Service and Syndication Sales Corporation as well as Times On-Line Services and NYT Custom Publishing.

title: Tecumseh Products Co.(TECUB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included favorable tax adjustments of $ 2.8 million, or 13 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months.

title: Candidates Hedge Their Bets On an Immigration Measure
description: Amid signs that recent attacks by nationally prominent Republicans and Democrats may have slowed the momentum of a ballot initiative on illegal immigrants, candidates in California's much-watched gubernatorial and Senate races are backing and filling to adjust their handling of the issue.

title: McCall Accuses London of Roiling Racial Tensions in Campaign
description: H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for comptroller, and some of his Jewish supporters today accused his Republican opponent, Herbert London, of stoking tensions between blacks and Jews in order to win votes.

title: Plastic Pipe Makers Plan to Settle Lawsuit
description: Three companies that manufactured plastic plumbing used in about six million homes throughout the United States have agreed to pay at least $750 million to replace those pipes that have leaked since installations began in 1978.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO. (AXP,N)
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings from continuing operations rose 18 percent as consumers increased their travel and spending, but net earnings fell 12.1 percent.

title: Rwanda Refugee Crisis Is Threatening Gorillas In Neighboring Areas
description: RESEARCHERS who have just finished a survey of populations of large mammals in Central Africa say the numbers are encouraging. But they also report that Rwandan refugee camps threaten the longterm health of the region.

title: Company Reports: Market Place; USAir Posts Another Loss; Pilot Concessions Seem Key
description: USAir reported another money-losing quarter yesterday, the latest evidence of the airline's intractable financial problems, which are unlikely to be solved without concessions from its pilots.

title: Cardinal Health (CAH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings included preferred dividends of $ 500,000.

title: LOCKHEED AND MARTIN MARIETTA MERGER QUESTIONS
description: The Federal Trade Commission wants more information from the Lockheed Corporation and the Martin Marietta Corporation about the proposed $10 billion merger of the companies, Lockheed said yesterday. In a prepared statement, the company, based in Calabasas, Calif., said the request was expected. A spokeswoman for Martin Marietta, which is based in Bethesda, Md., said the companies still expected approval of the merger during the first quarter of 1995.

title: Chess
description: Using the language of chess to explain a divorce, Boris Spassky once described himself and his former wife as bishops of opposite color: pieces that travel along different-colored squares and thus never make contact. Lately, the same could be said of Gary Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov.

title: A Mortgage Penalty, or a Plus?
description: What sounds like a consumer-friendly provision -- the prohibition in many states of penalties for homeowners who pay off their mortgages early -- actually raises the cost of mortgages, experts in housing finance say. And that has the effect of forcing low-income home buyers to subsidize high-income home buyers, they add.

Genlyte Group Inc.(GLYT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
In New Jersey, Barbs and Theatrics
description: Even before the Rollerblading, hairy-legged guy in the duck suit appeared on the campaign trail, there was ample reason to believe that feathers would fly in the last few weeks of the United States Senate race between Frank R. Lautenberg and Chuck Haytaian.

title: TALKS FOR A RAILROAD'S SALE ARE ENDED
description: The Illinois Central Corporation and Kansas City Southern Industries Inc. said yesterday that they had ended talks for the sale of Kansas City Southern's railroad. Kansas City Southern also canceled plans to spin off its mutual funds and financial services businesses to shareholders. The companies said they had terminated a letter of intent signed on July 19 after failing to agree "on a number of issues." At the time, the stock-swap agreement was valued at about $1.63 billion. Shares of Illinois Central, which is based in Chicago, rose 87.5 cents, to $30.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Kansas City Southern fell 75 cents, to $33.75.

title: '40 Acres' Promise to Blacks Was Broken

title: Q&A
description: Backyard Mushrooms

title: Selecting Composers From 4 Different Worlds
description: The American Composers Orchestra's programs have made a virtue of eclecticism, avoiding at all costs any single-minded perspective on American music. Sunday's program at Carnegie Hall was almost unnervingly free-spirited: an orchestral etude by Fred Lerdahl, a pipa concerto by Bun-Ching Lam, Roger Sessions's fiercely complex Symphony No. 8 and a kitschily Romantic piano concerto by the forgotten turn-of-the-century composer Henry Holden Huss. These are works from quite separate musical worlds; few threads can be found among them. But not every program needs a theme.

title: DDB Needham Gets Bud Bowl Campaign
description: The seventh annual installment of the popular Bud Bowl Super Bowl advertising campaign, which Anheuser-Busch has been running since 1988, will be created by DDB Needham Chicago, the Bud Light agency, rather than D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, which handles the company's flagship Budweiser brand. Though billings were not disclosed, Adweek estimated them at $10 million.

description: To the Editor:

description: ANXIOUS to turn around the flagging fortunes of Ayer Inc., its four new top managers are remaking the venerable agency in several important ways.

description: If the polls are right, a mean-spirited, impractical and probably unconstitutional California ballot initiative is headed for easy victory Nov. 8.

description: Duke With the women taking the forefront, the Blue Devils have been the talk of college soccer for the last few days as a result of two monumental accomplishments.

title: New Food Plant Is Dedicated To Effort to Feed the Hungry
description: Faced with dwindling donations from the food industry and growing demand from poor people seeking free meals, a Texas food bank has built a food-dehydrating plant in Lubbock, Tex., strictly to process produce donated by local farmers to feed the hungry.

description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was not the first of a Democratic candidate by a Republican mayor of New York City. Mayor Fiorello H. LaGuardia

title: Student Slain At School In Mt. Vernon
description: A 17-year-old baseball star was stabbed to death in a crowded hallway at Mount Vernon High School this morning in the aftermath of a dispute that apparently involved two other students, the police said.

title: Latest Killing of a Sri Lanka Politician Fits a Familiar Pattern
description: Little more than a decade ago, Sri Lanka was a model of civic development in the third world, with a literate voting public and an impressive crop of potential political leaders drawn from a range of parties. Now most of those leaders are dead, victims of ethnic militancy or intense political rivalries that turned lethal in unsettled times.

title: Average Voter Doesn't Have Fax Machine; In Touch With Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: NEWS ANALYSIS Who Can Do the Most?; Mayor's Endorsement of Cuomo Reflects Political Interests and Financial Realities
description: In the end, his advisers said, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's decision to do what once might have seemed unthinkable came down to a simple calculation: that whatever damage he might do to his standing as a Republican, on balance his political, governmental and personal self-interests would best be served by having Mario M. Cuomo as Governor, and so he should do all he could to assure it.

title: NATURAL GAS CLEARINGHOUSE TO BUY TRIDENT NGL
description: Trident NGL Inc. has signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by the Natural Gas Clearinghouse in a transaction that would create a natural gas powerhouse with annual revenue of $3.4 billion. Shares of Trident rose 62.5 cents, to $10.625. Natural Gas Clearinghouse is a privately held partnership based in Houston and owned by a subsidiary of British Gas P.L.C., the Nova Corporation of Calgary, Alberta, and members of Natural Gas Clearinghouse's management. Under the definitive agreement, Trident, which is based in Woodlands, Tex., will pay $11.75 a share for up to 50 percent of its current outstanding common stock. In connection with that tender offer, British Gas and Nova will each indirectly contribute an additional $67.5 million in cash to the combined entity.

description: H. Carl McCall, the New York State Comptroller, accused his Republican opponent, Herbert London, of stoking tensions between blacks and Jews. Page B1.

description: Some call it glamour and some call it retro, but the word that really sums up the European spring shows is shape. Clothes followed the curves of the female body, accentuating the breasts, waist and hips.

description: When President Clinton visits President Assad of Syria in Damascus, I hope it is not one of those quick in-and-out trips. Mr. Clinton should stay a couple of days. There are a lot of interesting things to be seen in Syria, and fun to be had.

description: The USX-U.S. Steel Group, the nation's largest steelmaker, said late yesterday that third-quarter earnings more than tripled, reflecting strong steel demand.

Don't Put Allies at Risk

While not regulated by the 1972 treaty, defenses against such weapons are directly affected by it.

title: Flightless Insect Hints at Origins of Flight
description: PTEROSAURS, birds and bats took to the air from evolutionary runways that scientists believe they understand fairly well, but insects began flying so much longer ago that details of their stepwise conquest of flight remain obscure. Scientists at Pennsylvania State University hypothesize, however, that a present-day flightless insect called the stone-fly may be closely related to ancestral insects that first learned to fly more than 330 million years ago.

description: An 18-month-old girl was killed yesterday when a fire engulfed the top floor of her family's two-story row house in East New York, Brooklyn, trapping the infant and her brother, fire officials said.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
2 Big Tobacco Processors to Merge
description: Two of the largest tobacco processing companies have agreed to a merger that would form a $1.4-billion company.

title: GIULIANI, DEFYING HIS PARTY, BACKS CUOMO FOR 4TH TERM; SEES PATAKI AS BAD FOR CITY
description: In a dramatic break with the state's Republican Party, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday endorsed Mario M. Cuomo, a national symbol of the Democratic liberal tradition, for a fourth term as New York's Governor.

title: Strains in Belgrade: Army vs. Serbian President
description: President Slobodan Milosevic's decision to end his support for the Bosnian Serbs has created misgivings and splits in the Serbian-dominated Yugoslav Army, an institution already embittered by low pay and repeated changes of leadership.

title: Prof. Ray L. Birdwhistell, 76; Helped Decipher Body Language
description: Ray L. Birdwhistell, an anthropologist and expert on how people communicate with body motions, died on Wednesday at his home in Brigantine, N.J. He was 76.

title: A Feat Even Cy Young Would Applaud
description: It will be years before Greg Maddux will know whether he will ever get to grace the stage at Cooperstown and join the likes of Sandy Koufax, Jim Palmer, Whitey Ford, Tom Seaver, Bob Gibson and Steve Carlton. But Greg Maddux already knows that he has achieved something none of those Hall of Fame pitchers has.

title: U.S. Price-Fixing Trial of G.E. Opens Today
description: The General Electric Company's chairman, John F. Welch Jr., has put the Kidder Peabody & Company fiasco behind him with the proposed sale of the securities firm to the Paine Webber Group. But a problem potentially more damaging to G.E.'s reputation comes on stage Tuesday in Federal Court here.

title: Turmoil Grows Worse At Time Warner Music
description: The turmoil at Time Warner's music group grew worse today when the president of Warner Brothers Records, Lenny Waronker, said he would not succeed the group's highly regarded chairman, Mo Ostin, who will step down in January after 25 years.

title: Sears Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Sears Canada's stock ticker symbol is SCC and is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: No Fracture for Johnson
description: LARRY JOHNSON's left foot isn't broken after all. Instead of missing eight weeks because of a stress fracture, the Charlotte Hornets' forward could be in uniform for the season opener on Nov. 4 at Chicago.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GIULIANI, DEFYING PARTY, BACKS CUOMO

title: Judge Rejects Simpson Prosecutor's Bid to Dismiss Jury Pool
description: Four days after saying in a closed hearing that many if not most jury candidates in the O. J. Simpson case were lying to be selected and should be given polygraph tests, Marcia Clark, the chief prosecutor in the case, asked Judge Lance A. Ito today to dismiss at least the first pool of 77 prospective jurors, and possibly all 300 who have thus far completed questionnaires.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 EMBARGO SQUEEZES IRAQ Under the United Nations embargo, Iraq's prosperity has vanished. The recent movement of Iraqi troops toward the Kuwait border drew attention to the conditions, but it has not ended the embargo. A1

title: Bears Retire Numbers
description: DICK BUTKUS and GALE SAYERS will have their Chicago Bears' jersey numbers retired -- and no, they hadn't been so honored already.

title: 'Perfect Anti-Kennedy' Opposes the Senator
description: In the hush of his library at 7:30 A.M. on Wednesday, Mitt Romney was a formidable sight. His white shirt was immaculate, his gray and black pin-striped trousers were sharply creased, his black wingtips shined. The man who is giving Senator Edward M. Kennedy the toughest race of his 32-year political career had already jogged three and a half miles. And he was whistling.

title: Atlantic Southeast
description: Shares of Atlantic Southeast Airlines, a regional air carrier, dropped sharply yesterday. The company reported that earnings were flat in the third quarter, citing in part fare discounting.

title: A Stormy Voyage on OS/2 Warp
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation has historically displayed tenacious self-delusion in sticking with "technically superior" products long after the wider world has found them wanting. OS/2 Warp, the eighth edition of I.B.M.'s operating system (and therefore dubbed "version 3") is but the latest in a hapless line that includes Micro Channel Architecture hardware and the mercifully forgotten software called Topview.

title: Prewar Black Movies, Downside Up
description: They were called race movies. Between World Wars I and II, black producers, directors and actors turned out hundreds of films whose characters departed from the Hollywood stereotype of the shuffling, eyeball-rolling, comically cowardly black.

description: Accelerating a drive to pare down operations outside its consumer-products business, the Scott Paper Company announced plans yesterday to sell a power plant in Mobile, Ala., to a unit of the Southern Company for $350 million.

Earnings for the first nine months of 1994 have been reduced $ 1.24 a share as a result of the earthquake.

title: Stocks Fall As Rates Exceed 8%
description: The stock market faltered again yesterday as long-term interest rates punched past 8 percent, after flirting with that psychologically important level for three weeks.

title: Fire Seen as Vital for Nature, Igniting Ecological Debate
description: AT first glance, the scene might have seemed like a wildfire out of control. Orange flames, driven by a gusting wind, crackled across the prairie and charged into a stand of pine trees, sending a swirling cloud-castle of smoke billowing into the air. Black desolation remained where the fire had passed.

title: St. Paul Cos.(SPC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest periods included investment gains of $ 9,320,000, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 34,668,000, or 39 cents a share, in the 9 months, compared with investment gains of $ 6,415,000, or 7 cents a share, and $ 31,104,000, or 34 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.Year-ago periods were restated to give effect to 2-for-1 stock split June 6.

title: Piper Jaffray Is Planning $5 Million Fund Bailout
description: Piper Jaffray Inc., the brokerage firm that managed a number of mutual funds with sharp losses, said yesterday that it would infuse $5 million into one of those funds, American Adjustable Rate Term Trust -- 1995.

title: Is a Team of Clydesdales Next?; In Heady World of Microbreweries, Growth Is the Word
description: The New Haven Brewing Company's line of beers is about as local as it gets. Who is the guy on the label of Mr. Mike's Light Ale, grinning behind the bar with the big sloshing tankard of suds? It is Mike Gettings, the company president. The dignified face on the label of Blackwell Stout? Blackwell himself, the brew-house dog, who even contributed a paw print of approval.

title: 2 Reagan Officials Dispute Drug Claims Against North
description: Two senior officials in the Reagan Administration today defended Oliver L. North, the Republican candidate for Senate in Virginia, against assertions that he ignored information about drug activities by rebel forces in Nicaragua that were fighting the leftist Government that was in power there a decade ago.

title: N.H.L. Talks Held Quietly; Season Is Cut By 4 Games
description: On the same day the National Hockey League announced cancellation of four games from the 84-game schedule of each team, negotiators for the league and the union met secretly in Chicago and made no progress yesterday, leaving the expectation that more substantial cancellations are sure to follow.

title: Dominion Resources Inc.(D,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Alone in a Sea of Trouble; BOC Yacht-Race Rescue Came While the Boat Was Sinking
description: Rough seas had been slamming against the hull of Josh Hall's 60-foot sailboat for five straight days. An experienced ocean racer, Hall was familiar with the sounds and the feel of a turbulent sea, the slapping and banging of the waves, and the seismic motion that runs the length of the boat as it rides up the front side of a wave and falls off the back.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KEVIN COSTNER and his wife, CINDY, announced that they will divorce after 16 years of marriage, Reuters reported yesterday. The couple issued a statement that read, "We did not come to this decision easily and on behalf of our entire family we ask to be allowed the dignity of sorting through this most painful part of our lives in private."

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Israelis Look To Clinton Trip For Progress With Syrians
description: While their attention is focused mostly on the peace treaty that they will sign with Jordan on Wednesday, Israeli officials are already looking beyond that ceremony to the fate of their negotiations with Syria.

title: Alfred A. Giardino, 81, Ex-Chief of New York Board of Education
description: Alfred A. Giardino, a former president of the New York City Board of Education and chairman of the city's Board of Higher Education, died on Sunday while attending his 60th class reunion at Brooklyn College. He was 81 and lived in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Observer; The Anarchy Vogue
description: I'm against government. Used to be you couldn't do that. Be against government, I mean. It meant you were an anarchist. Like Sacco and Vanzetti. They were anarchists, weren't they? In those days anarchists got locked up, though I think Sacco and Vanzetti were hanged or went to the chair, which is neither here nor there, and I wish I hadn't brought it up.

title: State to Investigate E.M.S. Role in Death
description: The State Health Department said yesterday it is investigating whether an ambulance crew acted properly in not transporting a homeless man who later died on the sidewalk across from a hospital.

title: Panel Rules That Police File On Rowland Should Be Public
description: A police report about a domestic disturbance in April at the former home of John G. Rowland, the Republican candidate for governor, should be made public, a hearing officer for the state Freedom of Information Commission said today.

title: Intel and CNN Set New Computer Service
description: The Intel Corporation and CNN will announce a new service on Tuesday that will permit business personal computer users to view CNN or CNN Headline News broadcasts on their computer screens.

title: Harold Hill Smith, 84, Geneticist Whose Work Led to Cell Fusion
description: Dr. Harold Hill Smith, the geneticist whose research produced the first fusion of a cell from a human with one from a plant, died last Wednesday at a nursing home in State College, Pa. He was 84 and a resident of Shoreham, L.I.

title: DETROIT DIESEL TO BUY ITALIAN ENGINE MAKER
description: The Detroit Diesel Corporation said yesterday that it would buy an Italian diesel engine maker for $125 million. The company, VM Motori S.p.A., will be sold by Montagu Private Equity, an investment group that is part of the Hongkong & Shanghai Bank. The sale is expected to be completed next year. Detroit Diesel said VM was the only independent supplier of medium-duty diesel engines to the car industry.

title: The Dangerous Hits Just Keep on Coming
description: It was a rough Sunday for quarterbacks in the National Football League. Troy Aikman, Chris Miller and Vinny Testaverde were knocked out of games with concussions. Stan Humphries left late in the Chargers' 20-15 loss to Denver with a sprained ankle. And the Bengals lost starter David Klingler (sprained knee) and backup Don Hollas (shoulder injury).

title: Art Looted by Nazis Goes on Show in Paris, Seeking Its Owners
description: In the long history of victorious armies looting the artworks of occupied lands, nothing matches what Nazi Germany did to France between 1940 and 1944 -- nothing, that is, since Napoleon filled French museums and plazas with the finest treasures of nations that he had conquered.

title: By Design; Here's Looking at You, Coat
description: In leather, in organza, in taffeta and in gabardine, trench coats marched down the runways of Paris and Milan, Italy. Humphrey Bogart's favorite raincoat has been updated in new fabrics and pale colors, with a tightly belted waist and a short full skirt. These versions will be in American stores come spring, but there are plenty of stylish trenches for fall right now.

title: MINNESOTA MINING & MFG. CO. (MMM,N)
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 7.9 percent, on strong unit sales and increased productivity.

title: Many Voices of One Man In an Ethnic Urban Tour
description: "Some People," initially produced by Performance Space 122, has reopened, in a slightly revised form directed by Jo Bonney, at the Susan Stein Shiva Theater at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, East Village. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 13, 1993.

title: Dislocated Toe Puts Oakley in Quite a Bind

description: The Rev. Benjamin F. Chavis Jr., who was dismissed in August from his job as executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., has agreed to withdraw his suit against the civil rights organization for wrongful termination without receiving the substantial sum he had been seeking, according to a settlement made public today.

title: Chemicals Units Lift Oil Concerns
description: Exxon, Amoco and ARCO said yesterday that their earnings from operations rose in the third quarter because of a resurgence of their chemical businesses and higher prices for their crude oil.

title:
COLLEGE FOOTBALL;
Enough Vowels and Touchdowns for the Heisman
description: In a week that could see him run to the front of the Heisman Trophy race, Colorado's all-purpose tailback, Rashaan Salaam insisted today he doesn't want to win the Heisman because "the limelight will destroy you if you're not careful."

title: Temple Loses Davis
description: Temple halfback DANNY DAVIS will miss the rest of the season after breaking his right ankle in last weekend's 49-42 loss to Syracuse.

title: Space Studies Find Line Across Pacific Linked to Currents
description: OBSERVATIONS from space shuttles and other vehicles have shown a remarkable, clearly visible line that marches for hundreds of miles across the Pacific Ocean as if the waters were being divided.

title: Deaf to Estrogen's Call: A Man's Strange Story
description: HE was a towering young fellow, nearly 6 feet 8 inches, the sort of height that prompts strangers in elevators to ask, "Do you play basketball?" or "How's the weather up there?" But that wasn't the problem -- too tall is better than too short in this culture, right? And, yes, his feet and hands were unusually big; his size 18 shoes were beginning to pinch. But that wasn't what brought him to the doctor, either. No, it was his gait. His knock-knees were getting ever more knocked, the upper legs twisting inward so that his knees were too close together, his ankles too far apart, his feet splayed, his abnormal walk a growing embarrassment to him. So he consulted an orthopedic surgeon.

title: The Rivlin Memo and Fiscal Honesty
description: Newt Gingrich, the House Republican whip, raised political hypocrisy to new levels this weekend when, citing a leaked White House memo, he accused Democrats of threatening Social Security and Medicare. This from the author of a "Contract With America" -- which, by pledging to whack a trillion dollars out of the Federal budget, would virtually guarantee huge cuts in entitlements.

title: What That Survey Didn't Say
description: Last year on cable television, I saw a sex and hypocrisy double-header: "Peyton Place" followed by "Return to Peyton Place." The first movie begins with shots of the village churches, which do a brisk business on Sunday morning. Then it shows what the sanctimonious churchgoers do the rest of the week -- the drunken lout who rapes his stepdaughter; the unwed mother who invents a dead husband to legitimize her child; the self-deluding mother whose refusal to acknowledge incest in her family leads first to murder, then to suicide.

description: President Jean-Bertrand Aristide selected an American-educated commodities trader as Prime Minister today, political figures said. They saw the move as placing a strong supporter of the free market in a position to oversee the overhaul of the country's staggering economy.

As a result, Rockport is talking to several agencies about the creative portion of its global footwear account with billings estimated at $3 million to $4 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: New Kind of Memory Found to Preserve Moments of Emotion
description: DO you remember where you went on your first date? Or the most terrifying scene of the last movie that really frightened you? Or what you were doing when you heard the news that the space shuttle Challenger had blown up?

title: Harold H. Wein, 78, Economics Professor
description: Harold H. Wein, a retired professor of economics and business management, died on Oct. 13 at Michigan Capitol Medical Center in Lansing. He was 78 and lived in Okemos, Mich.

title: New York's Top Judge Plans Overhaul of the Juror System
description: In a major overhaul of New York's jury system, the state's top judge announced a package of revisions yesterday aimed at making jury service more bearable -- tours of duty would be shorter, deliberation rooms cleaner, clerks less snappish.

title: DANCE
description: Spirited Cast and Audience Revive the Swing Era Joyce Theater

title: Democrats Show Surprising Life in House Races
description: Even as the Democrats are bracing for devastating losses in the mid-term elections, they are fighting back with unexpected strength in the South, which was supposed to be the party's most vulnerable region.

title: Union Camp Corp.(UCC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of 10 cents a share to reflect the withdrawal from the retail paper bag business in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a gain of 30 cents a share on the sale of a minority interest in Bush Boake Allen, a 16 cents a share charge to write down certain nonstrategic assets and a $ 3,716,000 pretax charge from an accounting change.c-Included a 23 cents a share charge to reflect the increase in the corporate federal income tax rate in the quarter and 9 months.

title: The Latest Thing for Masses of Data, but Is It Going to Work?
description: THE CD-ROM market is exploding, although no one knows how big the blast is. Look at the advertisements in the newspaper and you will see that the little disks are beginning to rival programs supplied on floppies. The ads, or a visit to a retailer, also attest that a desktop computer without a CD-ROM drive and a sound card is getting to be a rarity. Our own local video-rental shop has recently started stocking compact disks.

title: Gasoline Trading Revised
description: The New York Mercantile Exchange said yesterday that it would raise the deposits required to buy or sell futures contracts on heating oil or unleaded gasoline as of the start of business today.

title: Fire Boxes to Be Removed Because of Budget Cuts
description: Fire Department officials said yesterday that budget cuts would force them to begin eliminating the red fire-alarm boxes that have stood sentinel on sidewalks throughout New York City for more than a century.

title:
Back to the Arms Race?;
Don't Imperil The Treaty
description: The Administration has changed "Star Wars" to theater missile defense. But this cosmetic make-over cannot hide President Clinton's continuation of a Reagan Administration program that overestimates the perfectibility of technology and underestimates the Russian threat. If realized, the President's plans would jeopardize the Antiballistic Missile Treaty and the entire arms control process.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about turmoil at Sony Pictures Entertainment misidentified the studio that produced the money-losing films "Little Nikita," "Old Gringo" and "Ishtar" in the 1980's when Jeff Sagansky worked as a top executive at Tristar Pictures. Columbia Pictures, not Tristar, produced them.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BARRY TUCKER, president of the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, wanted to give silver castanets to RISE STEVENS, the mezzo-soprano, at the foundation's benefit concert on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Players Sue to Raise N.B.A. Salary Cap
description: The National Basketball Association's already-tense labor problems worsened yesterday when two players sued the league in Federal Court, alleging that the league artificially reduced the salary cap for the upcoming season.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Oct. 15 about protests after the killing of a kidnapped Israeli soldier misidentified the kidnappers in some editions. They were Palestinian militants, not Israeli militants.

title: Region Briefs; L.I. Man Convicted Of Burying Baby Alive
description: A Hempstead man has been convicted of helping to bury alive the 2-day-old baby girl his wife said she conceived by a former boyfriend.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Benefits column on Sunday about a fund-raiser for the Hudson Riverkeeper Fund, to take place this evening at the Architects and Designers Building, 150 East 58th Street, misstated the time. The event starts at 6:30.

title: Shift at Top Of Computer Sciences
description: William R. Hoover, who built the Computer Sciences Corporation into one of the top computer service companies in the world, will announce his retirement as chairman and chief executive on Monday, the company said yesterday.

title: Forest Laboratories Inc.(FRX,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
International Specialty Products Inc.(ISP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge relating to the refinacing of the company's bank debt of $ 1,200,000, or 1 cent a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a tax provision of $ 2.9 million, or 3 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Shell Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net after-tax charges of $ 32 million in the quarter and $ 28 million in the 9 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Wrigley (Wm.) Jr.  Co.(WWY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax reduction of 3 cents a share for a contribution of appreciated securities to the company's charitable foundation in the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a nonrecurring gain of $ 24.8 million after taxes on property sold in Singapore.

title: Consolidated Edison Co. of New York (ED,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
QUAKER OATS CO. (OAT,N)
description: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that earnings fell 37.3 percent in the first quarter as a result of higher marketing expenses for Gatorade and other products.

title: Chicago Merc Plan Rejected
description: Chicago Mercantile Exchange members have rejected a proposal to merge the exchange's old guard and new stars.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS PUTS INSURANCE UNIT UP FOR SALE
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it intended to sell the long-term care insurance business of its Amex Life Assurance Company subsidiary. Amex Life, with $2 billion in assets at the end of 1993, is the country's top writer of long-term care insurance. Company officials could not be reached for comment. The move comes as American Express tries to shed businesses and focus on its financial service units. Amex Life, which employs about 400 people, said several insurers had inquired about buying the long-term care business.

title: Copper Near a 4-Year High; Lumber Is Off and Cotton Up
description: Copper reached its highest price in almost four years yesterday with rising world demand depleting supplies. Inventories have tumbled this year, the result of record consumption in the United States and of rising use in Europe and in growing economies of East Asia.

title: Genicom Corp.(GECM,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: In Moscow, Differences On Oil Spill
description: Russian officials today had differing and sometimes conflicting accounts of a major oil spill from a pipeline in the Russian Arctic republic of Komi, but they agreed that the main damage occurred more than a month ago, that a cleanup was under way, and that the spill was considerably smaller than American officials said on Monday.

title: Continental Air's Chief Steps Down
description: Continental Airlines said yesterday that its chief executive and vice chairman, Robert R. Ferguson, had resigned. The carrier also reported lower-than-expected earnings for the third quarter.

title: An Old Coach's New Offensive
description: Lou Saban's first job was to caddy for Al Capone's brother at the Acacia Country Club in Chicago every Tuesday afternoon. Ralph Capone tipped well, but he never spoke on the fairways and Saban and his brother always suspected that he carried a gun.

title: Dominion Textile reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 1.3 million.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Troubled N.Y.R.A. Hands Control to Noe
description: The New York Racing Association confirmed reports yesterday that it was naming Kenneth Noe Jr. as president and general manager.

title: World News Briefs; India Blocks Departure Of Kashmiri Mission
description: Three civilian leaders from Kashmir were forced today to cancel a visit to the United Nations and Washington to argue their case for political negotiations to end a secessionist war in Kashmir, after they were denied passports by India.

title: Devils' McNab Calls It a (Long) Career
description: After 48 years in hockey as a player, coach and administrator, the last 12 with the Devils, MAX McNAB retired from hockey yesterday. The 70-year-old McNab served the team as director of operations, general manager and executive vice president. As a player, McNab was the center for GORDIE HOWE and TED LINDSAY in helping Detroit capture the Stanley Cup in 1950.

title: In America; Throwing a Curve
description: In Montclair, N.J., where I grew up in the 1950's and 60's, there was an elderly woman named Mildred Maxwell who would greet the periodic outbursts of segregationists and other racial provocateurs with the angry and scornful comment, "There isn't a hell hot enough for that man and his ideas."

title: A Femme Fatale Who Lives Up To the Description
description: A hired assassin, an innocent fall guy and a husband and wife intent on killing each other made a sterling film noir spectacle out of "Red Rock West," John Dahl's recently released sleeper. Now Mr. Dahl, whose work will never again fall into the sleeper category, is back with "The Last Seduction," which makes his earlier miscreants look like a collection of cream puffs. "Red Rock West" was memorably smart and steely. But it's a walk in the park picking buttercups compared with this.

title: Benefit for British
description: The Hanover Band, a period-instrument ensemble from Britain, is to present a benefit concert on Tuesday at 7:30 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Roy Goodman is to conduct the 74-piece orchestra in performances of Beethoven's Third Symphony ("Eroica"), Weber's Clarinet Concerto No. 2 (with Colin Lawson, soloist) and Schumann's Fourth Symphony. The concert is to benefit the Royal Society for Nature Conservation. Tickets are $6 to $35. Information: (212) 247-7800.

title: Giuliani's Move Dismays Limbaugh
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo received a blistering review in one quarter today.

title: In Giuliani Strongholds, They'll Vote For Cuomo for Their Own Reasons
description: Crawford Avenue in Gravesend, like many streets in southwest Brooklyn, was a block of electoral granite for Rudolph W. Giuliani when he ran for Mayor last year. Support doesn't get much more solid, after all, than when you get 95 percent of the vote.

title: Cancer Care at H.M.O.'s: Do Limits Hurt?
description: AS more and more Americans get their medical care through health maintenance organizations, a debate has developed over the quality of care cancer patients may be receiving if they are H.M.O. members.

title: Excerpt From Debate By Kennedy And Romney
description: Following is an excerpt from the debate last night between Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, at Faneuil Hall in Boston, as transcribed by The New York Times.

title: As China Upgrades Its Nuclear Arsenal, It Debates Need for Guns vs. Butter
description: In the next few months, as American and Russian reconnaissance satellites watch, China's nuclear weapons agency will lower a hydrogen bomb into an 1,800-foot shaft beneath the Gobi Desert.

title: Williams Cos.(WMB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 23.4 million, or 22 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 51.7 million, or 49 cents a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months also included extraordinary loss of $ 11.1 million, or 11 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 11.1 million, or 11 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 29.5 million, or 30 cents a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months was also reduced by $ 15 million, or 15 cents a share, because of tax increase.Results in 1993 were restated to reflect the company's sale of its WillTell network services operations.

title: 15 More Arrested In Plane Ticket Scam
description: Heidi Travel Plus, a travel agency on Austin Street in the Forest Hills section of Queens, has gone out of business, but not before helping to book one final group tour.

title: A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; SCHOOLS
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

title: 2 Studies Find No Breast-Implant Tie to Connective-Tissue Illness
description: Two studies presented today found no association between silicone gel breast implants and connective-tissue disease, confirming earlier findings in smaller studies.

title: Emphesys Financial Group Inc.(EFG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included after-tax realized gain on investments of $ 400,000, or 3 cents a share.c-Included after-tax realized gains on investments of $ 400,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 800,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months was also after a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 2,800,000, or 17 cents a share.Year-ago results are on a pro-forma basis which reflects results as if company's December 1993 restructuring and initial public offering in the first quarter of 1994 had occurred Jan. 1, 1993. Without the pro forma adjustment, net income for the third quarter of 1993 was $ 23 million.

title: A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; Correction
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: No trifle, this truffle: ANDY BALDUCCI, president of the food shop in Manhattan bearing his family's name, did not hesitate an instant when he got a call from GIOVANNI BASILE, the principal officer of a truffle company in Italy, announcing a monumental find: a white truffle weighing 600 grams, or 1 pound 4 ounces.

title: Howard Quirk, 70, Executive Of Chubb Family Foundation
description: Howard Evans Quirk, a former executive officer of the Victoria Foundation of New Jersey, one of the country's oldest and largest community-oriented philanthropies, died on Sunday at his home in Montclair, N.J. He was 70.

title: Avon Products (AVP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss of $ 23,800,000, or 34 cents a share, which consisted of income from discontinued operations of $ 1.2 million and a loss on sale of discontinued operations of $ 25 million and a loss from an accounting adjustment of $ 45,200,000, or 63 cents a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 6,400,000, or 9 cents a share, in the quarter and a net loss of $ 4,000,000, or 6 cents a share, which consisted of income from discontinued operations of $ 6 million and a loss on sale of discontinued operations of $ 10 million. The 9 months also included a charge of $ 107,500,000, or $ 1.49 a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: Dentsply International Inc.(XRAY,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 75,000 in the quarter and $ 1,311,000, or 5 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 689,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,315,000, or 9 cents a share, in the 9 months.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 12,132,000, or 50 cents a share, included after-tax charges of $ 16.45 million, or 67 cents a share.Year-ago results are restated to conform to the 1994 presentation.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 WHITHER NUCLEAR CHINA? China is the third-largest nuclear power in terms of explosive strength, but without a visible enemy it is wrestling with choices about the future of and funding for its nuclear program. A10 CLINTON IN CAIRO President Clinton landed in Egypt as he began his Middle East tour by visiting the tomb of Anwar el-Sadat, the Egyptian leader killed by Muslim radicals. A8

title: Uncovered Short Sales Fell on Nasdaq for Month
description: Shorting is the flip side of buying a stock in the hope it will go up; a short-seller borrows shares, sells them and later buys them back to return to the original owner. If the share price has dropped in the meantime, the short-seller pockets the difference; but if the price rises, the short-seller loses money. Short-selling is also used for technical reasons or to hedge market positions.

title: New York Seeking To Retake Housing Fixed by Squatters
description: When Peter Spagnuolo first saw the building on East 13th Street that he now calls home it was little more than a roofless hulk -- burned by arsonists and stripped by vandals of its wiring, windows and bathroom and kitchen fixtures.

title: A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; POLICE
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

title: Real Estate
description: BEFORE there were superhighways, motorists traveling in or out of Philadelphia from the north used Route 1. On the way they passed a huge, red-brick Gothic building in Northeast Philadelphia, set amid large clusters of small houses. This was the Sears, Roebuck & Company warehouse and catalogue shipping center, which sent goods to mail-order shoppers from Maine to Virginia from the 1920's until 1990.

title: A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; CUNY
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

title: American General Corp.(AGC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge which reflects 1 percent corporate tax rate increase required by the Revenue Reconciliation Act of 1993 of $ 30,000,000, or 14 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 46,000,000, or 21 cents a share.Revenue represented revenues and deposits.

title: Debate on Race and I.Q. Recalls Past Prejudice; No Evolutionary Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: UConn Women's Player Quits After Arrest
description: A player on the Connecticut women's basketball team quit school yesterday, two days after she and a member of the men's team were arrested in an early morning shoving match on the Storrs campus.

title: Lawson Products Inc.(LAWS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 352,000, or 2 cents a share.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 14,075,473, or $ 1.04 a share, included gain of $ 740,000 related to the sale of a facility.

title: Spiegel Inc.(SPGLA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss, which was after a one-time net charge of $ 21.9 million, or 21 cents a share, for closing certain catalog distribution facilities, in the quarter and 9 months.(Loss)

title: Cone Over Key in Close Cy Young Contest
description: The battle for the Cy Young Award in the National League ended on Monday in a walkover for the unanimous choice, Greg Maddux. But it was a different story in the American League yesterday, where David Cone and Jimmy Key -- fire and ice, power and finesse -- waged a classic duel that resulted in one of the closest races in league history.

title: Giuliani and Cutbacks: How Much Will Voters Bear?
description: The sweeping new reductions in municipal government proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday were praised by fiscal monitors as another large step toward bringing the city's finances into structural balance. But the question that quickly emerged was, how long will such cutting remain politically sustainable?

title: A Nonexistent League Is Faced With a Real Delay
description: The president of the United States Soccer Federation said yesterday the anticipated spring 1995 start-up of a professional league is not definite.

title: Calculating Effects of a G.O.P. Congress: More Respect or More Deadlock?
description: Suppose the Republicans took over Congress. What difference would it make?

title: Clinton Arrives in Egypt on Mideast Tour
description: Determined to pursue what he called "new steps" toward peace in the Middle East, President Clinton touched down in the Egyptian capital early this morning, the first stop on a whirlwind trip that will take him to Israel and five Arab countries in four days.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Monday about President Clinton's campaign appearance in Seattle misspelled the surname of a Congressional candidate in some copies. She is Harriet Spanel.

title: Here's How 24 Plus 6 Can Equal 40 Million
description: PSSST. Listen up. Forget the elections. What I am about to tell you could mean a whole lot of bucks. Like maybe 40 million. You interested? O.K., here goes. Twenty-four. That's right, the number 24. Statistically speaking it has been hot, real hot.

title: Book Notes
description: A Hollywood Property Publishers may have their greedy episodes, but for big money and pirhanalike action nothing beats Hollywood when it smells a competitive movie on the horizon.

title: Ceremony Will Be Hot, Windy, and Made for TV
description: At 2:15 P.M. today, the desert showed what it can do to the best-laid plans of mice and advance men.

title: Market Place; Selloff in Outboard Marine Had a One-Day Head Start
description: Outboard Marine disappointed Wall Street yesterday. Well, most of Wall Street, because someone evidently had advance word and jumped ship early.

title: String Quartet Playing For AIDS Charities
description: As soon as the Tokyo Quartet finished celebrating its 20th anniversary in 1989, its players began laying plans for their 25th, this season. They immediately decided two things. One was that they would celebrate by playing complete Beethoven quartet cycles in several cities. The other was that the six-concert cycle in New York, which opens tomorrow evening at Carnegie Hall, should benefit a charitable cause.

title: A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; Transportation
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

title: Police Investigating Shooting By an Officer of Man in a Car
description: A police officer fatally shot a Brooklyn man in the passenger seat of a stopped car Monday, the police said, and investigators said yesterday that they were reviewing the incident.

title: Interface Inc.(IFSIA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
SCI Systems Inc.(SCIS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: SCI Systems said that the estimated effective income tax rate increased to 39 percent in the latest quarter, compared with 34 percent in year-ago period.

title: Harry Simmons, 51; Designed Housing For the Inner City
description: Harry Simmons Jr., the founder of Simmons Architects and an associate architect for the AT&T Building in Manhattan, died on Sunday in a plane crash in Massachusetts. He was 51 and lived in Park Slope, Brooklyn.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: BASEBALL Yomiuri Giants Take Lead in Japan Series Masahiro Kawai drove in the winning run with a sacrifice fly in the top of the 10th inning last night as the Yomiuri Giants edged the Seibu Lions, 2-1, and took a lead of two games to one in the four-of-seven-game Japan Series. Kawai hit the decisive fly with the bases loaded and one out before 31,000 at Seibu Stadium in Tokyo. The Pacific League champion Lions had 10 hits against four Giants pitchers. (AP)

title: Kubota Ends A High-Tech Business
description: Kubota Ltd., the Japanese tractor manufacturer that tried to become an electronics company by investing in American technology start-ups, gave up on much of its dream today.

title: Seaboard Corp.(SEB,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 10
Northern Telecom Ltd.(NT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a net gain of $ 98 million on the sale of businesses. The per-share amount was not provided.c-Net loss, and the 9 months included restructuring charges and other costs totaling $ 1.161 billion. The per-share amount was not provided.(Loss)Preferred-share dividends were $ 1 million in latest quarter, compared with $ 2 million in year-ago period, and $ 3 million in latest 9 months, against $ 5 million in year-ago period.

title: Kodak, With Net Off 31%, Sees Cutbacks
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, still struggling to cut its operating costs, reported a 31 percent decline in its third-quarter earnings yesterday and said more cutbacks were coming.

title: A Choice and an Echo
description: Just when the Democrats seemed to have something going with their attacks on the Republicans' "Contract With America," the Republicans have pounced on a counterweapon -- an internal Administration memo prepared by Budget Director Alice Rivlin. Titled "Big Choices," the memo is a list of largely unpopular options to hold the deficit in check and permit adequate financing of programs like the new national service corps, welfare reform and Head Start.

title: Breed Technologies Inc.(BDT,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company acquired Hamlin Inc. on Aug. 31, 1994, in an acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests. Accordingly, the financial statements for all periods presented prior to the acquisition have been restated to include the results of operations and financial position of Hamlin.

title: Sports of The Times; What to Do With Sudden Fortunes?
description: HIS timing was usually perfect on the ice. Bryan Trottier could swoop in behind a vulnerable opponent, plant a vicious elbow in his back and deliver a soft pass to Mike Bossy. Goal, Islanders.

title: PENNZOIL SELLS SULFUR UNIT TO FREEPORT-MCMORAN
description: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday it would take a $50 million charge in the third quarter after agreeing to sell most of its unprofitable sulfur operations to Freeport-McMoran Resource Partners L.P., a New Orleans sulfur producer. Under the agreement, Freeport-McMoran will pay Pennzoil quarterly payments for 20 years based on the prevailing price of sulfur. Pennzoil, based in Houston, said that at current sulfur prices, had the deal been in effect for all of 1994, it would have seen income of about $1.6 million, compared with the unit's expected loss of $14 million.

title: Enter The Dragon
description: When China takes over Hong Kong at midnight on June 30, 1997, its first official act will be to scrap our elected Legislative Council. This month Beijing announced the creation a "temporary" legislature to pass Hong Kong's laws after the changeover. This unelected body, with no fixed term of office, will undoubtedly rubber-stamp all laws the Communist leadership wants.

title: Mytishchi Journal; Why Vote for This Man? If He Loses, Jail Awaits
description: This is a measure of politics in the new Russia. There will be a special election here on Sunday to replace a member of Parliament gunned down outside his apartment house in late April, in a killing thought to be mob-related.

title: Births to Young Teen-Agers Decline, Agency Says
description: The rate of births to girls 15 to 17 years of age declined 2 percent in 1992 -- the first decline since 1986, according to data made public yesterday by the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: Boycott Urged On Talk Show Called Racist
description: A coalition of New Jersey ministers and civil-rights advocates yesterday urged sponsors to boycott a talk show on WABC-AM radio whose host, they maintained, regularly makes racist remarks. Their demands come as one advertiser, New Jersey Transit, said it was taking a second look at whether to advertise on the show.

title: Trojan Treasure Is Viewed
description: The Schliemann Treasure -- the hoard of ancient gold and silver discovered in the ruins of ancient Troy in the 1870's that has been hidden in Russia since the closing days of World War II -- has finally come to light, says a group of German museum officials who viewed the treasure yesterday at the Pushkin Museum in Moscow.

title: U.S. Surgical Corp.(USS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, which included $ 8 million of restructuring charges, in the quarter and 9 months.(Loss)

description: China's Nuclear Future

description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.
