Court Bars Return of Refugees to Cuba
description: Responding to a lawsuit that seeks political asylum for Cuban refugees held in detention camps, a Federal district judge here barred the Clinton Administration today from turning over to Havana a group of refugees detained at the United States naval base at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba.

title: Worley Restricted After Missing Game
description: Chicago running back TIM WORLEY, who missed a team flight to Detroit over the weekend and is said by the team to be tending to personal matters, was placed on the reserve nonfootball injury list yesterday. His spot was filled by receiver KENNY SHEDD, who had been on the Jets' practice squad.

title: Kennedy and Romney Meet, And the Rancor Flows Freely
description: In a vivid piece of political theater, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts attacked his Republican challenger, Mitt Romney, tonight for his views on abortion, health care and Social Security.

title: Chevron Corp.(CHV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included benefit from IRS settlement, as well as charges from environmental remediation provisions. The net effect of these special items was a benefit of $ 18 million. (Operating income, excluding these special items, was about 63 cents a share.) for the quarter and the 9 months reflects $ 23 million of special charges.c-Included special items, which reduced net income by $ 145 million. (Operating income, excluding these special items, was 87 cents a share.) for the quarter and the 9 months reflects $ 662 million of special charges.The company said all share earnings and shares outstanding amounts for 1993 have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1994.

title: Student Accused in Stabbing Says He Acted in Self-Defense
description: A lawyer for the 17-year-old student charged with fatally stabbing another student at Mount Vernon High School on Monday said today that his client had acted in self-defense after being attacked by the victim and several other students in a hallway.

title: Empire District Electric Co.  (EDE,N) reports earnings for 12mo to Sept 30
Swordfish the Sicilian Way
description: SPAGHETTI with swordfish is a classic Sicilian dish. Here, some liberties have been taken. The anchovies have been replaced by olive paste because there were no anchovies in the house, and yellow pepper was added to give body to the sauce when the amount of oil in the traditional recipe was reduced.

title: Torre to Stay On as Cardinals' Manager
description: JOE TORRE survived a front-office shake-up with the St. Louis Cardinals yesterday, getting another season to prove himself as manager under the team's new general manager, WALT JOCKETTY, who was hired on Oct. 14.

title: GOODYEAR TIRE & RUBBER CO. (GT,N)
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, benefiting from the continuing boom in American auto production and higher international sales, said that the company's earnings rose 11.1 percent in the third quarter.

title: Regulators And Lilly In Accord
description: Bowing to the Federal Trade Commission, Eli Lilly & Company agreed yesterday to accept restrictions on operating the giant PCS Health Systems drug marketing unit, which Lilly plans to buy from the McKesson Corporation in a $4 billion deal.

title: Japan Hints at Conditions on Aid for North Korea Atom Plants
description: Japan's Finance Minister hinted today that Tokyo might make its pledge to help pay for modern nuclear reactors in North Korea contingent on contributions by European countries.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Mayor Giuliani proposed a second round of budget cuts that would squeeze almost every government service in New York City. A1.

title: Study of Yo-Yo Dieting Is Faulted
description: A REPORT last week by the National Institutes of Health said there were no negative health consequences from repeatedly gaining and losing weight, so-called yo-yo dieting.

title: Saatchi Shifts Texaco And Star to Bates
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company P.L.C. said yesterday that it had transferred the account of Texaco Inc. and Star Enterprises, a refining and marketing company co-owned by Texaco and Saudi Refining Inc., from Campbell Mithun Esty to another Saatchi agency, Bates Worldwide. The transfer, which was expected, sends to Bates what had been Campbell Mithun's largest account, with estimated United States billings of $60 million to $80 million.

title: Johnson Controls Inc.(JCI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 122,000,000, or $ 2.99 a share, from an accounting adjustment.

title: GREAT COOKS: Jean-Jacques Rachou; A Quiet Chef Is Mentor to A Generation
description: THE stocky, smiling man who answered the door of his midtown apartment wearing a T-shirt, tan pants and jogging shoes was hardly recognizable as Jean-Jacques Rachou, the punctilious, taciturn owner and chef of La Cote Basque, Manhattan's palatial homage to classic French cuisine.

title: Off the Menu
description: Restaurant Passes Hurdle

title: Foreman Eats, And Speaks
description: George Foreman, a Wendy's burger in front of him, was speaking yesterday on the telephone from Houston. "I got to keep up my strength," said the 45-year-old, who will fight Michael Moorer for the heavyweight title Nov. 5 in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Arboreal Armories; A Bush Grows in Brooklyn, Concealing the Weapons of Youth Outside Family Court
description: It is not your standard weapons locker. It is, in fact, a bush, and it stands outside Kings County Family Court in Brooklyn. But weapons are what often hang in its dense array of branches -- knives, Kung Fu stars and razors.

title: Magnetek Inc.(MAG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income of $ 3.1 million, or 12 cents a share, from disocntinued operations.c-Included loss of $ 161,000 from discontinued operations.

title: GIULIANI PROPOSES $800 MILLION MORE IN SPENDING CUTS
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed a second round of budget cuts that would squeeze almost every government service in New York City, from schools to hospitals to prisons, from recycling to bridge painting to food programs for the poor.

title: Hollywood Dreams Lure 3 Baby Bells to Ovitz
description: The Creative Artists Agency is expected to join with three regional Bell companies as early as next week in forming a potentially controversial venture to offer video entertainment programming for telephone customers on the East and West Coasts, movie-industry executives said today.

title: Germans See Growth; Markets Drop Anyway
description: Reporting that the German economy was driving itself out of deep recession, a group of leading economic research institutes significantly increased projections today for economic growth this year and predicted that the output of Europe's largest economy would rise further in 1995.

title: Wine Talk
description: IN 1966, when Leon Adams first visited the Yakima Valley in Washington State, he was amazed to find pedigreed grapes like cabernet sauvignon being blended with nondescript concords to make cheap jug wines. Mr. Adams, who wrote "The Wines of America," the first serious chronicle of this country's wine history, convinced some of the growers that they might make some good wines if they brought someone from California to show them how.

title: SCEcorp (SCE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings included charge of 13 cents a share in the third quarter and 17 cents a share in the nine months, for a nonrecurring charge to Mission Cos.

title: Companies Cited in Payoffs For Co-op Work Are Named
description: After months of waiting, owners of hundreds of Manhattan apartments now stand to learn who paid off the managers of their buildings to gain lucrative plumbing, renovation and hardware supply contracts.

title: Franco Is Seeking a Top-of-the-Line Pact
description: John Franco's agent, Dennis Gilbert, has begun conversations with the Mets' general manager, Joe McIlvaine, about signing Franco to a new contract that the Franco camp hopes will make him the highest-paid reliever in the game.

title: Less Demand For New Bills At Auction
description: Prices of Government securities were little changed yesterday after a mildly disappointing auction of two-year notes. Retail demand was significantly lower than in recent two-year sales, traders said, disappointing many market participants who had thought the sale would be more popular.

title: Personal Health; Postpartum depression: shedding light on the blues.
description: DIANA (who asked that her last name be withheld to protect her privacy) had a high-level position at a leading university in New York when she gave birth to her first child. The last thing she expected was the debilitating depression that overcame her in the weeks and months after her son's birth.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was trip back in time for ROSEMARY LEARY, a former wife of Timothy Leary, the psychedelic drug guru, when she went to the preview of an auction of 74 letters she had written to him. They were all written in 1970, while he was in prison in San Luis Obispo, Calif., for possession of marijuana.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review on Thursday about a performance of Hubbard Street Dance Chicago at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday misidentified a leading dancer in "Mae." She was Laura Elena Haney, not Christine Carrillo.

title: Tribe Donates $10 Million
description: The Mashantucket Pequots, a Connecticut Indian tribe whose primary source of income is a casino near Ledyard, Conn., has contributed $10 million to the fund-raising campaign for the National Museum of the American Indian.

title: WHX Corp.(WHX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 9,984,000, or 35 cents a share, from an adjustsment in accounting.

title: In a Mixed Session, Dow Drops 4.71
description: The stock market closed mixed yesterday as a key sale of Treasury securities indicated that short-term interest rates were headed higher.

title: RJR Nabisco's Earnings Climb Sharply
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported sharply higher third-quarter earnings and strong operating gains in its food and tobacco businesses yesterday, rebounding from the cigarette price-cutting war initiated by its major competitor, the Philip Morris Companies, in 1993.

title: Experts Call for Easing Plague Precautions on Travel From India
description: A team of specialists from the World Health Organization who investigated the recent outbreak of pneumonic plague in India called today for a relaxation in international restrictions on travelers from India.

title: Noranda Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)Year-ago 9 months' results included a loss of $ 66 million from the sale of an interest in Macmillan Bloedel Ltd.The company's stock ticker symbol is NOR and is traded on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cadbury Seeks Control of Dr Pepper
description: Like an eager suitor pursuing a reluctant maiden, Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. announced yesterday that it had intensified its courtship of Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies.

title: Glenn Gets Role on Kickoff Returns
description: When the record is 4-3, when a victory is this much away from a loss, little things mean a lot. And so the Jets, still trying to put together a perfect package, or at least one with a minimum of loose ends, continue to fine tune and fiddle this week as they prepare to play the Colts in Indianapolis.

title: MGM Grand Inc.(MGG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss(Loss)

title: Once-Promising Hungary Struggles With Economic Slump
description: Hungary, once viewed as Eastern Europe's beacon of economic hope, is facing a slump unknown since the country started on its journey toward capitalism.

title: Public & Private; The Out-Of-Work Wife
description: It so happened that in the hours before Lady Diana Spencer was to become the Princess of Wales in 1981, I was working on a story on Eighth Avenue, hanging out with a group of prostitutes. At daybreak I intended to go home and watch the royal wedding, my companions to get some sleep. But before we parted they gave an unforgettable valediction to the bride. "She's got the richest john in the world," one of the women said.

title: York Intl.(YRK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss, which was after a charge of $ 70.3 million, or $ 1.87 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Mr. London, In Deep Mud
description: Even in the tense final weeks of an election campaign, it is not too much to ask that candidates and their supporters observe at least minimum standards of fair play. Herb London, the Republican candidate for New York State comptroller, sinks beneath that minimum with a new television commercial that continues his campaign's effort to portray H. Carl McCall as anti-Semitic.

title: Student Raped in Brooklyn
description: A 15-year-old student at Bishop Ford High School in Brooklyn was sexually assaulted yesterday by a stranger in the school bathroom, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the flooding in Texas referred incorrectly in some editions to the reopening of the Houston Ship Channel. It occurred on Sunday evening, not on Monday.

title: Kinder, Gentler But Still Indelicate
description: Looking back, it was an awful moment in the glorious history of the Giants.

title: DOLE TO BUY REST OF CASTLE & COOKE FOR HIGHER OFFER
description: The Dole Food Company said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to buy the 17.2 percent of common stock of Castle & Cooke Homes Inc. it does not already own for $15.75 a share in cash, or about $81 million. The price is 13 percent higher than the $14 a share, or $72 million, Dole offered in August for Castle & Cooke, a home builder. Castle & Cooke shares rose 75 cents, to $15.25, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. David H. Murdock is chairman and chief executive of both Castle & Cooke and Dole, in which he has a 23 percent stake.

title: Blazers' Robinson Calls Off His Holdout
description: CLIFFORD ROBINSON rejoined the Portland Trail Blazers yesterday and said his 11-day holdout was worth it, even though he didn't get the contract extension he wanted.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page last Wednesday about a review of advertising agencies by the Coleman Company misstated the location of the Rojek Marketing Group, which is managing the review. It is in Cleveland, not Cincinnati.

title: How Elvis Became Elvis: A Legend's Early Years
description: LAST TRAIN TO MEMPHIS The Rise of Elvis Presley By Peter Guralnick 560 pages. Little, Brown. $24.95.

title: Debate on Race and I.Q. Recalls Past Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Myron S. Malkin Is Dead at 70; Designed Space Shuttle Program
description: Dr. Myron S. Malkin, a physicist who was the first director of the space shuttle program and a former Defense Department official, died on Monday at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 70 and lived in Bethesda.

title: TELE-COMMUNICATIONS IN DEAL FOR 100% OF HERITAGE
description: Tele-Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would pay the Comcast Corporation $290.3 million in stock for the 19.9 percent stake in Heritage Communications, a cable television operator, Tele-Communications does not already own. "T.C.I. and Comcast have both benefited from our joint ownership in Heritage, dating back to 1988, and we are pleased to consolidate the remaining ownership interest in these properties," said John C. Malone, the chief executive and president of Tele-Communications. The acquisition, subject to regulatory approval and the approval of Tele-Communications' board, is expected to close early next year.

title: Clark Equipment Co. (CKL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 34,159,000, or $ 1.96 a share.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 6,886,000, or 40 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9,261,000, or 53 cents a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 6,150,000, or 35 cents a share.Year-ago results are restated.

title: No Headline
description: "It would be a wrecking ball, not renovation crews that the city would be bringing here if it were not for us. You can't neglect buildings the way these were and expect to come back years later and to turn them into housing again." SAM SMITH, a New York City squatter. [ B3:2. ]

title: Transcript at Rabbi's Trial Is Interpreted in Two Ways
description: An ultra-Orthodox rabbi accused of having kidnapped a Jewish teen-ager said he would pay $10,000 for the youth's mother to give up custody of the boy, according to a secretly recorded conversation presented as evidence at his trial.

title: Foundation Health Corp.(FH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The decrease in revenues from the first quarter of fiscal 1994 was due to the expiration of the large California/Hawaii CHAMPUS Reform Initiative contract on Jan. 31, 1994.

title: Commission Supports New Reform
description: Fearing a loss in the momentum of the college sports reform movement it has spearheaded, a private commission asserted today that higher academic standards for student-athletes have been successful and stressed its continued support for further measures scheduled to go into effect next year.

description: Share earnings and shares oustanding are fully diluted.

description: A transcript of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's statement endorsing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was incomplete yesterday. Following is the passage that was omitted at the end of the Mayor's statement.

description: With three members of their starting five having spent more time in the training room than on the practice floor, the Nets are beginning to rely more and more on the All-Star forward Derrick Coleman for points, rebounds and posturing.

description: Jiri Kylian was not one of the founders of Netherlands Dance Theater, but as artistic director he has continued and enriched its mission as a creative organization.

A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; Social Services
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

description: The Justice Department has requested records from Novell Inc. as part of an antitrust review of the proposed merger of the Microsoft Corporation and Intuit Inc., the producer of the Quicken personal finance software.

title: The Stars Are Returning, But It Will Be for Charity
description: The owners won't let them play on their ice, so National Hockey League players will take their sticks and pucks and play on somebody else's ice.

title: Graham Symposium This Week in Michigan
description: A four-day symposium on Martha Graham is to be held this week at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Called "In the American Grain: The Martha Graham Centenary Festival," and presented by the University Musical Society, the event tomorrow through Sunday is to examine the choreographer's career and collaborations. It is to feature exhibitions, seminars, films, symphony concerts and dance performances.

description: b-Included a gain of $ 12,124,000 for a damage award payment received from Nintendo of America Inc.c-Net lossShare earnings included preferred stock dividends in arrears of $ 781,000 in both the latest and year-ago quarters and $ 2,345,000 in both the latest and year-ago 9 months.(Loss)

title: A Mall Comes to a Black Township
description: Late last year, a group of white executives from Sanlam Properties, a leading South African development company, piled into a mini-van and rode into terra incognita, the sprawling black metropolis of Soweto.

title: SATURN WORKERS MAY APPLY FOR OTHER G.M. JOBS
description: The Saturn Corporation has agreed to let United Auto Workers-covered employees apply for jobs in other factories run by the General Motors Corporation, a break from its innovative labor agreement that emphasized Saturn's independence from G.M., The Detroit Free Press reported yesterday. In earlier years, workers were required to quit G.M. before getting jobs at Saturn. But recently Saturn's role has been diluted by G.M.'s decision to fold Saturn into a new companywide Small Car Group, by negotiations to build and sell an American version of the European Opel through Saturn dealerships and by a vote by Saturn workers to end weekly team meetings, the paper said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the Giuliani Administration's agreement with city unions on job cuts misstated the meeting place and omitted the identity of one participant. The site was outside the office of Local 375 of the Technical Guild, not at City Hall; the man second from the right was Lewis G. Albano, president of the local.

title: DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO. (DWD,N)
description: Dean Witter, Discover & Company said yesterday that third-quarter earnings rose 7.5 percent as profits from its brokerage and credit-card businesses increased.

title: On Pro Football; What's Stirring in the Lions' Den?
description: Before the 1992 season, the Detroit Lions sought Pat Swilling with vigor. They offered him huge dollars, nearly $2 million a year, but in reality, they had no chance. The New Orleans Saints simply matched the offer and Swilling, as a restricted free agent, was forced to remain a Saint.

title: New Jerseyans Learned the Hard Way About Cutting Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Necessary Budget Pain
description: Confronting a real budget crisis, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has offered a new plan for more spending cuts. The supposedly balanced budget that the New York City Council adopted barely four months ago has already developed a huge gap -- $1.1 billion according to Mr. Giuliani, and possibly even more. The Mayor has made impressive headway in reducing the city payroll and negotiating better contracts with city unions. But it is time now to squeeze harder.

title: Watergate Redux as Robb Hits Back
description: As if the poor voters of Virginia did not have enough scandals to sort through, what with Iran-contra, extramarital rub-downs and cocaine at parties, Charles S. Robb has offered up another one: Watergate.

title: Labor Costs Up Slightly
description: Labor costs showed a small increase in the third quarter, the Government said today in a report that provided little evidence of accelerating inflation.

title: Food Notes
description: Merchants' Halloween

title: In Brighton Beach, the Good Life Has a Russian Accent
description: They serve lobster in a way that Rasputin, the Russian mystic who died in 1916, probably never imagined: as a salad tossed with fennel and honeydew melon.

title: Debate on Race and I.Q. Recalls Past Prejudice; Social Science Remedy
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the plan to eliminate 7,600 New York municipal jobs referred incompletely to the employees exempted from a special severance offer. Along with teachers, the offer excluded police officers, firefighters and other uniformed officers.

title: CDI Corp.(CDI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: CDI Corp. said its technical services operations, which account for 85 percent of consolidated revenues, benefitted from the growth in outsourcing in the 1994 third quarter.

title: For Key, 17 Victories Are Merely 17 Victories
description: He pitched the Yankees to a big lead in the American League East, and he led the majors with 17 victories, but when it came time to memorialize a shattered season, Jimmy Key was left without so much as an asterisk yesterday.

title: Endorsement? Pataki Seeks Other Topics
description: Campaigning in the heart of Giuliani country, State Senator George E. Pataki worked hard yesterday to change the subject from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's newest strength -- his endorsement by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- to one of his oldest vulnerabilities -- his passionate opposition to the death penalty.

title: Warning To Rookies: Don't Dare Cross Line
description: Veteran major league baseball players have a message for young, or financially unstable, or nonroster type players who might consider serving as strikebreakers next spring. And their message is this: Do it, and you will pay.

title: In New Jersey, the Candidates Make a Radio Show the Issue
description: Trading accusations and insults about who is a hypocrite and who is out of touch, about who is a big spender and who is a racist, the two candidates for United States Senate tangled tonight in a sharp-edged televised debate here.

title: Little Country School Copes With Change
description: The Cabot School does not look like much. The ventilation system doesn't ventilate. The furniture is frayed. Every week, the custodian makes a trip behind the white clapboard school to make sure the septic tank is working.

title: New Jerseyans Learned the Hard Way About Cutting Taxes; A Levy on Vacant Lots
description: To the Editor:

description: Business Technology

title: Class Notes
description: Craig Leonard has seen the future of higher education, and it looks like a computer-generated, lemon-colored Life Saver in a hula skirt dancing under a spotlight to tropical bongos.

title: Officer Held for Larceny
description: A 12-year police veteran was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn and charged with petty larceny and misconduct when he took $700 that had been placed in a car a test by the police department's Internal Affairs unit. Officer Michael Wittich, 37, assigned to the 67th Precinct in East Flatbush, was taken into custody after he took the so-called "bait money" while on patrol, said Sgt. John McCluskey, a police spokesman. The sergeant said that such integrity tests are becoming common. Officer Wittich was suspended without pay.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: NOTHING unusual here: a young mother with a child in one arm and a collapsed stroller in the other descending the stairs of an Upper East Side town house.

title: Protective Life Corp.(PL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' per share earnings were reduced by a one-time income tax expense adjustment of 9 cents a share, relating to the increase in the federal corporate tax rate to 35 percent from 34 percent.

title: Texaco Inc.(TX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $ 87 million, or 34 cents a share, on disposal of operations.c-After loss from discontinued operations of $ 175 million, or 68 cents a share, which included an $ 11 million loss on operations, and a $ 164 million loss on disposal of operations, in the quarter; the 9 months was after loss from discontinued operations of $ 181 million, or 70 cents a share, which included a $ 17 million loss on operations, and a $ 164 million loss on disposal of operations.The latest quarter and 9 months included a $ 20 million special charge by an insurance unit related to the property damage from the fire at the Pembroke refinery, as well as a special gain of $ 23 million from the sale of an interest in a downstream joint venture in Sweden. The quarter also included $ 8 million in tax benefits on an asset sale. Before items, net income in the quarter was $ 270 million.The latest 9 months also included a $ 119 million charge on staff reductions and write-downs of certain assets being offered in the program to consolidate activities and sell non-core assets, and $ 87 million in tax benefits on an asset sale. Before items, net income from continuing operations was $ 627 million.The year-ago periods included a $ 235 million special charge related to staff reductions, write-downs of assets and provisions for financial reserves, partially offset by $ 152 million in net deferred tax benefits, principally arising from reduced tax rates in the United Kingdom. The year-ago period also included a gain of $ 145 million on tax benefits from an asset sale. Before items, net income from continuing operations was $ 255 million for the quarter and $ 848 million for the 9 months.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's statement endorsing Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was incomplete yesterday. The omitted passage appears today on page B6.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ENVIROTEST SYSTEMS CORP., Phoenix, a vehicle emissions testing company, said the State of Ohio had approved two 10-year contracts expected to be worth about $157 million. HUGHES AIRCRAFT CO., Los Angeles, said its radar system unit had won a $152 million contract from the McDonnell Douglas Corp., St. Louis, to upgrade the APG-63 radar for the F-15.

title: Cygne Designs
description: The New York Times Shares of Cygne Designs, a New York designer of women's clothing, hit a 52-week low yesterday in Nasdaq trading before recovering. After the market closed on Monday, the company said that it would report lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football National Football League

title: In a Bar, the Patrons Watch the Sport of Boston Politics
description: In the name of good conversation, the television at Doyle's bar and restaurant is almost never turned on. The exceptions have been Presidential inaugurations, the World Series (without the sound), the Challenger shuttle explosion, the assassination of John F. Kennedy -- and, tonight, the debate between Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Mitt Romney.

title: Ingersoll-Rand Co. (IR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 21,000,000, or 20 cents a share, which represented cumulative effect of accounting changes for postretirement benefits.

title: Free of Abuse Charge, Principal Returns
description: Frank Catrambone said he was neither angry nor bitter, only relieved to be back at work 13 months after being accused of molesting two young girls. But when he returned as principal to his brown brick school today, the only child he let himself hug was the son of a cousin.

title: OFF THE PODIUM WITH: Rachael Worby; In Private Life, She's a First Lady
description: BY the light of a full moon, Rachael Worby is flying over the mountains and villages of West Virginia from one life to another. It is nearly midnight, and she is traveling with her husband in his sleek state-owned plane. She is still dressed in her sweat-drenched work clothes, the baggy black wool pants suit that she wore earlier in the evening to conduct the Wheeling Symphony Orchestra. Now, she is en route to Charleston, where she lives in a palatial red brick house with a brass plaque on the front door that reads "Governor's Mansion."

title: Consolidated Freightways Inc.(CNF,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary write off of intrastate operating rights of $ 5,522,000, or 15 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Ex-Foes on Common Ground
description: They are polar opposites on many issues, but Mayor Giuliani and Governor Cuomo share many common, formative traits. Page B6.

title: Candidates Continue Angry Tone
description: In their fifth debate, H. Carl McCall and Herb London kept up the already angry tone of their battle for the state comptroller's job, trading insults and mocking each other's platforms.

title: A Passive Faust Goes To the Devil Slowly
description: Marionettes, dolls and pieces of clay have never seemed as sinister and surreal as they do in the films of the brilliant Czech animator Jan Svankmajer. His shorts, many evoking Poe or Kafka, bring the menace of the subconscious to life, and his extraordinary feature "Alice" depicts an eerie wonderland darker than any Lewis Carroll dared. His new feature, "Faust," combines his usual mix of animated elements with a great deal of live action to tell an updated version of the old devilish story; the result will probably be more intriguing to Svankmajer cultists than to newcomers.

title: Executive Changes
description: AMSCO INTERNATIONAL INC., Pittsburgh, appointed Daniel P. Barry president and chief executive and Frank DeFazio chairman. INTERSTATE/JOHNSON LANE, Charlotte, N.C., named James H. Morgan, its president and chief operating officer, to be its chief executive.

title: If You're a Victim, Could That Be Your Own Fault?
description: The camera's affection for victims has been evidenced on every sort of show over the years, from made-for-television hankie soakers to talk fests featuring dysfunctionals. The reiterated message is that everybody is hurting and needs help. Viewers have learned that someone or something else is to be blamed for any action, however revolting, and experts have come through with fancily named traumas to suit the case at hand, be it murder or addiction or just plain nastiness.

title: Bryn Terfel in an All-German Recital
description: The Welsh bass-baritone Bryn Terfel rode into New York on a wave of publicity based largely on advance word from Europe, where he has been patiently building his career for the last four years, and from the Santa Fe Opera and the Ravinia Festival, where he made his first American appearances. He arrived with a double stamp of approval from James Levine, who brought the 28-year-old singer to the Metropolitan Opera for his debut as Figaro last week and was the accompanist for his first New York recital on Monday evening at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Eastman Chemical Co.  (EMN,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results are pro forma as if the spin-off from Eastman Kodak Co. had occurred at the beginning of 1993. Eastman Chemical became an independent company Dec. 31, 1993.

The 9 months also included a charge for change in method of accounting for certain postemployment benefits of $ 14,600,000, or 15 cents a share.The 1993 third quarter tax rate benefited from a reduction in the 9-month effective tax rate to 38 percent from 44 percent used for the first 6 months as a result of changes to the U. S. Federal income tax law.

title: A Lack of Ice Time Has Lemaire Just Spinning in Circles
description: Jacques Lemaire's eyes lighted up the moment he stepped out of the Devils' dressing room and saw people skating on the ice at South Mountain Arena here this morning.

title: Kemper Corp.(KEM,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,200,000, or 10 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 5,700,000, or 17 cents a share, in the 9 months.c-After income from discontinued operations of $ 281,200,000, or $ 7.29 a share, in the quarter and $ 308,300,000, or $ 6.73 a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 11,900,000, or 26 cents a share.Results in the latest quarter included net realized investment losses of $ 30.3 million, compared with investment losses of $ 151.6 million in the year-ago quarter.Results in the latest 9 months included net realized investment losses of $ 14.3 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with investment losses of $ 217.3 million, or $ 4.74 a share, in the year-earlier period.

title: Oakley Expects Toe Surgery 'Sooner or Later'
description: Charles Oakley sat out of last night's exhibition game against the Washington Bullets after he once again raised the possibility of having surgery to correct a partly dislocated toe on his right foot.

title: Hartford Steam Boiler Inspection & Insurance Co.  (HSB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included special charge of $ 2.9 million, or 9 cents a share, for California Proposition 103 insurance rate rollback referendum in the quarter and 9 months.c-Net loss and included $ 20 million pretax restructuring charge in both the quarter and 9 months.(Loss)

title: Owners Reject Velarde's Free Agency Bid
description: RANDY VELARDE joined a Yankee teammate, JIM ABBOTT, on two lists yesterday: the list of 111 players who have filed for free agency and the list of 11 players whom the clubs have rejected because, the clubs say, they don't have sufficient service time.

title: Mildred Natwick, 89, Actress Who Excelled at Eccentricity
description: Mildred Natwick, a versatile actress who created an engaging gallery of eccentric, whimsical and spunky characters in plays, films and television for more than 60 years, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

title: MEDIATOR ACCEPTED FOR USAIR NEGOTIATIONS WITH PILOTS
description: USAir and its pilots' union accepted a mediator yesterday to help resolve an impasse over how much union workers should contribute to the carrier's cost-cutting efforts. At the urging of Transportation Secretary Federico Pena, the two sides agreed to work with Gerald Baliles, the former Governor of Virginia, who last year was chairman of a commission on the United States airline industry. The Air Line Pilots Association broke off talks with USAir after the airline said it would sell some larger aircraft as part of a plan to pare the number of pilot jobs and send many captains to lower-paying positions on smaller planes. USAir says it needs to reduce its annual labor costs by $500 million.

title: Amid Real Dramas, A New Opera House Opens in Tel Aviv
description: For two nights this week, Israel celebrated the opening of its first opera house.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: What's for Lunch? American
description: IT was lunch time at Public School 144 in Forest Hills, Queens, and nearly 200 youngsters crowded along the beige picnic-style tables, tearing into brown bags and plastic boxes as if they were birthday gifts.

title: A Wide Impact, From Soup Kitchens to Recycling; HOSPITALS
description: The new round of budget cuts proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani would in large and small ways affect nearly every agency of city government. Here are the agencies that will endure the biggest cuts.

title: Lab Studying Lyme Disease To Reopen
description: A Lyme disease research laboratory that closed at New York Medical College in Valhalla in June when the top scientist left for Yale University will reopen at the State University College at Purchase, officials announced today.

title: County's Charter Revision In Peril, Despite Wide Favor
description: Despite bipartisan support for a new Nassau County charter, the outcome of a Nov. 8 referendum on the proposal is a tossup, political and civic leaders say.

Don't Punish Universities for Research Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Slain Candidate's Widow to Lead Party in Sri Lankan Election
description: As mourners filed past the body of the latest victim of this country's cycle of political violence today, the dead man's political party nominated his widow to succeed him as its candidate in a presidential election next month.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in some copies misstated the amount the city expects to save by cutting health care costs for city workers. It is $190 million, not $200 million.

title: Beyond Decoration, Pumpkin Treats From the Kitchen
description: KNIFE-WIELDING artisans transform the symbol of the autumn harvest into snaggletoothed, grinning jack-o'-lanterns, but cooks whittle pumpkins differently. Cooks know that a pumpkin's sweet, rich flesh brings the same comforting assurance to the table that the sight of its plump orange belly brings to the farm stand.

title: SWEEPING REVISION IN COMMUNICATION IS ON THE HORIZON
description: Telecommunications companies and their customers are on the verge of the most sweeping revision of the nation's communications landscape since the breakup of the Bell System in 1984.

title: GENERAL SIGNAL SAYS IT WON'T RAISE BID FOR RELIANCE
description: The chairman of the General Signal Corporation, Edmund M. Carpenter, said yesterday he had no plans to raise his company's bid of $1.35 billion in stock for the Reliance Electric Company, even though the Rockwell International Corporation last week surpassed that offer for the industrial equipment maker. Mr. Carpenter called Rockwell's $1.5 billion all-cash offer for Reliance a "hostile bust-up kind of raid" that could not win regulatory approval. Reliance, of Cleveland, said it was working with General Signal, whose bid values each Reliance share at about $26, as its lawyers and advisers study Rockwell's offer, which values each share at $30.

title: Vatican Establishes 'Stable and Official Relations' With P.L.O.
description: Seeking broader influence in the Holy Land, the Vatican today established a form of diplomatic relations with the Palestine Liberation Organization to balance its ties with Israel.

title: AirTouch Communications (ATI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: Starving at 900 Calories
description: To the Editor:

title: Light Source To Replace Many Bulbs
description: A new type of energy-efficient, long-life lighting developed by a Maryland company with support from the Energy Department may allow the replacement of hundreds of floodlight bulbs with just a few of the new units.

description: b-After a charge of $ 6,500,000, or 14 cents a share, from cumulative effect of changes in accounting for income taxes and postretirement benefits.

title: Giuliani Threatens to Cut Funds To Force Merger of Police Forces
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani delivered what amounted to an ultimatum to the city's transit officials yesterday, saying they had 90 days to merge the transit police with the city's Police Department or he would cut off virtually all the financing of the transit force.

description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 1,100,000, or 2 cents a share.

description: Shares of Baxter International Inc. tumbled yesterday, after the company said sales in its medical supply unit fell in the third quarter and trimmed forecasts for revenue growth.

title: S. A. Kingsbury, 71, Expert on Proverbs And Folk Wisdom
description: Stewart Ashley Kingsbury, who did research on the origins of proverbs, folk wisdom and place names and edited several reference books on the subjects, died on Sunday at his home in Marquette, Mich. He was 71.

title: Gary Larson's Creatures Off the Printed Page
description: With Disney's "Lion King" on its way to being the biggest moneymaker -- $1 billion over all -- in Hollywood history, the entertainment industry is envisioning a Golden Age of Animation. Beware of producers looking for a golden anything. But there's no doubt that the animation scene on television these days is glistening with vitality. The newest welcome entry: Gary Larson.

The 9 months also included an extraordinary charge on debt extinguishment of $ 2,500,000, or 2 cents a share.(Loss)

title: Petrochemical Profits Are Helping Oil Companies
description: An increase in demand for petrochemicals, used in making plastics, synthetic rubber and fibers, is causing a shortage of supplies and a jump in prices.

title: For Cuomo and Giuliani, an Odd Marriage of Shared Burdens
description: They have never shared so much as a meal and could not fairly be called friends, their friends say. On some issues, like the death penalty, they are polar opposite icons of their parties. Through two bitter mayoral elections and two Republican Presidencies, they were pointed intellectual and oratorical adversaries.

title: A Maverick Ups the Ante On Loyalty
description: Since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's surprise endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, politicians have been debating how the Republican Mayor's maverick act might affect him in his own party.

title: In a Church, Lamb Images
description: No specific doctrine was preached in Deborah Hay's "Lamb, Lamb, Lamb, Lamb, Lamb . . .," which was offered on Friday night at St. Mark's Church by the Danspace Project and Movement Research. Yet this gentle ceremony for 26 dancers seemed at home in a house of worship.

title: CONSECO PURCHASE OF KEMPER IS DELAYED
description: Conseco Inc. said yesterday that its proposed $3.25 billion purchase of the Kemper Corporation would be delayed until next year because the company would not decide how to finance the purchase until late November. Conseco, a Carmel, Ind., insurer, had wanted to complete the purchase of Kemper, a Chicago financial services company, by the end of the year. It has until March 31 to conclude the deal. Conseco said it might still sell one or more stakes in the Western National Corporation, the Bankers Life Holding Company and CCP Insurance Inc., but said the sales were not needed to acquire Kemper. On the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, Conseco shares fell $1, to $36.25, and Kemper shares fell $1.75, to $52.625.

title: A Significant Stop in Syria
description: The official reason for President Clinton's trip to the Middle East is to witness today's signing of the Israel-Jordan peace treaty. But the intriguing stop will be the meeting tomorrow in Damascus with Syria's President, Hafez al-Assad.

title: Another British Minister Resigns Over Outside Lobbying Deals
description: A junior British Government minister resigned today over reports that he failed to disclose outside lobbying deals, the second junior minister to quit under a cloud in a week, leaving Prime Minister John Major scrambling to limit the political damage from questions about his Conservative Party's ethical standards.

title: U.S. Builds Its G.E. Case On Timing
description: Opening its arguments in its case against the General Electric Company today, the Government said that G.E. conspired with De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. to fix prices of industrial diamonds after an earlier attempt by G.E. to raise the price failed because De Beers did not match the move.

Ashland Coal (ACI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 18,836,000, or $ 1.09 a share.

title: Hunger and Dissent Stalk a Struggling Ethiopia
description: After two decades of war and famine, political oppression and mass killings, the recipe for restoring a shattered economy under a democratic government remains elusive here.

title: Cilcorp Inc.(CER,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article in the Metro Section on Oct. 12 about the possibility that Sears, Roebuck & Company would open a department store at Herald Square referred incorrectly to the company's previous operations in New York. They have indeed included some in Manhattan; periodically since 1928, Sears has operated stores there with limited offerings like appliances and home furnishings. All of those stores have since closed.

title: Have Stroller, Will Exercise
description: IN this age of relentless exercise, it was inevitable: strollers serving as equipment for working out. Postpartum mothers and mothers of toddlers are twisting, breathing deeply and doing deep knee bends at new exercise classes in Riverside Park, Central Park and Battery Park City. Elizabeth Trindade, the founder of the program and a personal trainer, began to organize the classes last spring. The sessions include about 27 exercises, most of them done while the mother holds onto the stroller bar as if holding a ballet barre. The baby goes along for the ride, sometimes just staring, sometimes performing his or her own form of exercise, like leg raises that wind up with toes in the mouth.

title: Pataki in Peekskill: Behind the Revival
description: George E. Pataki's tenure as Mayor of Peekskill, and the years afterward as a dominant presence there, offer insight into the politician's priorities as he seeks the governorship of New York State. In many ways, it provides a clearer picture than his Albany record as a four-term minority-party Assemblyman and one-term Senator.

title: Aflac Inc.(AFL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about microbreweries referred incorrectly to the location of one in which Anheuser-Busch has become an investor. The company, Red Hook Brewing, is in Seattle, not Portland.

title: Giuliani Urges Fusion Vote: Cuomo on the Liberal Line
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani reiterated his endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo last night, adding the new twist of asking New Yorkers to vote for Mr. Cuomo on the Liberal Party line.

description: Already, they call him Mr. Speaker.

title: Finding on Universe's Age Poses New Cosmic Puzzle
description: The most accurate measurement yet of the distance to a remote galaxy has yielded a refined estimate of the rate at which the universe is expanding, bringing scientists much closer to determining one of the most fundamental and elusive numbers in cosmic theory: the age of the universe.

description: They may be locked out of 26 arenas across North America, but the Copps Coliseum in Hamilton, Ontario, is not one of them.

title: Acquittal for Rabbi's Wife
description: The judge made his comments after the prosecution rested its case. The Helbranses have been on trial since Oct. 3 on charges of kidnapping Shai Fhima Reuven, who was 13 when he disappeared in April 1992 after his mother had sent him for bar mitzvah instruction to the Hasidic yeshiva that Rabbi Helbrans then ran in Brooklyn.

title: New Study Links Abortions and Increase in Breast Cancer Risk
description: A new federally financed study has found that women who have abortions increase their risk of breast cancer.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Music Notes column on Tuesday about Placido Domingo's new post as principal guest conductor at the Los Angeles Music Center Opera misstated his immediate performance and recording plans with the company. He, not the baritone Vladimir Chernov, is to sing the title role in the production of Verdi's "Otello" scheduled for May; Mr. Domingo will not conduct it. He is to conduct the company's orchestra and Mr. Chernov in an aria concert to be recorded by Sony Classical.

title: Washington Gas Light Co.(WGL,N) reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Fred Springer-Miller; Sportsman, 65
description: Fred Frank Springer-Miller, a former I.B.M. systems engineer who helped design the first fully computerized Olympic scoring system, for the 1964 Winter Games at Innsbruck, Austria, died on Saturday at his home in Greenville, S.C. He was 65.

title: DU PONT (E.I.) DE NEMOURS & CO. (DD,N)
description: E. I. DuPont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that its third-quarter operating earnings rose 86 percent, reflecting cost reductions and growth in the company's global markets. Over all, the company rebounded strongly from a net loss in the corresponding period last year.

title: President Offers Economic Plan for Mideast
description: Just hours after celebrating the formal peace between Israel and Jordan, President Clinton outlined a plan tonight to promote economic development across the Middle East. But he coupled it with a warning that violence could still tear the region asunder.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Comeback for Agassi Andre Agassi, blanked in the first set and down by 2-4, 15-40, in the second, produced an impressive comeback yesterday to beat Nicklas Kulti of Sweden in the second round of the Stockholm Open. The United States Open champion, ranked eighth in the world, won by 0-6, 7-5, 6-4. Pete Sampras, playing in his first ATP tournament since early September, struggled before beating the Czech qualifier Daniel Vacek, 7-6 (8-6), 6-1. Seventh-seeded Michael Chang became the highest-seeded player to fall, losing by 6-4, 6-3 to Sweden's Magnus Larsson. (AP) COLLEGE FOOTBALL A New Bowl Alliance The Cotton and Holiday Bowls have announced an agreement that gives them access to teams from the expanded Big Eight, the Pacific-10 and the Western Athletic Conferences, as well as an opportunity to invite Notre Dame. Under the new agreement, the Holiday Bowl, played in San Diego, will get the two teams not chosen by the Cotton Bowl, and both the Cotton Bowl and Holiday Bowl will have the option of selecting Notre Dame if it is left out of the alliance games.

description: Her face still disfigured and her nose still flattened because of the many times it had been broken, Hedda Nussbaum reappeared in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday.

description: A brief sports article on Tuesday about the refund policies of hockey teams in the New York area referred incorrectly to single-game tickets for the Islanders. Returns for refunds must be made at least seven business days in advance of the rescheduled game, not up to 48 hours in advance.

description: b-After a charge of $ 3.4 million, or 3 cents a unit, and $ 4.3 million, or 4 cents a unit, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, both on remediation costs associated with a sinkhold beneath a phosphogypsum storage stack at IMC-Agrico's New Wales, Fla., fertilizer facility.c-Net loss and the 9 months is after charges of $ 124.2 million, or $ 1.20 a unit, on restructuring the administrative organization at Freeport-McMoran Inc., and a $ 23.7 million, or 23 cents a unit, accounting charge.Share earnings are in units.(Loss)

title: Cornhuskers Fear Their Title Hopes Will Go Unfulfilled Again
description: Football at Nebraska, like other schools where the sport has a feel of the assembly line, is about winning national championships. Thus, rooting for the Cornhuskers has come to require an elasticity of the heart -- an unalterable faith that every season will bring a title and a stolid acceptance when every season falls just short.

title: Hanover Direct Inc.(HNV,A) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Usery Talks With Players
description: BILL USERY JR., the Federal mediator recruited to work on the baseball strike, now 11 weeks old, held a session with the players' union at its offices in New York yesterday. "It's in the nature of the process not to discuss what was discussed so I won't," said Eugene Orza, the union's No. 2 official." Nine more players filed for free agency, raising the total to 120, plus the 11 whose status is in dispute because of 52 days lost from the strike. Among those filing yesterday were pitchers BOB WELCH and BOBBY WITT of Oakland, and first baseman JOHN KRUK of Philadelphia.

title: The Simple Touch
description: SCOTT WILLENS'S Wonderland line of chairs and tables seems to come from a minimalist wonderland. Mr. Willens, a designer in San Francisco, has kept his children's furniture free of distracting details.

title: Suit to Block Emission Rules Is Dismissed
description: A Federal District Court judge in Syracuse has thrown out a lawsuit by the Big Three auto manufacturers to block New York State's adoption of the California low-emission vehicle rules.

title: THREAT SEEN TO B.A.T. ACQUISITION OF AMERICAN TOBACCO
description: Antitrust regulators at the Federal Trade Commission will recommend that the commission block the proposed $1 billion purchase of the American Tobacco Company by B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., according to a report in F.T.C. Watch, a Washington newsletter that tracks the agency. The report said the F.T.C. staff's recommendation could be made to the commissioners this week. B.A.T., based in London, said on April 26 that it would buy American Tobacco from American Brands for $1 billion in cash. The acquisition would strengthen B.A.T.'s position as the nation's third-biggest tobacco company.

title: Furniture Circus Comes To Town
description: Mario Buatta, the New York society decorator, strolled from one cocktail party to the next with a gag toupee on his head. In front of the La-Z-Boy showroom on Main Street, a crowd of button-down business people waiting for the light watched a bevy of suspiciously well-endowed young women promote the Tiki Club topless bar. And across town, in the parking lot of the National Guard Armory, a 5,000-pound African elephant named Laura gently lowered her wrinkled gray flanks onto a specially built daybed to test the strength of a new laminated lumber product made from aspen saplings.

title: Tenneco Net Rose by 36% In 3d Quarter
description: Tenneco Inc. reported today that its third-quarter earnings jumped 36 percent, driven by sharply higher income at its Case farm and construction equipment division and its packaging unit.

title: 3 Men Hurl Racial Slurs and Attack Officers in Bar, Police Say
description: Three minority police officers who had just ended their shifts were assaulted in a Brooklyn bar yesterday by three white men who shouted racial slurs and threw punches and beer bottles at them, officials said.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: BUDGET COUNTS ON HELP FROM ALBANY Buried throughout the plan Mayor Giuliani put forward to close a $1.1 billion gap in New York City's budget is what amounts to a sizable bill to Albany -- payable to City Hall. A1. NEW YORK CITY PANELS APPROVE INVESTIGATIVE AGENCY Defying the wishes of Mayor Giuliani, two City Council committees passed a bill that would establish a permanent agency with full investigative powers to monitor corruption in the Police Department. B3.

title: Sheldon B. Liss; Historian, 57
description: Sheldon B. Liss, a historian who specialized in 20th-century radical political movements in Latin America, died on Oct. 19 at MetroHealth Medical Center in Cleveland. He was 57 and lived in Brecksville, Ohio.

title: New Investigative Firm
description: James B. Mintz, a co-founder of the Investigative Group, a leading corporate investigative concern, has left the firm to form his own company. The new firm, the James Mintz Group, will have offices In New York and Washington. It will specialize in gathering facts for litigation, due diligence and other corporate and financial matters.

title:
CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Labeling the Toys That Could Choke
description: ON a day at the Oklahoma City Zoo with her 18-month-old toddler, Sara Messinger of Edmond, Okla., probably like many parents that day, treated her son, Jonathan, to a toy from a vending machine. Back home that afternoon, Jonathan was put down for his nap holding the toy, a six-inch-tall koala bear that seemed to be made out of hard plastic.

title: One Thing's Sure With Bob Grant: It's Not Chicken Talk
description: The microphone light went dim for a few minutes chock full of commercial messages while Bob Grant, seated calmly at the center of a storm of charges that he is the city's leading radio bigot, picked up the thread of an interrupted conversation with a visitor in the broadcast booth.

description: Elaine M. Garzarelli, one of Wall Street's most prominent and flamboyant stock market forecasters, has been ousted by Lehman Brothers.

title: PENNZOIL TO PAY $454 MILLION IN TAX SETTLEMENT
description: The Pennzoil Company said yesterday that it would pay $454 million in cash to settle a tax dispute with the Internal Revenue Service. Pennzoil, an oil exploration and development company based in Houston, said it had cash holdings of more than $898 million as of Sept. 30. The company said the tax dispute concerned $2.2 billion that was withheld from Pennzoil's taxable income in 1988. The sum represented a significant part of a $3 billion settlement with Texaco Inc. in 1988 related to Pennzoil's attempt to acquire the Getty Oil Company. The $2.2 billion was invested in common stock of the Chevron Corporation. Shares of Pennzoil, which announced the settlement after the market closed, rose 37.5 cents, to $49.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Yang Dezhi, 83; a Leader Of Red Army

title: Answering the N.R.A.
description: CANDIDATE Senator Bob Kerrey, a Democrat being challenged for re-election in Nebraska by Jan Stoney, a Republican, is one of several lawmakers being opposed by the National Rifle Association because of his vote for a ban on assault weapons. This is Mr. Kerrey's response to an association's advertisement featuring the actor Charlton Heston, who asserted: "You said you wouldn't vote for gun bans. But you went to Washington and voted for the first Federal gun ban in American history." PRODUCER Struble/Totten Communications ON THE SCREEN Opens with men on a shooting range, with red letters declaring, "A Message to Charlton Heston from Bob Kerrey." The camera zooms in on Mr. Kerrey, dressed in hunting garb, as he fires at a clay pigeon. As he talks into the camera, he ejects the shell from the shotgun he just used, and then, midway through, puts the gun down and picks up another weapon. SCRIPT An announcer says, "A message for Charlton Heston from Senator Bob Kerrey." Then Mr. Kerrey says: "I'm a hunter, and I believe in the constitutional right to bear arms. When it's time to hunt birds, you need a good gun like this Ruger Red Label. Twenty-five years ago, in the war in Vietnam, people hunted me. They needed a good weapon -- like this AK-47. But you don't need one of these to hunt birds." The announcer then says: "Bob Kerrey. The courage to lead." ACCURACY The distinction Mr. Kerrey draws is correct. A spokesman for the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said that the semi-automatic version of the AK-47 would be covered by the ban in the crime bill, which covers 19 types of semi-automatic weapons. The spokesman also said that shotguns like the Ruger Red Label would be unaffected by the ban. SCORECARD The ad is a tough response to a tough attack: Mr. Kerrey deals head-on with the charge that his support for a ban on semi-automatic weapons was a sellout of Nebraska hunters and gun owners. By word and message, he is trying to tell hunters that he is one of them. And, as is often the case with Mr. Kerrey, his background as a veteran of the Vietnam War, where he lost a leg and won the Medal of Honor, gives a political argument an emotional punch. ROBIN TONER
