description: b-Net loss, which was after one-time, noncash charge of $ 220.2 million, or $ 3.47 a share, for changes in accounting methods due to the adoption of SFAS 106, 109 and 112.c-Included one-time tax benefits of 8 cents a share and a one-time gain of 6 cents a share from a special, voluntary termination program for both periods.(Loss)

title: Southern Co.(SO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Eating in Style
description: NOTHING is too luxurious for a young child. This sterling silver Victorian repousse set is made by Kirk Stieff, a Baltimore-based silversmith firm. As some children's silverware designs slip more and more toward minimalism and others bend toward an overly babyish style, the fork and spoon at right are reassuringly old-fashioned.

title: Harsco Corp.(HSC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge from minority interest of $ 494,000 in the quarter and $ 1,644,000 in the 9 months.c-After an extraordinary charge from minority interest of $ 150,000 in the quarter and $ 47,000 in the 9 months. The 9 months also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $ 6,802,000, or 27 cents a share.

title: Race for Governor: Cuomo Gets Endorsement of 'Character'
description: CANDIDATE -- Mario M. Cuomo PRODUCER -- The Garth Group, New York City

title: Kemp Says Trust Is the Key
description: A panel of former National Football League players and management officials said last night that the keys to their league's labor agreement were open financial records and trust, and urged baseball and hockey to try the same formula.

title: SARA LEE CORP. (SLE,N)
description: The Sara Lee Corporation yesterday reported better-than-expected earnings in the first quarter.

title: Study Disputes Subway On-Time Claims
description: A new study has confirmed what many subway riders have long suspected: The on-time performance of trains in the city's subway system is far below the 91 percent rate the transit authority has claimed in the last two years.

title: Senator Decides to Fight N.R.A.'s Fire With Fire
description: There is a fierce advertising war over guns being fought in much of the West. On one side is Charlton Heston and the National Rifle Association; on the other is a group of senators, like Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, which is fighting back with a vengeance.

title: Corrections
description: A listing on Oct. 9 with a map showing growth in the Hispanic population in a group of American cities specified the states incorrectly for two entries in some editions. As the map showed, the cities -- in which the Hispanic population surpassed the non-Hispanic black population by 1990 -- were Oak Ridge, Fla., and Pittsburg, Calif.

title: Ohio Casualty Corp.(OCAS,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an accounting charge of $ 319,000, or 1 cent a share, from the adoption of FAS 112 and 115.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies Earnings more than doubled at Ford, helped by vigorous demand for the Windstar mini-van, Mustang sports coupe and four-wheel-drive Explorers. The performance contrasted sharply with last week's disappointing results from General Motors. [ Page D1. ] Lehman Brothers ousted Elaine M. Garzarelli, one of Wall Street's most prominent and flamboyant stock market forecasters. She was widely hailed for calling the 1987 market crash. [ D1. ]

title: Bethlehem Steel Corp.(BS,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net lossLatest quarter's share earnings was less than one cent a share.(Loss)

title: Female Fighter Pilot Killed in Crash Off California
description: One of the Navy's first female combat pilots was killed in a training accident off Southern California on Tuesday, the Navy said today.

title: Israel and Jordan Sign a Peace Accord
description: At this desert outpost along their border, desolate except for their hopes, Israel and Jordan signed a peace treaty today to put behind them 46 years of war, mistrust and fear for tomorrow.

title: Livable City Ponders Its Outburst of Anger and Unrest
description: This central Kentucky city rising out of rolling fields of horse farms, burley tobacco fields and bourbon distilleries is perennially near the top of magazine lists of the nation's most livable cities.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO. (PG,N)
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that its fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 18 percent, driven by cost-control efforts and higher worldwide sales volume.

title: Administration Moves Against Tax Credit
description: Mindful of next month's elections, in which immigration has been a hot issue in California and other states, the Clinton Administration took a stand today against illegal aliens' collecting a widely used tax credit that is intended to benefit working poor people but has been a major instrument of fraud.

title: Interpublic Responds To WPP Lawsuit
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies has responded to a suit filed in New York Supreme Court by the WPP Group USA that accused Interpublic of violating an agreement not to hire certain executives from two WPP agencies, J. Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather.

title: Bucharest Journal; Little Care and Less Love: Romania's Sad Orphans
description: In a drab dormitory, small children old enough to walk and talk grip the rails of their cribs in frustrated attempts at locomotion, silently rocking back and forth. A playroom filled with toys, a paradise of imagination and exercise donated by foreigners, remains locked because the children's caretakers consider it too much trouble to supervise. The caretakers, women in white uniforms, sit a few yards away in the corridor, smoking and chatting.

title: Bankers Life Holding Corp.(BLH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included nonrecurring gain of $ 8.1 million, or 15 cents a share, primarily from the resolution of items associated with the change in control of the company in 1992 in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included trading losses of $ 800,000, or one cent a share.c-Included trading income of $ 2.1 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 16.1 million, or 29 cents a share, in the 9 months.Pro forma results for year-ago 9 months reflect the March 1993 initial public offering and recapitalization as if they occurred Jan. 1, 1993.

title: Holmes Says He'll Fight McCall
description: LARRY HOLMES will challenge OLIVER McCALL for the World Boxing Council heavyweight championship on Jan. 21, a longtime Holmes aide said yesterday.

title: Parents and Schooling
description: To The Home Section:

title: Victims Sue Arms Makers In Shooting On L.I.R.R.
description: A group of family members of those slain in the Long Island Rail Road shootings last December, along with some wounded survivors, filed a lawsuit yesterday against the companies that made the weaponry used in the attack.

title: Could It Be? Does 1+1=1 In Math's Grand Scheme?
description: Although Fermat's last theorem is a daunting and longstanding challenge, mathematicians say they are interested in Dr. Andrew Wiles's work because it points the way to a grand linkage between two major branches of mathematics: algebra and analysis (also known as calculus).

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 ISRAEL AND JORDAN SIGN TREATY Israel and Jordan agreed to peace, settling land and water disputes, agreeing to cooperate in tourism, trade and other areas, and pledging that neither would let its land be used for attacks on the other. A1

title: Timken Co.(TKR,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss; the 9 months was after a charge of $ 254,263,000 from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: A Launching Pad for a Video Revolution
description: To understand why some of the regional Bell companies want to team up with Michael Ovitz, the Hollywood superagent, visit the gleaming new digital video production center of the Bell Atlantic Corporation in Reston, Va.

title: Clinton, in Letter, Assures North Koreans on Nuclear Reactors
description: President Clinton promised North Korea's leader in a letter released today that if the planned international financing for new nuclear reactors fell through, he would do his utmost to have the United States provide them.

title: Agreement on Rules In Metro-North Talks
description: The Metro-North railroad has agreed with four unions, representing half its unionized work force, on how to negotiate with them. The agreement, reached on Tuesday night, is meant to reduce the possibility of wildcat job actions in the next few weeks, the railroad said yesterday.

title: UNITED TECHNOLOGIES CORP.
description: The United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that its third-quarter net income rose 23.6 percent, as its commercial businesses, led by its Otis elevator and Carrier heating and cooling equipment units, showed an 11 percent increase in revenue.

title: Agriculture Dept. Scraps Poultry Bacteria Plan
description: The Department of Agriculture said yesterday that it would scrap the much-criticized rules it proposed this summer to control bacterial contamination of poultry.

title: Retaliation Won't Deter Islamic Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: W. K. Frankena, 86, Philosophy Professor
description: William K. Frankena, a philosophy professor at the University of Michigan who compiled a widely read book on the theory and history of ethics, died on Saturday at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ypsilanti, Mich. He was 86 and lived in Ann Arbor.

title: Stone Container Corp.(STO,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included extraodinary charges of $ 44.8 million, or 50 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 61.6 million, or 70 cents a share, in the 9 months, from predominately noncash write-off of the unamortized balance of fees applicable to recent prepayments of debt. The 9 months was also after a charge of $ 14.2 million, or 16 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Included a charge of $ 39.5 million, or 56 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.(Loss)

title: Borden Reports a Net Loss of $130.5 Million
description: Borden Inc. announced a third-quarter loss of $130.5 million yesterday, citing one-time charges and disappointing performance of its dairy, pasta and food businesses.

title: Wealthy Ward In the Capital Talks Secession
description: Washington is saddled with debt, crime, and troubled schools. Since 1980, the population has shrunk to 585,221 from 638,333, and the middle class finding the grass greener in the suburbs.

title: CHRYSLER TO ADD JOBS AT NEON PLANT IN ILLINOIS
description: The Chrysler Corporation is planning to add workers at its plant in Belvidere, Ill., because of strong demand for its new subcompact car, the Neon. A company spokesman, Mike Aberlich, declined to say how many jobs would be added until the formal announcement was made on Thursday. Chrysler's Belvidere plant now has about 3,700 workers on two shifts, and there have been reports that the company, the No. 3 United States auto maker, wants to keep the plant operating round the clock. The plant now has the straight-time capacity to build about 250,000 Neons a year, Mr. Aberlich said. By increasing overtime operations, the plant could make as many as 300,000 Neons a year, he said.

title: Kennedy and Romney Look to Round 2
description: After one widely watched debate with Senator Edward M. Kennedy that did not appear to have significantly helped the challenger, Mitt Romney, who spent most of today preparing for a second debate on Thursday that may be his last chance.

title: No. 2 Commissioner Of Police Resigns
description: First Deputy Police Commissioner David W. Scott, one of the highest-ranking black officials in the Giuliani administration, said yesterday that he would retire at year-end to spend more time with his family.

title: Journal; Getting Real
description: "One of the reasons why people are so turned off about politics today," said the Mayor of New York on Monday, is "because we don't act like we're real people."

title: Cleaning, Worrying, Rebeling
description: For the opening of its 25th season, Mabou Mines has returned to La Mama, where it was born, for the first time since 1972, with a spectacular staging of "Mother," written by Patricia Spears Jones and starring Ruth Maleczech, one of the troupe's founders. The performance -- continuing on Thursdays to Sundays through Nov. 6 -- is a perfect emblem of this innovative company: a multimedia collage that is memorable, exhilarating and disorienting.

title: 2 Council Committees Pass Bill to Create Police Agency
description: Defying the wishes of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, two City Council committees passed a bill yesterday that would establish a permanent agency with full investigative powers to monitor corruption in the Police Department.

title: Michael Kasdan, 66, Producer and Potter
description: Michael Kasdan, a former Broadway producer and theater manager, died on Saturday at his home in Mahopac, N.Y. He was 66.

title: Clark USA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a gain of $ 16.4 million after tax from a reversal of a 1993 year-end inventory writedown. It said the writedown was reversed because crude oil and product prices improved from the end of 1993.c-Net lossClark USA, Inc. is a unit of Horsham Corp. Clark recently filed for an initial public offering.

title: James J. Norwood Union Official, 63
description: James J. Norwood, the general secretary-treasurer of the Laborers' International Union of North America, died on Monday at St. Louis University Hospital. He was 63 and lived in St. Louis.

title: Thomas Hits a Double At the M.V.P. Plate
description: Frank Thomas, the big-hitting Chicago White Sox first baseman whose pursuit of the American League triple crown ended with the premature demise of the 1994 season, settled for a rare consolation double yesterday. He was named the league's most valuable player for the second straight year, becoming the sixth American Leaguer to achieve that.

title: Essay; Loyalty And Perfidy
description: Republican Party loyalty has just been dramatically tested from coast to coast.

title: A Hospital That's Friendly
description: THE staff at the Rhode Island Hospital in Providence was hoping for more than just a pretty, post-modern box for its new Hasbro Children's Hospital. And after working with parents, local artists and others in the community to make the hospital as homey and efficient as possible, the staff got much more.

title: LILCO TO STUDY TAKEOVER BY NEW YORK STATE
description: The board of the Long Island Lighting Company told the company's management yesterday to begin discussing a takeover by New York State with officials of the Long Island Power Authority and the New York Power Authority. The board also authorized hiring Dillon, Read & Company as investment bankers and the law firm of Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Frankel, a spokeswoman said. Two weeks ago Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a $9 billion takeover of the utility by the Long Island Power Authority. With the Authority's lower cost of credit, and with tax exemptions available to public power entities, a publicly owned Lilco could cut electric rates at least 10 percent, state officials said. Mr. Cuomo proposed paying $21.50 a share. Lilco shares fell 12.5 cents yesterday, to $17.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Hotheads in California
description: When 70,000 people marched in downtown Los Angeles this month to protest Proposition 187, the anti-illegal-alien measure on the ballot this November, it was only the latest and most obvious example of the pro-immigrant lobby shooting itself in the foot.

title: School Days May Shorten, Cortines Says
description: Schools Chancellor Ramon C. Cortines said yesterday that continuing budget cuts from City Hall could force "radical" changes in the school system, including a shorter classroom day in coming years.

title: Money Store Inc.(MONE,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings and shares outstanding were restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split in March and issuance of 1 million shares in December.

title: Rothenberg's League Still Seeking Backers
description: A day after he acknowledged that the start of Major League Soccer could be delayed until 1996, Alan Rothenberg, the chairman of the league and president of the United States Soccer Federation conceded yesterday that the birth of a Long Island franchise could be delayed ever further.

title: Market Place G.E.C.'s chairman may be ready for battle with British Aerospace.
description: SOMETIME in the next few days, the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain is expected to make a decision that could have profound ramifications for the British military contracting industry. Lord Weinstock, who has headed G.E.C. for 31 years and built its GEC Marconi division into the nation's second-largest military supplier, is likely to decide whether to start a hostile bid for VSEL P.L.C., a naval shipyard and Britain's leading submarine builder.

title: Commercial-Fishing Halt Is Urged for Georges Bank
description: Faced with a fishery on the verge of collapse, a Federal council today recommended virtually shutting down commercial fishing in the Georges Bank off Cape Code, once one of the world's richest fishing grounds.

title: CRAY RESEARCH STOCK FALLS ON LOW EARNINGS PROJECTION
description: The stock of Cray Research Inc. fell yesterday after the company, a supercomputer maker, said a shift in sales toward less powerful, cheaper models would result in lower earnings for 1995. The company's shares fell to a 52-week low of $17.75 before closing at $18.375, down $1.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. Late Tuesday, Cray, based in Eagan, Minn., reported third-quarter earnings that were stronger than expected. But the company also said its earnings would not exceed analysts' estimates of $2.15 a share for 1994.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Tokyo String Quartet misstated the opening date for its Beethoven concert series at Carnegie and Avery Fisher Halls. It was last night; it is not tonight.

title: Bar Association Starts Fund-Raising Campaign
description: The City Bar Association in New York yesterday announced a campaign to raise $3 million for its programs to provide legal services to the needy.

title: Wall St. Story: Jumbled Fact
description: Short-sellers are frequently a much-needed balance in the markets, debunking some of the hype on public companies. But sometimes they go too far.

title: Yonkers Mayor's Wife Challenged on Fund-Raising Tactics
description: In an unusual letter sent today to Yonkers city officials, the Westchester County District Attorney charged that someone in the re-election campaign of Mayor Terence M. Zaleski engaged in illegal campaign fund-raising out of City Hall. The District Attorney said that the Mayor's wife, who is his campaign treasurer, had sole responsibility for the fund-raising, but had stymied the investigation of the matter.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When Andrei Sakharov , the Soviet-era dissident nuclear physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner, came to the United States in 1988, he was invited to the home of RONALD S. LAUDER, and the two men had their picture taken together.

title: Pennsylvania Power & Light Co.(PPL,N) reports earnings for 12mos to Sept 30
description: b-Included nonrecurring charges of about 24 cents a share related to regulatory decisions.

title: THE 1994 CAMPAIGN: The Incumbent, Running in the Past; Can Giuliani Chase the Musty Smell From Cuomo's Campaign?
description: It was the day after he had unexpectedly won the endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo was flying high -- flying as high, that is, as his wary, pensive, rather equivocal nature would let him.

title: Companies Get U.S. Grants
description: The Pentagon has awarded $202.2 million in grants to industry to stimulate research into flat-panel display manufacturing processes and other advanced technologies.

title: Running, These Days, Just to Keep Up
description: ON weekends in Central Park this time of year, you can tell who the marathoners are. They lope determinedly, lean, machinelike, rounding the six-mile loop three times and then tacking on a few more miles to finish the longest training run. By now the dilettantes who lined up for entry forms at Tavern on the Green in the spring have dropped away and those who are still training have nearly won their personal races. Running the marathon isn't a few hours out of your life; it begins the moment you commit body and soul to the months of miles that end in a day of unmatched exhilaration completely public, completely private. Never does New York City, the whole city, feel so much like home.

title: Tomorrow's Interactive Home
description: Information Superhighway. For most Americans, the term is a fuzzy, bewildering abstraction. But the announcement this week that Sprint, the large long-distance carrier, will join forces with T.C.I., the nation's largest cable company, and two other cable operators should bring the idea into sharp focus.

title: Foley, Behind in Polls, Plays Gingrich Card
description: Although the race has tightened somewhat, Speaker Thomas S. Foley is still behind in his effort to hold onto the Congressional seat he has held for 30 years, recent polls indicate.

title: Accounts
description: * Louise's Inc., Louisville, Ky., to Ground Zero, Venice, Calif., as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of Louise's fat-free and low-fat snacks, including potato chips, tortilla chips and popcorn. Billings were not disclosed. * United Distillers P.L.C., London, to Leo Burnett/San Juan, to handle advertising for five brands -- Gordon's gin, Gordon's vodka, Tanqueray gin and Johnnie Walker Black and Red Labels Scotch whiskies -- in Puerto Rico, previously at BBDO Puerto Rico, San Juan. Burnett already handles United Distillers brands in 25 other markets including the United States and Britain. Billings were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Filing Expected on Prudential
description: After more than a year of investigation, Federal prosecutors are expected to file a criminal complaint today against Prudential Securities, contending that the brokerage house engaged in large-scale fraud in its sale of limited partnerships in the 1980's, people with knowledge of the inquiry said yesterday.

title: I.B.M. Finds Flaw in Some New Software
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had briefly halted production of its new operating system software, OS/2 Warp, to correct a flaw.

title: Singer Co.(SEW,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
...While a Mathematician Calls Classic Riddle Solved
description: For a year and a half, mathematicians have been on tenterhooks as a proposed proof of the world's most famous mathematics problem, Fermat's last theorem, was alternately called incandescently brilliant and then fatally flawed. But now the problems with the proof may be resolved.

title: Remembering College, Women on the Verge And Silly Traditions
description: Wendy Wasserstein's "Uncommon Women and Others" has reached the awkward age.

title: Wang Laboratories Inc.(WANG,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included noncash charges of $ 6.6 million for amortization of intangible assets and $ 2.4 million included in the provision for income taxes.The year-ago first quarter is not comparable due to implementation of ''fresh-start'' reporting in latest quarter.

title: 33d Street? Just Look For an Eagle
description: IMAGINE how dreary the subway would be without its ceramic murals and mosaics -- the steamboats at Fulton Street, the beaver at Astor Place, the eagle at East 33d Street. Today, the 90th anniversary of the opening of the New York City subway system, also celebrates the reissue of "Subway Ceramics: A History and Iconography," by Lee Stookey. Over the last 24 years she has photographed 38 stations that have ceramic picture plaques.

title: It's a Grim Message: Dummies Fail More Often
description: THE BELL CURVE Intelligence and Class Structure in American Life By Richard J. Herrnstein and Charles Murray. 845 pages. The Free Press. $30.

title: A Jury System for Jurors
description: It is no secret that the jury selection system in New York is a disgrace. For years it has operated mainly for the convenience of lawyers, judges and court personnel, in roughly that order.

title: GOING HOME WITH: Heather Whitestone; Placing the Person Ahead of the Crown
description: AT the Summit Club, here in her hometown, Miss America has been on her feet for almost two hours, smiling, shaking hands and reading lips. Heather Whitestone, the first Miss America with a disability (she lost her hearing after a bout of Hemophilus influenza at the age of 18 months), could teach the ramshackle House of Windsor a thing or two about dignity and grace. But doesn't she ever get to sit down?

title: Dollar Steadies as France Makes an Offer of Support
description: The dollar steadied yesterday after the French Economics Minister said France was ready to help the United States support the dollar if necessary.

title: A Bank Sells Stock And Is Hit
description: The New York bank that says it is the largest financial institution operated by blacks has gone public -- with depositors who bought stock already suffering paper losses of millions of dollars.

title: Excerpts From Letter
description: Following are excerpts from a letter by the Westchester County District Attorney, Jeanine Pirro, to Yonkers officials:

title: U.S. Said to Seek Pacific Free Trade Pact
description: In a broad expansion of the Clinton Administration's trade agenda, White House officials said today that President Clinton planned to ask Asian leaders to commit themselves to free trade throughout the Pacific by a specific date early in the next century.

title: What Is This Thing Called Home, After All?
description: AT a costume party last year, my 6-year-old daughter and I experienced every variety of Halloween gimmickry. A friend of mine had recently divorced, and she and her daughter held the party in their new apartment. Our feet had no sooner touched the welcome mat than hideous laughter erupted. Inside, we found mechanical pumpkins, eerily lighted globes, life-size skeletons.

title: Small Rise In Orders Of Durables
description: Prospects for further brisk economic growth remained bright today as the Government reported a small rise in orders for long-lasting factory products for September and revised still higher the very big August jump.

title: Post-Debate: Candidates On the Road, Stars in Tow
description: The two candidates for United States Senate took their campaigns back on the road today, both accompanied by celebrity guest stars and both claiming to be refreshed from a "victory" in their debate the night before.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Corp.(KLU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss on early extinguishment of debt of $ 5,400,000, or 9 cents a share.c-Included a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $ 21,800,000, or 38 cents a share, and a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 507,300,000, or $ 8.85 a share.(Loss)

title: Investors in Deal to Buy Park Communications
description: Park Communications Inc., a collection of television, newspaper and radio properties amassed by the late Roy H. Park, said yesterday that it had agreed to be sold to two investors for $711.4 million.

title: Jersey Needs an Alternative to Its Bilingual Education Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Centex Corp.(CTX,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on sale of 51 percent interest in Centex Construction Products Inc., the company's former Construction Products unit of $ 37,495,000, or $ 1.19 a share.Centex Corp. retains 49 percent ownership of Centex Construction Products.

title: Victory Is Seen Only for U.S. and Israel
description: Many Arabs are greeting the peace treaty between Jordan and Israel without much joy. It may be a turning point in the 46-year-old Arab-Israeli conflict, but Arabs tend to regard the treaty as an admission of an Arab defeat in a long struggle rather than an honorable end that deserves rejoicing.

title: N.B.A. and Players Agree to Play Ball This Season
description: Breaking the chains of labor strife that have linked baseball and hockey in unprecedented shutdowns, the National Basketball Association and its players proclaimed eight months of labor peace yesterday and pledged to play their season while trying to forge a lasting agreement.

title: Imo Industries Inc.(IMD,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $ 737,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 2,895,000, or 17 cents a share, in the 9 months, and extraordinary charges and fees related to restructuring of senior credit facilities, of $ 5,299,000, or 31 cents a share, in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net lossd-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 6,584,000, or 39 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 7,314,000, or 43 cents a share, in the 9 months, and an extraordinary charge for valuation allowance against a related tax benefit in the second quarter of $ 6,876,000, or 41 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 18,095,000, or $ 1.07 a share, in the 9 months.(Loss)

title: Florida to Try Early Deportation
description: Some illegal immigrants suspected of crimes in Florida may now be deported even before they go to trial under a pilot program announced here today by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the state.

title: Browning-Ferris Industries Inc.(BFI,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge for the early retirement of the company's $ 100 million 81/2 percent sinking fund debentures of $ 5,263,000, or 3 cents a share.c-After an extraordinary reorganization charge of $ 16,470,000, or 10 cents a share.

title: Symposium to Focus On Mahler in New York
description: "Mahler in America, 1907-1911," an educational symposium, is to take place on Nov. 19 and 20 at Weill Recital Hall. Starting the second year of Carnegie Hall's presentation of Mahler's complete orchestral works, the symposium will focus on the composer's New York years, and will coincide with a performance of the Third Symphony by the St. Louis Symphony on Nov. 19 and the opening, on Nov. 16, of a Mahler exhibit in the Rose Museum at Carnegie Hall.

title: Halliburton Co. (HAL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss and included charges of $ 193.6 million, or $ 1.70 a share, mainly related to the divestiture of the company's geophysical business in both the quarter and 9 months.(Loss)

title: New Attack by G.O.P. Lifts Democrats' Spirits
description: With little more than a week to go until Election Day, the national parties stepped up the volume today. The Republicans introduced a series of sharply negative television advertisements, and the Democrats said that was a sign of panic over late-surging support for Democratic candidates and for President Clinton.

title: Brantley the First Free Agent to Sign
description: The business of baseball went on yesterday as if the strike did not exist.

title: Case Corp.(CSE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of $ 8 million in both the quarter and 9 months. The 9 months also included charge of $ 29 million from an accounting adjustment, and a charge of $ 5 million from the early retirement of debt. Earnings per share were $ 1.63 before those items.c-Included tax benefits of $ 37 million in both the quarter and 9 months.Share earnings are on a pro forma basis, the company had a net of 37 cents a share in the latest quarter and $ 1.23 a share in the 9 months, compared with a loss of 17 cents a share and 50 cents a share in the year-ago quarter and 9 months, respectively. Pro forma figures are calculated as if the company had entered into its reorganization agreement with Tenneco Inc. on Jan. 1, 1993.Total revenues for the period, including other income, were $ 1.04 billion and $ 3.23 billion in the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively, and $ 900 million in the year-ago quarter and $ 2.93 million in the 9 months.

title: Race for Governor: Cuomo Rebuts Pataki on Crime
description: CANDIDATE Mario M. Cuomo PRODUCER The Garth Group, New York City

title: Leggett & Platt (LEG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Corrections
description: A "Campaign Snapshot" chart on Oct. 20, about the Pennsylvania Senate race, misstated voter registration figures in some editions. The figures for registered voters are: Democrats, 2,946,266; Republicans, 2,476,977; Others, 369,038.

title: Two Parents, Two Murders, Two Children, Too Much
description: In "Silent Fall," Richard Dreyfuss plays a psychiatrist who solves a double murder witnessed by the victims' 9-year-old autistic son. As the final credits roll, the singers Wynonna and Michael English wail the movie's theme song: "Healin', I'm healin.' " It's the last ludicrous touch in a film that starts out offering the depth and suspense of a mediocre made-for-television movie and ends up as something much worse.

title: RANKS OF INMATES REACH ONE MILLION IN A 2-DECADE RISE
description: This summer, the number of inmates in America's prisons topped one million for the first time, the Justice Department said today, releasing a survey that reflected decades of demands for tougher punishments.

title: Investigating Beethoven's Modernity
description: Two celebrations -- one sober, the other happier -- converged at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night. The Tokyo String Quartet is observing its 25th birthday with an extended act of generosity, the Beethoven cycle in six concerts given in behalf of Classical Action: Performing Arts Against AIDS. Alternating between Carnegie and Avery Fisher Halls, the series is to stretch over the season and end on May 10.

title: Granting Father's Wish, or Manslaughter?
description: William F. Meyer Jr. drew his last breaths with his head encased in a plastic bag. It was an inelegant but expedient way to end his life instead of succumbing slowly to the cancer that had begun in his colon and spread to his lungs.

title: FIRST DATA TO SELL CABLE SERVICES UNIT TO CSG
description: The First Data Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Cable Services Group Inc. unit to CSG Holdings Inc. for an undisclosed amount. First Data, an information and credit card processing company based in Hackensack, N.J., said it expected to complete the transaction by Dec. 1. Cable Services Group, based in Omaha, is the second-largest provider of data processing services to the cable television industry. CSG Holdings is owned by Morgan Stanley Group Inc. and Trident Investment Group.

title: Thomas G. Gee, 69; Ex-U.S. Judge Ruled In Creationism Case
description: Thomas Gibbs Gee, a retired judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit, died on Tuesday at Methodist Hospital in Houston. He was 69 and lived in Houston.

title: Three Unraveling Marriages in the Shadows of World War II
description: Beware the small-town play, I say, in which the characters have names like Tood, Weetsie and Aunt Ola.

title: CLINTON REPORTS PROGRESS IN TALKS IN SYRIAN CAPITAL
description: President Clinton made a one-day venture into shuttle diplomacy today in hopes of speeding the way toward an Israeli-Syrian peace. He said he won some private assurances from President Hafez al-Assad of Syria that could speed the peace talks but did not get from the Syrian leader a message that aides had hoped might soothe an anxious Israeli public.

title: Bracho Trades Award for Shot at Riding
description: A banned jockey, JESUS BRACHO, surrendered his Eclipse Award as the nation's outstanding apprentice jockey of 1992 to regain a license to race in Florida. Bracho was stripped of his right to ride after racing stewards determined that he submitted falsified riding documents from his native Venezuela. He was the most prominent of seven Venezuelan jockeys expelled in 1993 for record discrepancies. The Bracho investigation concluded that he should not have qualified as an apprentice, a designation entitling his mounts to carry less weight. Stewards suspended him for 60 days and recommended a life ban. The state division was scheduled to hear Bracho's appeal next week when the agreement was reached on a more lenient penalty.

title: An Adagio of Penn State Memories
description: Shortly before sunrise tomorrow, Anthony Davis -- jazz pianist, composer and college professor -- will become Anthony Davis college football fan. Davis and his 15-year-old son Timothy will make the four-hour drive from New York through the bluffs and waves of amber and magenta of Central Pennsylvania to his final destination: State College, Pa. Population 65,000.

title: Family Permits Skew Arab Jerusalem's Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: In Prime Time, the N.Y.P.D. Rules; 8 Million Stories About Police? It Just Seems That Many
description: A vengeful cop guns down a drug dealer for selling coma-inducing heroin to his cousin. It turns out, however, that the cousin got the drugs from someone else, and the police officer had killed the wrong person. Facing arrest, the cop shoots himself.

title: Shell Oil Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a tax credit of $ 153 million.c-Included a tax credit of $ 97 million.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: Imasco Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cuomo Relies on the Loyal For Campaign's Inner Circle
description: Above all, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo values loyalty, according to many of those who have worked for him during his 12 years in Albany. It comes as no surprise then that most of his top campaign operatives this year are longtime Cuomo aides and friends who have played significant roles in the Governor's political life.

title: Eastern Enterprises (EFU,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included pretax gain of $ 2,306,000 related to sale of barge construction and repair facilities.c-Included pretax write-down of $ 13 million related to the sale of Ionpure operations in the quarter and 9 months.(Loss)

title: Bonds Stable With G.D.P. Due Today
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved slightly higher early yesterday, with the market holding on to most of its gains as many investors moved to the sidelines ahead of today's third-quarter report on gross domestic product.

title: Hedda Nussbaum Collapses in Court While Viewing Video of Past Injuries
description: It has been seven years since Joel Steinberg last struck Hedda Nussbaum. But when a videotape of the countless injuries she suffered at his hands was played in a Manhattan courtroom yesterday, Ms. Nussbaum collapsed on the witness stand and had to be helped out of court.

title: Kerr-McGee Corp.(KMG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $ 5.3 million charge for restructuring in both the quarter and 9 months.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Agassi Defeats Martin in Three Sets Andre Agassi rallied to defeat Todd Martin, 6-7 (4-7), 6-4, 6-1, yesterday in the third round of the Stockholm Open and will face second-seeded Goran Ivanisevic, a 7-5, 6-3 winner over Andrea Gaudenzi. Michael Stich, the defending champion, defeated Jim Courier, 7-5, 6-3, and next faces Boris Becker. Top-ranked Pete Sampras had a walkover because Marc Rosset had the flu. (AP) Upset for Hingis: Fourteen-year-old Martina Hingis defeated fourth-seeded Sabine Hack, 6-3, 6-0, to advance to the Nokia Grand Prix quarterfinals in Essen, Germany. (AP) BASEBALL Giants Closer to Winning Japan Series Koichi Ogata hit a grand slam as the Yomiuri Giants beat the Seibu Lions, 9-3, last night to move to within a game of winning the four-of-seven Japan Series. (AP) YACHT RACING American Closes In on Second Place Steve Pettengill, aboard Hunter's Child, with his sights on arriving in Cape Town this morning, closed in on a second-place finish over all in the first leg of the BOC Challenge, the round-the-world race for solo sailors. It would make Pettengill, of Middletown, R.I., the first American to finish any leg of the BOC Challenge among the Class I (50 to 60 feet) leaders. HORSE SHOWS Switzerland Takes Nation's Cup Switzerland beat out Germany by less than 2 points in the Washington Hospital Center Nations' Cup at the Washington International Horse Show yesterday in Landover, Md.

title: Caballe Heads Roster For Tucker Benefit
description: Montserrat Caballe, Carol Vaness, Vladimir Atlantov, Thomas Hampson, Sherrill Milnes and Samuel Ramey are among the artists scheduled to take part in the Richard Tucker Music Foundation concert on Sunday at 6 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: There's No Escape, So Brown Just Copes
description: He has tried to block out the criticism. And Dave Brown has done a pretty good job of it. But he is in New York, after all, the media capital of the universe where a person would have to stick themselves in a refrigerator to avoid the spotlight.

title: The Spoken Word
description: INSIDE BASEBALL WITH MARVIN MILLER, Marymount Manhattan College, 221 East 71st Street, Manhattan. A lecture by the founder and former head of the Major League Baseball Players Association. Tonight at 7:15. Admission: $1. Information: (212) 517-0564.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: PATAKI FOCUSES ON ENDORSEMENT'S PRICE

title: Diner's Journal
description: Lutece, as Always

title: Lautenberg And Haytaian Spar on Issues In TV Taping
description: Sticking to their scripts as they waved props in the air, the two major candidates for the United States Senate from New Jersey yesterday taped their last scheduled televised appearance before the Nov. 8 election, using both words and body language to get their messages across.

title: The Artistry of Those Who've Lived
description: There's no other company quite like Netherlands Dance Theater 3, which appeared on Wednesday night at the Majestic Theater as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival. At a time when the choreographic accent tends to be on youth, this group is proud of the fact that all its dancers are over 40.

title: Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd.(RCL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 3,404,000, or 5 cents a share, for early retirement of debt.Royal Caribbean Cruises said that the interruption of a cruise due to an on-board intestinal illness and the subsequent cancellation of two other cruises in August cut 1994 third quarter earnings by about $ 2 million, or 4 cents a share.

title: Arabs and Jews Talk Economics
description: Make peace pay. That is the goal of the conference starting Sunday in Casablanca, Morocco. King Hassan II will play host to officials from Israel, Jordan, Egypt, Saudi Arabia and dozens of other Middle Eastern, North African and Western countries who will gather to discuss economics, not politics. Government leaders and executives from about 1,000 corporations will meet for three days to discuss joint business ventures.

title: Ruddick Corp.(RDK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 3.4 million in the quarter and year. The year was also after a gain of $ 3,869,000, or 16 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: A Down-to-Earth View at United
description: Gerald Greenwald, chairman of United Airlines, observed recently that the airline is a business of a million details. But in the three months since he took over the employee-owned company, he has subtracted a few items from that list. The toe-cleavage rule was one of the first.

title: Giuliani Cuts In Spending To Start Now
description: In blunt defiance of the City Council, the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is already moving to impose some of the $800 million in new spending cuts announced three days ago, a move the Council's leaders said yesterday could violate the City Charter.

title: Market Place; The selloff in municipal bond mutual funds picks up speed.
description: THERE are worse things in life than taxes. That, in any case, seems to be a belief taking hold with more investors in mutual funds. With interest rates heading up, enough losses have accumulated in funds that invest in municipal bonds that investors are beginning to flee in larger numbers than before.

title: Abroad at Home; The Public Citizen
description: The highest office in a democracy, Justice Brandeis used to say, is the office of citizen. Like James Madison and the others who founded the United States, he believed that Americans have a duty to be involved in the issues facing their country.

title: Issues of Race Are Raised In Simpson Jury Selection
description: Lawyers for O. J. Simpson asserted today that prosecutors were attempting, through needlessly persistent and provocative questioning, to keep blacks off the jury. Their accusations brought race to the surface of a case in which it has always lurked not far below.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Benefits column on Sunday about a dinner that was held on Monday for the University Settlement Society of New York misidentified those honored. They were Peter Riegert, an actor, and Leslie Winthrop, president of the Advertising Agency Register, an advertising service company in New York.

title: A Daughter and a Father Who's Become a Woman
description: In "The Sex of the Stars," a French Canadian film awash in sudsy histrionics, Denis Mercier portrays an astronomer who returns to Montreal after a sex-change operation to visit his 12-year-old daughter, Camille (Marianne-Coquelicot Mercier, who is not related to Mr. Mercier). When Henri-Pierre, who left Canada seven years earlier to live in New York, reappears as Marie-Pierre, his former wife, Michele (Sylvie Drapeau), goes ballistic and his former employer tells him flatly that he looks ridiculous.

title: Russian Troops Quitting a Hot Spot in Moldova
description: "They would like to spit on this agreement," said the commander of the 14th Russian Army, Lieut. Gen. Aleksandr Lebed, speaking for his troops stationed in the self-declared Trans-Dniester Republic.

title: Ten Writers Win Whiting Awards
description: Ten people have received the 1994 Whiting Awards, given annually to "writers of exceptional talent and promise." The awards, from the Mrs. Giles Whiting Foundation, carry prizes of $30,000 each.

title: Ionics Inc.(ION,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Panel on Money Symbols
description: "The Token: America's Other Money," a symposium on the use of tokens for money over the last 200 years, will take place tomorrow at the American Numismatic Society, Broadway at West 155th Street, Washington Heights. Lectures by collectors and curators will deal with various tokens and their uses, from scrip issued as currency during wartime to coins used as political campaign souvenirs. An exhibition of more than 300 vintage coins is on view at the society through December.The symposium is in two sessions, from 10 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. and from 2 to 5 P.M.. A $25 ticket includes a buffet lunch and post-symposium reception; a $50 ticket includes dinner. Information and registration: (212) 234-3130.

title: New Publisher Named at Elle
description: Hachette Filipacchi named Carl Portale publisher of Elle magazine yesterday. The appointment is effective on Monday.

title: Kaneb Services Inc.(KAB,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on issuance of units of $ 15,122,000, or 47 cents a share.

title: Espinosa Out Of Marathon
description: Andres Espinosa, the 1993 New York City Marathon champion, made his withdrawal from the 25th race on Nov. 6 official yesterday.

title: Reno Attacks Proposal on Aliens, and Aide Questions Its Legality
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she opposed a bitterly debated California ballot measure that would deny illegal immigrants educational and other social services, and one of her chief legal advisers said the proposal was open to constitutional challenge.

title: Genzyme Corp.(GENZ,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company attributed its decrease on net income for the latest quarter to an increase in its net investment in research and development of $ 6 million and an increase in its effective tax rate of 14 percentage points.

title: An Agonizing Search for Two Boys
description: Susan Smith said she stood in the middle of a dark, isolated road on Tuesday night and screamed, "I love you all" as a carjacker disappeared in the distance with her two children in the back seat. So far, the people of this small textile town in northwestern South Carolina have been unable to pray Mrs. Smith's two little boys home again.

title: ABM Treaty Failed To Cool Arms Race
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Halts Shift of Welfare Supervisors
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled yesterday that New York City cannot go forward with its plans to slash the number of supervisors in its welfare centers until it convinces him it will do a better job of providing poor people with benefits in a timely fashion.

title: Herbalife International Inc.(HERB,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
American Cyanamid Co.  (ACY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included one-time charges of $ 25 million, or 28 cents a share, related to the company's pending merger with American Home Products Corp. in both the quarter and 9 months.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 412,400,000, or $ 4.59 a share, in the quarter and $ 622,200,000, or $ 6.92 a share, in the 9 months. The 9 months also included a charge from an accounting adjustment of $ 332,600,000, or $ 3.70 a share, and a one-time charge of $ 378 million, or $ 4.21 a share, related to the Immunex acquisition.(Loss)

title: Seasoned D'Amato Aides Run the Pataki Campaign
description: Zenia Mucha, deputy campaign manager for State Senator George E. Pataki, the Republican candidate for governor, is tired of hearing charges that her current employer is dancing on strings manipulated by her former employer, United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Raul Julia of Sesame St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Citgo Petroleum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHRONICLE
description: That was not the only news out of Oxford yesterday. ARTHUR MILLER, the American playwright, has been appointed the professor of contemporary theater at the university, Reuters reported.

title: Donnelley (R.R.) & Sons (DNY,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge from cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change of $ 69,500,000, or 45 cents a share.Year-ago 9 months' income from continuing operations of $ 100,114,000, or 65 cents a share, included net gain of $ 60,800,000 from restructuring.

title: Ryland Group Inc.(RYL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 2,076,000, or 13 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net loss, which included pretax provision of $ 45 million related to the company's homebuilding activities, in the quarter and 9 months.(Loss)

title: Nets to Keep Backcourt Busy
description: When the Nets meet the Celtics tonight in the annual Hall of Fame game in Springfield, Mass., their starting backcourt of Kenny Anderson and Kevin Edwards will be given significant playing time for the first time in the preseason.

title: Interest Seen In Another Ziff Holding
description: The $1.4 billion sale of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company to Forstmann Little & Company yesterday still leaves three of the Ziff family's operations on the block, including the much-anticipated Interchange Online Network, an electronic publishing system.

title: PENNSYLVANIA POWER TO CUT UP TO 1,500 JOBS
description: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company said yesterday that it would cut 1,000 to 1,500 jobs during the next three years as part of a reorganization. The plan is the latest in Pennsylvania Power's effort to cut costs, as the power generation industry becomes more competitive. The utility, based in Allentown, has reduced the number of employees to fewer than 7,600, from 8,300, in the last three years. About 850 employees will be offered early retirement packages. The company said it could not rule out layoffs to accomplish the other job cuts.

title: Home Video
description: New Kind of Videos

title: Brokerage Firm Admits Crimes In Energy Deals
description: After more than three years of denying that it broke the law, Prudential Securities admitted yesterday for the first time that the firm committed crimes in its sale of certain limited partnerships in the 1980's and agreed to pay $330 million to resolve criminal charges.

title: Dole Food Co. (DOL,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
description: b-Included non-recurring pretax gains of $ 30.8 million related to sale of 18 percent of common stock of Castle & Cook Homes Inc. and $ 9.4 million related to sale of interest in California and Hawaiian Sugar Co.

title: Quebecor Printing Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Airgas Inc.(ARG,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
U.S. and Cuba Seem to Make Little Headway on Refugee Issue
description: The United States and Cuba have wrapped up talks here on immigration issues, making little apparent headway on the status of thousands of Cuban refugees being held in American internment camps.

title: Hoping Lions' Roar Is Not Just a Whimper
description: Tomorrow is Homecoming Day and I haven't yet decided whether or not I'm going up to Baker Field to cheer Columbia on against Princeton to what sometimes seems like its first winning season since Charles Van Doren took the quiz show title. I could justify the trip because Columbia football is the only game in town; the Yankees are playing the World Series in their dreams, the Rangers season is frozen and St. John's is a month away from loosing Felipe Lopez. But rooting for Columbia football teams is beyond mere fandom for alumni; feelings range from passionate to mixed to nil, even among those who know the difference between the Big East and the Western Canon.

title: Just a Quiet Apartment With 6 Gators
description: It was a tropical paradise -- a jungle of trees and dangling plants, an artificial sun, two murky pools, two iguanas, four turtles, a cockroach farm and (count 'em) six alligators, the largest six feet long -- all arrayed throughout a fourth-floor loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Northern States Power Co.(NSP,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Assad and Clinton Speak: Shared Quest for Peace
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Clinton and President Hafez el-Assad of Syria at a joint news conference after they met at the Presidential Palace in Damascus, as transcribed for Reuters by the Federal News Service, a private transcription company. President Assad's remarks were made through an interpreter. OPENING STATEMENTS

title: Defending Austerity, Russia Government Survives a Vote
description: After a strong speech to Parliament by the Prime Minister defending an austere draft budget for 1995, the Russian Government survived a vote of no-confidence today in the lower house.

title: SCEcorp (SCE,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings included charge of 13 cents a share in the third quarter and 17 cents a share in the nine months, for a nonrecurring charge to Mission Cos.

title: For Children
description: Halloween is no longer just about amassing 50 candy bars in one night. This year, making masks is very important, the more creative or multicultural the better. Children can also see theater programs on ghoulish themes, hear readings of ghost stories and get spooked out in all sorts of haunted places, including a windmill. All this without ever eating chocolate. (Well, a little wouldn't hurt.) Here is a selection of events in the New York metropolitan region. 'It's Alive!' and 'So, Sue Me' TriBeCa Performing Arts Center 199 Chambers Street (212) 346-8510 Recommended ages: 5 and up Through Nov. 6

title: Cuomo Remains Strong With Gay Supporters
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo stood before 550 homosexual New Yorkers at a fund-raising dinner earlier this month and said he sought their support "for the good of all the gay and lesbian people." They gave him a standing ovation.

title: INSIDE
description: Race and Simpson's Jury

description: b-Net lossLatest 9 months' revenue included full 9 months of operations from Hollywood Casino-Aurora, which opened in June 1993.(Loss)

title: Paine Appoints Kidder Official
description: Paine Webber Group Inc. named the No. 3 executive at Kidder, Peabody & Company, Michael D. Madden, to the new position of vice chairman of Paine Webber.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Former G.E. Unit Manager Tells of Meeting on Prices
description: A General Electric official met with officials of a rival, De Beers Centenary A.G., to discuss stabilizing prices of industrial diamonds, a key witness in the G.E. price-fixing trial testified today.

title: Japan Tobacco Plunges 24% On Its First Day of Trading
description: The preparations for the share offering were bumpy, the auction was a failure and the opening of trading today in the newly listed Japan Tobacco Inc. was just short of a debacle.

title: Sports of The Times; Big News: Let There Be Games
description: THIS is why I wanted to jump up and give Charles Grantham and David Stern a great big hug yesterday: they gave me someplace to go this winter.

title: Orion Capital Corp.(OC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain of $ 11,825,000, or 81 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.Latest periods included after-tax investment gains of $ 790,000, or 6 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 1,476,000, or 10 cents a share, in the 9 months, compared with $ 717,000, or 5 cents a share, and $ 4,548,000, or 31 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Fiery Volcano In Colombia Spewing Gold
description: A volcano in Colombia is spewing more than a pound of gold each day into the atmosphere, a scientist said yesterday. He said the volcano was also depositing 45 pounds of gold a year into the rocks lining its crater.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas (BU,N) reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 12.5 million on sale of Canadian gas exploration and production company and an after-tax write-off of $ 11.5 million of an investment in a propane company.

title: Proof of Punk's Currency
description: How fast can a band play without sacrificing melody? How loud can a singer scream while still carrying a tune? How can a band stay on the edge without going over the top? These are questions today's aspiring punk-rockers seem to be asking themselves.

title: Everything Half-Off? Clinton Brings President's Day Sale to Syria
description: Along the narrow alleys of this city's labyrinthine souk, merchants trying to lure passing tourists inside their cluttered shops were practicing a new line this morning. "American?" asked one, idling in a doorway framed by bolts of brightly colored cloth. "Come inside. Today, for Clinton, we give you half-off off everything."

title: Gen. Yang Dezhi, 83, Dies; Was Chinese Army Chief
description: Gen. Yang Dezhi, a Chinese military leader for more than half a century and a former Army Chief of Staff who opposed the Tiananmen Square crackdown, died on Tuesday, the official New China News Agency reported. He was 83. The cause of death was not given.

title: Conseco Inc.(CNC,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included trading loss of $ 800,000, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 600,000, or 4 cents a share, in the 9 months and realized losses of $ 4.3 million, or 16 cents a share, and $ 8.7 million, or 27 cents a share, in quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 9 months also included a restructuring gain of $ 42.4 million, or $ 1.58 a share, and a charge from early retirement of debt of $ 2.4 million, or 9 cents a share.c-Included trading income of $ 16.1 million, or 48 cents a share, and $ 43.1 million, or $ 1.30 a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively; realized gains of $ 1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9.5 million, or 29 cents a share, in the 9 months.Periods also included a restructuring charge of $ 1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, and $ 83.3 million, or $ 2.85 a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 9 months also included a charge from early retirement of debt of $ 10.9 million, or 37 cents a share.

title: Kuwait Is Allowing U.S. to Station a Squadron of Warplanes
description: Kuwait has agreed to allow the United States to station a squadron of 24 warplanes there as part of a broad effort to curb Iraqi military power, the Pentagon said today.

title: BC Telecom reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Earnings from BC Tel Mobility Cellular increased 4 cents a share in the third quarter. Cellular customer growth in the first 9 months of 1994 exceeded earlier growth expectations for the entire year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: America's Cup Racers Get Taste of Real Thing
description: The world championship for America's Cup yachts will bring top players to the field when it begins here Friday. But for participants, the series is like preseason football: being there is more important than winning, and watching others is more valuable than being seen.

title: Alberto-Culver Co. (ACV,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in New York City that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend

title: Williams Talks at Schools in Poor Areas
description: VENUS WILLIAMS, the newest 14-year-old phenom to turn pro, made a whistle-stop tour of two schools and a tennis center yesterday in the heart of the inner city in Oakland, Calif.

title: Bagwell's Latest Stat: All the M.V.P. Votes
description: Jeff Bagwell, the Red Sox reject who led the National League in four key batting categories as a first baseman for the Houston Astros, was the unanimous choice as the league's most valuable player yesterday, strengthening his reputation in Boston as the second going of Babe Ruth.

title: Fisher Scientific International Inc.(FSH,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mapco Inc.(MDA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included charge of $ 1.52 a share from settlement of a royalty oil dispute with state of Alaska.

title: Burlington Raises Offer For Santa Fe
description: Competing with a hostile bid by the Union Pacific Corporation, Burlington Northern Inc. raised its stock swap offer yesterday to acquire the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation to $3.25 billion, from the original $2.7 billion, when the merger was announced on June 30.

title: Self-Mockery, Sincere Kind Of Flattery
description: As award shows go, George Schlatter's "Comedy Hall of Fame" has the distinct advantage of not daring to take itself too seriously. Jonathan Winters, one of last year's inductees, insists the somewhat clunky-looking award makes a great doorstop. George Carlin, in this year's charmed circle, uneasily notes that the event is "the kind of thing comedians should make fun of." They do, albeit gently and sometimes sentimentally, on tomorrow's "Second Annual Comedy Hall of Fame" on NBC.

title: On My Mind; Bitburg and Beyond
description: Since President Clinton had to conclude his pilgrimage to Syria without getting any decent peace newsbreaks for his trouble, or time to take the exciting tourist trip to the two dozen torture centers of Damascus or the mortar ranges of the rich variety of terrorist camps, I thought he might be in the mood for a nice Hasidic joke.

title: AST Research (ASTA,NNM) reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net income(Loss)

title: N.B.A. Truce Is Good, But Accord Is a Must
description: The National Basketball Association and its players, in a fit of wisdom, have vowed to preserve their coming season. That wins them points, whereas major league baseball and professional hockey managed to win none this year.

title: Warner Music Officials Settle a Power Struggle
description: A power struggle that broke out this week in the executive ranks of the Warner Music Group seemed to abate late today, with Doug Morris emerging as a winner over his boss, Robert J. Morgado, the chairman and chief executive of the group, the world's biggest record distributor and the most profitable arm of Time Warner Inc.

title: No Headline
description: "I gotta be out of my head. I never win anything. Sometimes I think people ought to just take the money, buy a new tie and look for a better job." RICK CONIGLIO, a Buffalo optician, buying five lottery tickets. [ B3:1. ]

title: The Phony Use of Genuine Grief
description: Families of murder victims have heartbreaking stories to tell. But candidates for political office all over the country are displaying a distasteful tendency to exploit these stories for their own benefit. This is a shameful new form of victim abuse. The shame is compounded when the politician fraudulently uses a family's bereavement to argue for the death penalty and to depict an opponent as soft on crime.

title: Transamerica Corp.(TA,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss of $ 700,000, or 1 cent a share, from discontinued operations.c-Included certain items that had a net benefit of $ 25.1 million, or 32 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months. The periods also included a loss of $ 2.2 million, or 3 cents a share, and income of $ 3.2 million, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively, from discontinued operations.Latest periods included investment gains of 9 cents a share in the quarter and 15 cents a share in the 9 months, compared with 12 cents a share and 39 cents a share in year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Serenity Becomes Dramatic
description: Weslia Whitfield, the cabaret singer from San Francisco who has become a regular visitor to New York, smooths out the rougher psychological edges of everything she performs to create a mood of calm, homey gentility.

title: The Great Debate Debate: Hopefuls Clash on Oratory
description: Continuing one of the most grueling debate schedules in the nation, the four candidates for governor of Connecticut took one another on twice today -- a sort of day-night double-header -- staking out opposing positions on whether to eliminate the central legacy of Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s administration -- the state income tax.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CHRONICLE
description: The speeches at the Oxford Union, the prestigious debating society at England's Oxford University, tend to be lofty and the tones stentorian. But tonight, the delivery is sure to be, well, down to earth, when Kermit the Frog takes the podium.

title: Ambac Inc.(ABK,N) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 98,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: P.& G. Sues Bankers Trust Over Swap Deal
description: The Procter & Gamble Company yesterday sued the Bankers Trust Company over a complex financial transaction that caused P.& G., the Cincinnati consumer products company, to take a $102 million loss in April.

title: Restaurants
description: "Welcome home!" says the proprietor as you walk in the door.

title: Upstate, Pataki's New Message: Giuliani Endorsement Has Price
description: State Senator George E. Pataki's campaign allies suggested today that they would use Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's endorsement of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to their advantage, telling voters outside the city that Mr. Cuomo would have to pay Mr. Giuliani back with fiscal help to the city after the election.

title: INTROGEN AND RHONE-POULENC IN GENE THERAPY PACT
description: Introgen Therapeutics Inc. signed an agreement yesterday with Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc. to develop gene therapy cancer products. Introgen said the agreement had a potential value to the company of up to $50 million. Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, which is based in Collegeville, Pa., and is a subsidiary of the French chemical and health products giant Rhone-Poulenc, will finance all the research and development worldwide and will receive exclusive manufacturing and commercial rights in Europe. Introgen, based in Austin, Tex., and Rhone-Poulenc Rorer will have joint promotion rights in North America, and both companies will have the right to develop and market products in Japan, Korea, India, China and Australia.

title: Divisiveness of Shrine Issue Forces Clinton to Drop Tour
description: A nonevent today on President Clinton's Jerusalem schedule rekindled the long conflict between Arabs and Jews over who has sovereignty of this holy but eternally difficult city.

title: Salomon Plans Big Pay Cuts If Business Doesn't Improve
description: Losing money on much of its operations this year, Salomon Brothers yesterday announced a new compensation plan for next year that would sharply cut the pay of many of its highest-paid executives if business did not improve.

title: Diverse Expressions Of a Body Obsession
description: In New York in the 1940's, the Russian-born artist Pavel Tchelitchev was sometimes seen as Jackson Pollock's chief rival. His work was actively promoted by Charles Henri Ford, editor of View magazine and his lover; his patrons included Edith Sitwell and Gertrude Stein, and the Museum of Modern Art acquired "Hide-and-Seek," a large and elaborate Surrealist fantasy, the year he finished it.

title: Two Masters of a Medium in Their Early Years
description: The early works of well-known photographers often reveal stylistic roots that are hidden in later, more polished images. Two very different but equally fascinating shows in Manhattan, photographs by Robert Frank at the Pace/MacGill Gallery and by Garry Winogrand at the Bonni Benrubi Gallery, offer a chance to examine early pictures by leading figures in recent American photography.

title: Sparks Could Miss 2 Weeks
description: Word out of the Giants late last night was that cornerback Phillippi Sparks would not only miss Sunday's game against the Lions but could miss two weeks of action because of a severe groin injury.

title: Clinic Trials of French Abortion Pill Begin in U.S.
description: Trials of the French abortion pill RU-486 have begun in the United States, the Population Council said yesterday. But the organization said it would make no general announcement of the sites where women could obtain the drug because of concerns about potential violence.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Every Picture Tells a Story' 'Word and Image in American Folk Art' Museum of American Folk Art 2 Lincoln Square (at 65th Street) Through Jan. 15

title: Legal Aid Strike Left Unresolved Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Parents of Disabled Battle for a $160 Million Plan
description: Eileen Stuart is a rookie at campaigning, but she's been out most days lately trying to persuade New Jersey voters to approve a $160 million bond issue for housing for the disabled. Today, she put a stack of fliers at the local bakery. Before that, she left some at her hairdresser's and at a supermarket, a restaurant, a school, a doctor's office and with her rabbi.

title: Smoking Out California's Proposition 188
description: To the Editor:

title: A 16-Year-Old Turns Professional, Too
description: MEILEN TU, the 16-year-old United States Open junior singles champion, also chose next week in Oakland, Calif., for her professional debut on Monday. "Her future is going ahead, improving her game," said MEI TU, Meilen's mother and coach. "There is no reason to play juniors. I think this is a process. Nothing too exciting. Being pro is no different for Meilen. It's just a high level." Tu beat MARTINA HINGIS, widely acknowledged as the world's best junior, for the Open junior singles title in September.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a Federal price-fixing case against the General Electric Company misstated the Justice Department's record in taking criminal antitrust cases to trial. G.E.'s is not the only criminal antitrust trial. It is one of the most significant since 1981, according to the department's records, which also list 199 other criminal antitrust trials.

title: Ukraine Wins Pledges of Support at Canadian Finance Meeting
description: Ukraine, whose economy has nosedived since independence three years ago, won pledges for hundreds of millions of dollars in international financial support today to prop up the market-oriented reforms of its new President, Leonid D. Kuchma.

title: Kathleen L. Schwaninger, 50, An Advocate for the Disabled
description: Kathleen L. Schwaninger, an advocate for the disabled who played a critical role in the decade-long effort to close down the Willowbrook State School for the mentally retarded on Staten Island and who went on to help found an agency to aid seriously ill children, died Sunday in a plane crash in Hyannis, Mass. She was 50 and lived in Brooklyn and East Falmouth, Mass.

title: A Satirical Look at Black Yuppies
description: In "Drop Squad," Bruford Jamison Jr. (Eriq LaSalle), a token black employee at an advertising agency, is supposed to help pitch dubious products to what his white boss calls "the colored community." Bruford's accounts include Mumblin' Jack Malt Liquor, a beverage "available everywhere black people are served."

title: Macmillan Bloedel reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 20.8 million, or 17 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 9.7 million, or 8 cents a share, in the 9 months, related to the gain on the sale of the Harmac pulp business.c-Net lossd-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 12 million, or 11 cents a share, and $ 26.4 million, or 23 cents a share, in the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The 9 months also included a nontaxable gain of $ 39 million on the disposal of the investment in U.K. Corrugated. The per-share amount was not disclosed.(Loss)Year-ago periods were restated.Preferred-share dividends were $ 1.2 million in latest quarter, compared with $ 1 million in year-ago period, and $ 3.1 million in latest 9 months, against $ 3.6 million in year-ago period.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday, about a decline in the shares of Outboard Marine, misidentified the exchange where its options are traded. It is the Chicago Board Options Exchange, not the American Stock Exchange.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: HASBRO INC., Pawtucket, R.I., a toy maker, agreed to manufacture and market several lines of toys under the name of Nickelodeon, the children's cable television network, a registered trademark of MTV Networks, a division of Viacom Inc., Dedham, Mass. HEWLETT-PACKARD CO., Palo Alto, Calif., has agreed to acquire Versatest Inc., a privately held maker of test equipment for computer chips, including flash memory devices, on Oct. 31. The terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Appeals Court Rules Against Minority Plan
description: The University of Maryland may not award a group of scholarships exclusively to black students, a Federal appeals court ruled yesterday in a decision that challenged the policy of the Clinton Administration.

title: At U.N.L.V., the Tarkanian Era Hovers in the Rafters
description: Their gym was locked, their coach was in the Poconos and their only authority figure was a trainer. They were like an intramural team; no one had custody.

title: New Museum Celebrating American Indian Voices
description: IT has been said that America will never know peace until the damage done to its native people has been acknowledged and their cultural birthright restored. The National Museum of the American Indian, which officially opens Sunday at the Alexander Hamilton United States Custom House in lower Manhattan, may someday be counted a significant step toward that end.

title: Give President Credit for Restoring Tax Equity; Official Jobless Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Give President Credit for Restoring Tax Equity
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Warner and BellSouth Cool to License Bids
description: Two of the largest companies aspiring to offer wireless telephone services plan to hold off bidding during part or all of the forthcoming high-stakes auctions for radio licenses.

title: Woolworth
description: Shares of Woolworth moved in a narrow range yesterday as the retailer continued its search for a new chief executive. This month, the Council of Institutional Investors included Woolworth on a list of 20 companies delivering the worst return to stockholders.

Billings were estimated at $2.5 million.

title: Pitney Bowes Is Planning To Reduce Its Staff by 2,000
description: Pitney Bowes Inc., the maker of postage meters and mailing equipment, said yesterday that it would cut its worldwide staff by 2,000 employees in the next year.

title: Disclosure Rules Proposed on Lead Hazards
description: The Clinton Administration has proposed rules that would require sellers of homes, landlords and real-estate agents to disclose "known information" about lead-based paint hazards before they sold or leased most housing built before 1978.

title: Noe Says Five Days Of Racing Are Enough
description: Kenneth Noe Jr. took the reins as president and general manager of New York's race tracks yesterday and promptly said: "We've got too much racing in this country, and I intend to do something real quick."

title: Article 658847 -- No Title
description: When most people think of Japanese restaurants nowadays, they think of sushi and seafood, of noodles and soup, of intricately prepared and precisely arranged ingredients that appeal to the eye as well as to the mouth. They rarely think of beef, unless it is Kobe beef, the novelty dish that goes for around $100 a steak.

title: One Little Word Pervades Robb-North Race: Liar
description: As the Senate race winds down in Virginia, accusations of lying continue to cloud many of the issues that separate the Democratic incumbent, Charles S. Robb, and his Republican challenger, Oliver L. North.

title: D.M.B.& B. Gets T.W.A. Account
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. named its third agency in five years yesterday by selecting D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in St. Louis to handle its account, with billings estimated at more than $40 million. The assignment had been expected since the airline and Bates Worldwide in New York agreed earlier this month not to renew their yearlong contract when it expires at the end of December.

description: Convinced that Africa has made more progress than any other confederation in the last decade, the world governing body of soccer yesterday awarded that continent, along with Europe, a two-team increase for the 1998 World Cup in France.
